name: Billionaires
bio: America's most beloved investor is now the world's richest man. Soared past friend and bridge partner Bill Gates as shares of Berkshire Hathaway climbed 25% since the middle of last July. Son of Nebraska politician delivered newspapers as a boy. Filed first tax return at age 13, claiming $35 deduction for bicycle. Studied under value investing guru Benjamin Graham at Columbia. Took over textile firm Berkshire Hathaway 1965. Today holding company invested in insurance (Geico, General Re), jewelry (Borsheim's), utilities (MidAmerican Energy), food (Dairy Queen, See's Candies). Also has noncontrolling stakes in Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, Wells Fargo. Insurance operations flourished in 2007. "That party is over. It's a certainty that insurance-industry profit margins, including ours, will fall significantly in 2008." The Oracle of Omaha issued a challenge to members of The Forbes 400 in October; said he would donate $1 million to charity if the collective group of richest Americans would admit they pay less taxes, as a percentage of income, than their secretaries. Had long promised to give away his fortune posthumously. Irrevocably earmarked the majority of his Berkshire shares to charity in 2006, mostly to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Gift was valued at $31 billion on day of announcement; donation will far exceed that sum so long as Berkshire shares continue to rise.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second-richest man in the world this year; even richer than Microsoft's Bill Gates, at least for now, thanks to strong Mexican equities market and the performance of his wireless telephone company, America Movil. The son of a Lebanese immigrant, Slim made his first fortune in 1990 when he bought fixed line operator Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) in a privatization. In December, America Movil struck a deal with Yahoo to provide mobile Web services to 16 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. A widower and father of six, Slim is a baseball fan and art collector. He keeps his art collection in Mexico City's Museo Soumaya, which he named after his late wife. In recent years, he has donated close to $7 billion worth of cash and stock to fund education and health projects, and to the revitalization of Mexico City's downtown historical district.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard dropout and Microsoft visionary no longer the world's richest man. Blame Yahoo: Microsoft shares have fallen 15% since the company boldly attempted to merge with the search engine giant to better fight Google for Internet dominance. Gates is preparing to give up day-to-day involvement in the company he cofounded 33 years ago to spend more time focused on his philanthropic endeavors. Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has $38.7 billion in assets, donates to causes aimed at bringing financial tools to the poor, speeding up the development of vaccines (for AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis), bettering America's lagging high schools. Sells 20 million Microsoft shares every quarter, proceeds going to private investment vehicle Cascade; more than half of net worth now outside of Microsoft. Company spent $6 billion to land Web ad firm Aquantive last May. Would-be rival to Apple's iPod, the Zune, not yet a hit. Believes Microsoft's far-flung bets, including 10-year affair with Internet-based television, may soon pay off; says next 10 years will be the "most interesting" in software history.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads world's largest steelmaker, $105 billion (sales) ArcelorMittal, which accounts for 10% of all crude steel production. Just delivered 580 tons to be used in construction of the World Trade Center memorial in New York. With 44% stake, is the company's largest shareholder. Longtime inhabitant of London is Europe's richest resident. Mittal began his career working in his family's steelmaking business in India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's richest resident heads petrochemicals giant Reliance Industries, India's most valuable company by market cap. His fortune is up $22.9 billion since last year, making him the world's second biggest gainer in terms of dollars. The biggest gainer was his estranged brother Anil, who ranks 6th in the world just behind his older brother. The sons inherited their fortune from their late father, renowned industrialist Dhirubhai Ambani.  But they couldn't get along and in 2005 their mother brokered a peace settlement breaking up the family's assets. Mukesh is using some of his money to build a 27-story home.

name: Billionaires
bio: The year's biggest gainer, Ambani is up $23.8 billion in the past year, and is closing the gap with his estranged brother, Mukesh, who ranks one spot ahead of him in the world at number five. The sons inherited their fortune from their late father, renowned industrialist Dhirubhai Ambani.  But they couldn't get along and in 2005 their mother brokered a peace settlement breaking up the family's assets. A marathon runner, his biggest asset is his 65% stake in telecom venture Reliance Communications. He recently raised $3 billion from the highly anticipated initial offering of his Reliance Power, the biggest in India's history. Despite the hype, the stock tumbled 17% immediately after its February listing. In a bid to appease investors, company's board recently approved the issue of bonus shares. Still feuding with brother Mukesh: battling him in court over a gas-supply agreement.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Peddled matches, fish, pens, Christmas cards and other items by bicycle as a
teenager. Started selling furniture in 1947. Now his company Ikea, which sells hip designs for the cost conscious, is one of the most beloved retailers in the world, with an almost cultlike following. Ikea now has stores in 40 countries, from Sunrise, Florida, to Guangzhou in China. As egalitarian as his brand, Kamprad avoids wearing suits, flies economy class and frequents cheap restaurants. Has been quoted as saying that his luxuries are the occasional nice cravat and Swedish fish roe. Says his home is furnished mostly with his own Ikea products. Last May was awarded the Global Economy Prize by the University of Kiel for his contributions to society.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singh is now the world's richest real estate baron after listing his real estate development company DLF in 2007. The offering helped triple his fortune to $30 billion this year, up from $10 billion. A former army officer, known as K.P., he joined his father-in-law's Delhi Land & Finance in 1961. Singh later built DLF City in Gurgaon, his showpiece township on the outskirts of Delhi, by acquiring land from farmers. Over time, he transformed it into one of India's biggest real estate developers. Group plans to raise another $1.5 billion by listing a subsidiary in Singapore. A keen golfer, he now leaves son Rajiv, daughter Pia to run operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former metals trader survived the gangster wars in the post-Soviet aluminum industry. His holding company, Basic Element, now owns Russian Aluminum (UC Rusal), automobile manufacturer GAZ, aircraft manufacturer Aviacor and insurance company Ingosstrakh. In 2006 Rusal, SUAL and Glencore International, of Switzerland, merged their aluminum assets into the United Company Rusal,  the world's largest aluminum producer. Married to a relative of Yeltsin, Deripaska has been busy expanding UC Rusal's activities in Russia and abroad, moving it into aluminum production in Nigeria and China. To integrate vertically, has signed agreements to produce coal in Kazakhstan and invest in a nuclear power plant in eastern Russia. Attempting to get a stake in Norilsk Nickel, which co-owner (and fellow billionaire) Vladimir Potanin is fighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Germany's richest man. After World War II Karl and his younger brother, Theo, developed their mother's corner grocery store into discount supermarket giant Aldi, which now has more than 8,000 stores and $67 billion in sales. They eventually split ownership and management of the chain into North and South regions. Now retired, Karl used to manage more profitable southern half of Aldi's business in Germany. Fiercely private: Little known about him other than that he apparently raises orchids and plays golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once a poor immigrant, Li got his start selling plastic flowers in Hong Kong in the 1950s. Now Hong Kong's richest person. His fortune is centered on conglomerates Cheung Kong and Hutchison Whampoa. Through them, he is the world's largest operator of container terminals, world's largest health and beauty retailer, a major supplier of electricity to Hong Kong and a real estate developer. Hutchison Essar sold its stake in an Indian mobile business for $11 billion in 2007; the group still has other telecom interests. Li also has a $12 billion stake in Canadian oil company Husky Energy. He has announced plans to donate one-third of wealth over time. Eldest son Victor helps him run his massive empire; son Richard struck out on his own in early 1990s and is a billionaire in his own right.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cabdriver's son borrowed $200 from uncle to sell newspapers at age 12. Studied voice in teens, later dropped out of City College in New York City to become court reporter. Made first fortune in trade shows. Created computer industry's marquee event, Comdex, mid-1980s; sold show to Japan's Softbank for $862 million 1995. Then Vegas: bought Sands Hotel & Casino for $128 million, demolished it to build the $1.5 billion all-suites Venetian Resort Hotel Casino and the 1.2-million-square-foot Sands Convention Center. Changed the way casinos do business by enticing conventioneers to Sin City midweek, taking emphasis off gambling. Sold suites for $250 a night, added high-end retailers, celebrity-chef restaurants. Took Las Vegas Sands public December 2004. In January opened $1.9 billion Palazzo resort next to nemesis Steve Wynn's (see) Wynn Las Vegas. All in on Asia: opened $265 million Sands Macau Casino May 2004, recouped entire investment in one year. Unveiled $2.4 billion Venetian Macau in August; 10.5-million-square-foot mega-resort features 3,400 slots, 800 tables, 3,000 suites and a convention center. Won coveted Singapore gaming license last year; building $3.6 billion Marina Bay Sands on 51-acre site with a view of city's skyline.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Las Vegas Sands', 'uri': 'companies/las-vegas-sands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
Arnault put up $15 million from his family's midsize construction firm to buy Christian Dior in 1985. Since then he has built the world's largest luxury goods empire, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, whose brands also include Dom Perignon, Fendi and Tag Heuer. LVMH, which he still heads, acquired premier French financial daily "Les Echos" from the Pearson group last December. Son Antoine, 28, and daughter, Delphine, 32, sit on LVMH's board. Arnault has also set up an investment fund with his good friend and fellow billionaire, Albert Frere, in 2006; the pair own two wineries together. Via his investment arm, Groupe Arnault, owns French tour operator Go Voyages and a stake in French retail chain Carrefour. Arnault often spends New Year's Eve in his four-star hotel, Le Cheval Blanc, in ski resort
Courchevel, France. He is also said to be a skilled pianist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oracle titan reshaping the software industry via acquisition; has purchased 21 firms for more than $19 billion since the beginning of 2006. Forging into retail, business intelligence software; determined to squeeze out German rival SAP. Biggest challenge: making the myriad applications work together for the release of Oracle Fusion later this year. Chicago bred tech tycoon studied physics at U. of Chicago; didn't graduate. Started Oracle in 1977. Took public in 1986, a day before Microsoft. Companies have been fiercely competitive since. Side bet: invested $125 million in Web software outfit NetSuite. Still yearning to win yachting's most prestigious trophy, the America's Cup. Lost last year to Luna Rossi. Also owns 453-foot Rising Sun; building a smaller leisure boat because megayacht is hard to park.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Orphaned as a child, Abramovich dropped out of college, then made a fortune in a series of controversial oil export deals in early 1990s. His fortune took off in 1995 when he teamed up with Boris Berezovsky (now also a billionaire) to take over oil giant Sibneft at a fraction of its market value. (When Berezovsky fled Russia in 2000 to escape fraud charges, he sold out to Abramovich.) In 2003 to 2004 he sold stake in Russian Aluminum to fellow billionaire Oleg Deripaska, who is now ranked 9th in the world. In 2005 Abramovich liquidated his biggest asset, selling 72.6% stake in Sibneft to gas titan Gazprom for $13 billion. In 2006 he bought stake in the country's largest steelmaker, Evraz Group, and early in 2008, a piece of Highland Gold, a U.K. mining company with operations in Russia. He also spent some of his cash buying U.K. soccer club, Chelsea. He recently finalized divorce from the mother of his five children, Irina, but largely stays out of public eye, except for occasional spottings with rumored girlfriend Daria Zhukova.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of L'Oreal founder Eugene Schueller, a man who is said to have a checkered past with wartime ties to the Nazi regime, Liliane is the world's richest woman, thanks to her controlling stake in the cosmetics giant. She has held the stock for more than four decades. She became a widow last November when her 88-year old husband, Andre Bettencourt died. Her Bettencourt Schueller Foundation supports medical, cultural and humanitarian endeavors in France and developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of mill worker parents, Mordashov studied economics in Leningrad in mid-1980s. He was later named finance director of a steel mill. When the plant's elderly general director instructed him to buy up company shares so it would not fall into the hands of an outsider, Mordashov bought most of them himself. He became general director and built it into a conglomerate, acquiring automakers, coal companies, ports and transportation companies. Today his Severstal is Russia1s third-largest steel company but is looking to get much bigger. In a bid to expand internationally, Mordashov bought Rouge Industries of Dearborn, Mich. and Italian steel producer Lucchini but in 2006 lost widely publicized battle for steel giant Arcelor to powerful rival and fellow billionaire Lakshmi Mittal. In late 2007 he presided over the opening of a new mini-mill in Mississippi, in which he is biggest investor. One holding he cashed out of last year was Severstal-Auto.

name: Billionaires
bio: The most active and successful investor in the Middle East took his investment vehicle, Kingdom Holding, public on the Saudi stock exchange in July 2007. Kingdom Holding contains his investments in well-known companies such as Citigroup and News Corp., as well as Four Seasons Hotels and Fairmont Hotel management companies, among many others. The share price of Kingdom Holding does not fully reflect the 45% drop in stock price of Citigroup, his largest investment, in 2007. Alwaleed joined the Singapore government investment arm and several other investors in a $12.5 billion capital injection for Citigroup in January 2008; the size of his investment is undisclosed. In the early 1990s, Alwaleed made a risky bet on Citigroup that paid off hugely; in recent years it accounted for nearly half his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fridman spent his childhood in Ukrainian city of Lvov and studied at the Moscow Institute of Steel & Alloys in 1980s. He founded Alfa Group in 1990s with college friends (and now fellow billionaires) German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev; it's now a diverse conglomerate with oil, retail, telecom and banking interests. Strong Kremlin connections include a former subordinate who now serves as a political adviser to Putin. In 2003 he merged his oil company, TNK, with British oil giant BP, an achievement, considering that six years prior the two parties were fighting, with protesting his methods for taking over a partly BP-owned oilfield. Now focusing on telecom; his Altimo group has telecom holdings in Ukraine, Turkey, Russia and Uzbekistan. In 2007 Fridman was declared unofficial winner of a protracted and multimillion-dollar legal battle over a stake in Russia's third-largest mobile carrier, Megafon.

name: Billionaires
bio: A proletarian success story. First job was as mechanic in coal mine. After college in Siberia got job as steelworker. In 1991, when his boss was appointed minister of metallurgy, Lisin came with him to Moscow. In 1992 he joined up with tough group of traders called Trans-World Group; they came to dominate Russia's aluminum and steel exports. He managed the factories, and when the partners went their separate ways in 2000, Lisin got majority stake in Russia's giant Novolipetsk steel mill as his share. In early 2004, moved to control transport of his products by purchasing the port in St. Petersburg for an undisclosed sum; recently transferred the port from one of his companies to another.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a railway worker. With help from then-wife Rosalia Mera (see), got start making dressing gowns and lingerie in their living room 45 years ago. Business became one of world's most successful apparel manufacturers, $12 billion (2006 sales) Inditex. Group now has 3,245 stores in 66 countries. Ortega is chairman. Through his investment vehicles has invested in gas, tourism, banks and real estate; has properties in Madrid, Paris, London, Lisbon, plus luxury hotel and apartment complex in Miami. Owns a horse-jumping circuit and part of a soccer league. Shuns neckties. Ortega may be looking to his succession. Daughter Marta is now working at Inditex; reports are she is being grooomed to eventually take his place.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest brother Walter “temporarily” stepped down as chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties after disputing with his mother and two younger siblings over his unpopular long-term girlfriend. Family inherited company from late father; now one of Hong Kong’s largest landowners. Also has interests in telecom operator SmarTone-Vodafone; Hong Kong’s largest bus operator, KMB. Raised $1.4 billion in October share placement to be used for China investments, expected to top $10 billion in 3 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: With fellow billionaire Vladimir Potanin built holding company Interros by winning over the corporate customers of two huge Soviet-era banks in 1992. The group has interests in metals, engineering, agriculture and media. Soon after his highly publicized arrest (and release without charges) in the French ski town of Courchevel in early 2007, he and Potanin announced they were dividing up their holdings in Interros. Potanin would buy out Prokhorov's stake in Norilsk Nickel, the world's largest producer of nickel and palladium; Prokhorov would purchase his partner's stake in publicly traded Polyus Gold, Russia's largest gold miner. But settlement is on hold as of early 2008: Fellow metals tycoon (and billionaire) Oleg Deripaska is trying to buy a part of Prokhorov's Norilsk holding, with the fun-loving Prokhorov getting shares in aluminum giant UC Rusal.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With fellow billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov built large holding company
Interros by winning over the corporate customers of two huge Soviet-era
banks in 1992. The two later took control of metals giant Norilsk Nickel and
oil company Sidanco in controversial "loans-for-shares" auctions. Has
variously served as a deputy prime minister of the economy and as partner to
George Soros in telecom monopoly Svyazinvest. Active in philanthropy in
Russia; supporter of the arts. In 2007 Interros partners announced a
"divorce" of sorts, in which Potanin would buy Prokhorov's stake in Norilsk
Nickel (Russia's largest nickel producer) and Prokhorov would get his
partner's stake in publicly traded Polyus Gold, Russia1s largest gold miner.
As of early 2008 this is on hold, though, as fellow billionaire Oleg
Deripaska attempts to buy Prokhorov's Norilsk stake, much to Potanin's
chagrin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter-in-law of retail pioneer Sam Walton. Mother-in-law, Helen, passed away last April; matriarch's fortune to pass to charity over next few years. Sam began retail career 1940 making $75 a month as J.C. Penney clerk. Opened Ben Franklin 5-and-10 store in Newport, Ark. 5 years later; lost lease 1950. With brother James opened chain of general stores in Bentonville, Ark. 1962. Took Wal-Mart public 1970, now world's largest retailer, with more than 6,800 stores in 14 countries; 1.9 million employees. Sales: $375 billion. Family controls 40%. Christy: widow of John Walton (d. 2005) supports school choice programs for underprivileged kids.
title: Co-Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of retail pioneer Sam Walton. Mom, Helen, passed away last April; matriarch's fortune to pass to charity over next few years. Sam began retail career 1940 making $75 a month as J.C. Penney clerk. Opened Ben Franklin 5-and-10 store in Newport, Ark. 5 years later; lost lease 1950. With brother James opened chain of general stores in Bentonville, Ark. 1962. Took Wal-Mart public 1970, now world's largest retailer, with more than 6,800 stores in 14 countries; 1.9 million employees. Sales: $375 billion. Family controls 40%. Jim: oversees family banking business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of retail pioneer Sam Walton. Mom, Helen, passed away last April; matriarch's fortune to pass to charity over next few years. Sam began retail career 1940 making $75 a month as J.C. Penney clerk. Opened Ben Franklin 5-and-10 store in Newport, Ark. 5 years later; lost lease 1950. With brother James opened chain of general stores in Bentonville, Ark. 1962. Took Wal-Mart public 1970, now world's largest retailer, with more than 6,800 stores in 14 countries; 1.9 million employees. Sales: $375 billion. Family controls 40%. Rob: company's first lawyer; now chairman.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Developer made correct prediction in 2007 on rising China stocks, climbing oil prices, weak U.S. dollar. Criticized for using his clout to get access to numerous prelisted offerings; still, investment success has earned him nickname of "Asia's Warren Buffett."

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of retail pioneer Sam Walton. Mom, Helen, passed away last April; matriarch's fortune to pass to charity over next few years. Sam began retail career 1940 making $75 a month as J.C. Penney clerk. Opened Ben Franklin 5-and-10 store in Newport, Ark. 5 years later; lost lease 1950. With brother James opened chain of general stores in Bentonville, Ark. 1962. Took Wal-Mart public 1970, now world's largest retailer, with more than 6,800 stores in 14 countries; 1.9 million employees. Sales: $375 billion. Family controls 40%. Alice: raises horses, founded American art museum in Bentonville.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control of family fortune after his father, Kenneth Thomson, died. Had already succeeded his father as chairman of Thomson Corp., a media conglomerate in which family has a 70% stake, in 2002. Grandfather Roy founded the business 1934. Made bid in May to acquire Reuters for $17 billion. Company traded away traditional printed titles in order to move into software and electronic media for professionals, like Westlaw, a legal research tool. With his brother Peter also serves as cochair of family's investment concern, Woodbridge. Well-known art collector engaged to Kelly Rowan, star of defunct TV show The O.C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Larry Page (see) in computer science Ph.D. program at Stanford. Brin emigrated from Russia, Page grew up in Michigan; both sons of professors. Dropped out of school to start Google in 1998 from friend's garage. Initially financed by Stanford endowment, angel investors K. Ram Shriram, Andy von Bechtolsheim. Raised another $25 million from venture capital firms Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital in 1999. Hired seasoned tech exec Eric Schmidt (see) in 2001 to run operations. Took quirky ad-cum-search engine public 2004. Brin serves as president of technology, Page heads product division. Extending ad business into TV, cell phones, various online venues; bought Web video portal YouTube for $1.65 billion in 2006. Switched Mountain View, Calif. headquarters to solar power last summer; part of plan to "do no evil." Hit all-time high of $740 a share in early November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Sergey Brin (see) in computer science Ph.D. program at Stanford. Brin emigrated from Russia, Page grew up in Michigan; both sons of professors. Dropped out of school to start Google in 1998 from friend's garage. Initially financed by Stanford endowment, angel investors K. Ram Shriram, Andy von Bechtolsheim. Raised another $25 million from venture capital firms Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital in 1999. Hired seasoned tech exec Eric Schmidt (see) in 2001 to run operations. Took quirky ad-cum-search engine public 2004. Brin serves as president of technology, Page heads product division. Extending ad business into TV, cell phones, various online venues; bought Web video portal YouTube for $1.65 billion in 2006. Switched Mountain View, Calif. headquarters to solar power last summer; part of plan to do "no evil." Hit all-time high of $740 a share in early November.

name: Billionaires
bio: At end 2007 retired after almost 27 years as CEO of Otto GmbH, the world's largest mail-order company. Now heads the supervisory board. His family owns the $22 billion (sales) group which his father Werner Otto founded in 1949. Family also owns ECE, one of Europe's largest builders and managers of shopping centers; 87% of home furnishings chain Crate & Barrel; plus extensive real estate in U.S. and Canada. Supports foundation that funds preservation of the Elbe River.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has run Swedish retailer Hennes & Mauritz, founded by his father, for 26 years. The $12 (sales) hip clothing chain now has 1,400 stores in 28 countries and has cooperated with big name designers like Karl Lagerfeld, Stella McCartney, Viktor & Rolf, Madonna and Kylie Minogue. Persson is a member of the board of the Mentor Foundation, which fights youth substance abuse and whose trustees include the Queen of Sweden and Queen Noor of Jordan. Enjoys downhill skiing, tennis and golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Most of fortune derives from stake in gas behemoth Gazprom, plus piece of banking giant Sberbank. In autumn 2006 was seriously injured in car accident after losing control of a Ferrari Enzo on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice. Recovery was prolonged and painful. Listed shares of Polymetal, his gold and silver mining company, on the London Stock Exchange in 2007. Still planning construction of massive new housing development outside of Moscow. Re-elected to upper house of Russian parliament in early 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred C. Koch (d. 1967), MIT grad who invented method of refining gasoline from heavy oil. Took refining innovation to Soviet Union 1929; returned home 1930s. Sons Frederick, Charles, David (see) and William (see) inherited Koch Industries after father's death; Charles and David bought out William and Frederick for $1.3 billion in 1983. Long-running fraternal feud over deal settled 2001. Today Charles lords over nation's largest privately held company: chemicals, pipelines, ranching, commodities trading, lumber, paper; also refining operations in Alaska, Texas and Minnesota. Estimated sales: $90 billion. Bought Georgia-Pacific for $21 billion in 2005. Company owns ranch land abutting Yellowstone National Park in Montana and Texas. Charles: cofounder of conservative think tank Cato Institute. Recently published self-help business book The Science of Success; claimed company would go public "over my dead body."

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred C. Koch (d. 1967), MIT grad who invented method of refining gasoline from heavy oil. Took refining innovation to Soviet Union 1929; returned home 1930s. Sons Frederick, Charles (see), David and William (see) inherited Koch Industries after father's death; Charles and David bought out William and Frederick for $1.3 billion in 1983. Long-running fraternal feud over deal settled 2001. Today brother Charles lords over nation's largest privately held company: chemicals, pipelines, ranching, commodities trading, lumber, paper; also refining operations in Alaska, Texas and Minnesota. Estimated sales: $90 billion. Bought Georgia-Pacific for $21 billion in 2005. Company owns ranch land abutting Yellowstone National Park in Montana and Texas. David: ran as vice presidential candidate on the Libertarian Party ticket in 1980.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority shareholder of luxury goods group PPR (formerly Pinault-Printemps-Redoute), whose brands includes Gucci, Balenciaga and Stella McCartney. Also owns more-affordable catalog brands Lerner and Chadwick's. Son Francois-Henri now runs daily operations as chief executive. The second "P" of the group's name, "Printemps", was sold in 2006 to an investment group. Pinault, who also owns auction house Christie's, scrapped plans for a 352,000-square-foot museum in the former Renault factory in western Paris because of supposed red tape. His personal art collection is now showcased in Venice in the Palazzo Grassi. Was awarded the French Legion d'honneur last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soft-spoken Texan reclaimed chief executive spot at Dell Computer in January 2007 for first time since 2004 after numerous setbacks pummeled company's shares. Lost No. 1 spot in PC market to Hewlett-Packard in 2006 as company's long-standing practice of shunning retail outlets and selling desktop PCs directly to customers over the phone or Internet floundered. Hired former Motorola exec Ronald Garriques to lead company's global expansion, cut 10% of company's workforce, struck deals to sell desktop computers in Wal-Mart, Sam's Club stores. Battling HP for China market. Started selling computers from U. of Texas dorm room 1984 with $1,000; dropped out to start Dell. Took public 1988, grew fast with direct-sales model. Most of net worth now outside Dell. Reinvests via private investment vehicle MSD Capital: equities, real estate, private equity. Republican sits on U.S. President's Council of Advisors on Science & Technology. Wife, Susan, created upper-crust (and unaffordable) fashion label Phi.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft cofounder may be one of most hopeful tech investors ever. Spent 8 years at company he started in 1975 with Bill Gates--and 24 years after quitting, it still provides a quarter of his net worth. Lost huge sums on far-off visions, including Interval Research Group (tiny sun-powered, wearable computers; shuttered in 2000). Still has fun: rock 'n' roll museum in Seattle, basketball's Portland Trail Blazers, football's Seattle Seahawks, 413-foot yacht. Went to prestigious Lakeside School with Gates in Seattle. Dropped out of Washington State. Left Microsoft in 1983 to fight Hodgkin's disease. Early backer of DreamWorks SKG, sold big chunk in 2007. Guitar junkie funded 2-year legal battle by Jimi Hendrix kin to recover rights to his music; won. Donates to education, arts, science causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Armenian immigrant fruit farmer dropped out of school in eighth grade. Trained U.S., British fighter pilots during WWII. Flew surplus Air Force planes across Atlantic after war before building charter flights company Trans International Airlines; sold for $104 million profit 1966. Acquired Flamingo Hotel in Las Vegas 1967, built International Hotel 1969. Sold both properties to Hilton Hotels 1970. Went Hollywood: made billions buying and selling movie studio MGM, 3 times since 1969. Back to Vegas: nabbed Steve Wynn's (see) Mirage Resorts for $6.4 billion 2000, then Mandalay Bay Resorts for $7.9 billion 4 years later. Today MGM Mirage owns more than half the hotel rooms on Las Vegas Strip; stock down 35% since high of $100 per share late last year. Thought about buying Bellagio casino, unfinished 76-acre resort complex CityCenter from MGM Mirage last summer; pulled out after company struck deal to partner with Kerzner International to develop 40 acres of land on Strip. In August sold half of CityCenter, chunk of MGM to Middle East investment firm Dubai World for $4.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zealous chief navigates Microsoft's midlife crisis. Google is "it girl" now. Acquired online ad shop Aquantive last May for $6 billion in cash. Windows overhaul, Vista, released to mixed reviews. Then Yahoo: attempted to buy the search engine giant for $45 billion in early February; promptly turned down. Microsoft shares down 15% since making the offer. Detroit native dropped out of Stanford M.B.A. program to join former Harvard classmate Gates (see) in 1980. Pushes patience: "Great things in this business don't happen overnight." Rarely sells shares.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: With family controls Fidelity Investments, America&#39s largest mutual fund company. Assets under management: $1.6 trillion. Father Edward III joined company as an analyst in 1957, president 15 years later. "Abby" studied art history at Hobart & William Smith Colleges; then earned Harvard M.B.A. Joined family business 1988, tracked industrial equipment stocks. Ran her first diversified fund 1993. Father reduced his ownership in 1995; Abby inherited a 24% stake. Became president of company&#39s mutual fund division 2001. Now runs Employer Services division, which administers payroll and employee stock plans. Who owns what? Once clearly defined, Fidelity stakes amongst Johnson family members are now one of the best-kept secrets in capitalism. Company says Abby has sold some of her shares to other family members; family still controls 49% of company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers run $5.8 billion (sales) Essar Group, with interests in construction, shipping, power, oil and gas. Became Vodafone's partner in India last year in $19.9 billion deal. Own 33% of newly named Vodafone Essar; Ravi is chair. Extended steel business into North America with acquisitions of Minnesota Steel and Canada's Algoma Steel. Wedding bash for Ravi's daughter Smiti drew 4,000 guests, including family friend Richard Branson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads $5 billion (sales) M.A. Al-Kharafi & Sons, one of the largest diversified conglomerates in the Arab world. Its lucrative food division, Americana, has exclusive franchise rights in Middle East for brands like Pizza Hut, TGI Fridays, KFC and Wimpy. Also has stake in beleaguered doughnut maker Krispy Kreme. Other investments include telecom, fertilizers and airlines. Older brother Jassem is speaker of Kuwait's National Assembly. Sister Faiza was first woman president of Kuwait University.

name: Billionaires
bio: The sixth Duke of Westminster is the U.K.’s wealthiest landowner. His Grosvenor property group has valuable holdings in the posh Mayfair and Belgravia neighborhoods of London; the group also owns and manages real estate from Tokyo to Los Angeles. Resigned as chair of the firm in January 2007. Owns additional land in London via private family trusts. Head of the British reserve forces and youth policy, he has been busy rallying reservists in Iraq and Afghanistan. Supports more than 150 charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up NYC's Queens. Studied philosophy at Princeton. Went to Wall Street with $4,000 in poker winnings. Gained reputation for buying into troubled companies, forcing management to improve, restructure, buy back stock; scores in 1980s with Texaco, USX. Once considered the world's most dangerous shareholder activist; now having trouble effecting vast management changes. Requested Time Warner buy back stock, split company into 4 individual parts 2005; media firm repurchased $20 billion in shares but never split. Currently agitating Motorola; recently sold off 4 Nevada casinos including the Stratosphere. Sold private hedge fund outfit to American Real Estate Partners last year; now owns 90% stake in the publicly traded holding company. Reason: power. Renamed Icahn Enterprises.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Frank Mars began making chocolates from his kitchen in Tacoma, Wash. 1911. Father, Forrest Sr. (d. 1999), introduced malt-flavored nougat, which became foundation of candy bar line: Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also: M&Ms, Twix, Skittles. Added pet food (Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben's Rice. Today Mars world's largest confectioner. Sales: $21 billion; pet food division now larger than candy by sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Frank Mars began making chocolates from his kitchen in Tacoma, Wash. 1911. Father, Forrest Sr. (d. 1999), introduced malt-flavored nougat, which became foundation of candy bar line: Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also: M&Ms, Twix, Skittles. Added pet food (Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben's Rice. Today Mars world's largest confectioner. Sales: $21 billion; pet food division now larger than candy by sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Frank Mars began making chocolates from his kitchen in Tacoma, Wash. 1911. Father, Forrest Sr. (d. 1999), introduced malt-flavored nougat, which became foundation of candy bar line: Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also: M&Ms, Twix, Skittles. Added pet food (Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben's Rice. Today Mars world's largest confectioner. Sales: $21 billion; pet food division now larger than candy by sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband Gad Rausing died in 2000 leaving her and their three children ownership to packaging giant Tetra Laval, which his father founded in 1944. Company now has $15.4 billion in sales. All three children sit on the company's supervisory board; Jorn is head of its mergers and acquisitions. Otherwise family keeps low profile in part due to kidnapping attempt on Jorn in 1989. What else is known: Birgit lives quietly in Switzerland; Kirsten lives in the U.K. and is a passionate horsewoman; and Finn is chairman of the Swedish R.R. Institute of Applied Economics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Washington U. to serve in Navy; became fighter pilot on U.S.S. Enterprise during WWII. Sold cars after war, became sales manager for St. Louis Cadillac distributor. Backed by boss, took 50% pay cut to start own car-leasing business; offered rentals as temporary replacements for stolen, wrecked cars. Business boomed in 1970s after courts made insurance companies pay for replacement rentals. Today Enterprise Rent-A-Car sales exceed $9 billion. Son, Andrew, began working for dad "as soon as I could drive"; now chairman and chief executive. Daughter, Jo Ann Taylor Kindle, is president of charitable Enterprise Rent-A-Car Foundation. Increasing presence at airports; through holding company, bought Vanguard Auto Group, operator of National and Alamo car rental companies, for an estimated $1.2 billion last summer.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: A native of Kiev, graduated from the Moscow Institute of Steel & Alloys in 1988. The next year, with former classmate (now billionaire) Mikhail Fridman, cofounded Alfa-Eco, a commodities trader and predecessor of Alfa Group. Heads Alfa Group's oil business as executive director and board member of oil company TNK-BP, formed in 2003 with merger of Russian oil and gas assets owned by British oil giant BP and Alfa Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited stake in automaker BMW from late father Herbert Quandt, who rescued it from bankruptcy decades ago. Also inherited 50% stake in pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturer Altana. In September 2006 Altana sold its pharmaceutical division, best known for its blockbuster ulcer drug Pantoprazol which comes off patent in 2009, to Scandinavian firm Nycomed for $6 billion. Susanne pocketed about half of the proceeds. A trained economist with an M.B.A., remains active on Altana's board of supervisors.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Born into large family in the oil city of Baku and attended Azerbaijan's Oil
& Chemistry Institute; in 1972 started as drill operator in the Caspian Sea.
By 1990 was a deputy minister in the Soviet oil industry. In 1991 took three
large ministry-controlled oil fields - Langepas, Urai and Kogalym (LUK)and
set up Lukoil, which was soon privatized in favor of Alekperov-controlled
management. Has good relationship with Vladimir Putin; now heads one of the
few remaining independent oil companies in Russia. Working on expanding
Lukoil's retail gas station network in Europe and on the east coast of the
U.S., where in 2006 he acquired nearly 400 stations from ConocoPhillips.
Also developing Lukoil1s natural gas business in Russia, making deals in
Libya and Iraq.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Hollywood producer attended U. of Washington on skiing scholarship; halted Olympics bid after injury 1956. Built first house with $10,000 loan 1958. Developed 10,000-acre Rancho Mission Viejo in California, sold to Philip Morris 1967. With partners bought real estate developer Irvine Co. for $337 million 1977. Became sole owner 1996. Today portfolio includes 25,000 undeveloped acres in Orange County (13,000 can be developed), 400 office buildings, 40 retail centers, 90 apartment communities, hotels, marinas, golf courses. Gave $20 million to UC, Irvine's law school in August.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers tightly control luxury brand Chanel. Company was cofounded by their grandfather Pierre Wertheimer who eventually bought out his early partner Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel. U.S. resident Alain is chairman of the company, whose Chanel No. 5 perfume is the world's top selling scent. The brothers also own French vineyards like Rauzan-Segla in Margaux and Chateau Canon in Saint-Emilion. Equestrians, own thoroughbreds who have won such races as the French Derby and the Breeders' Cup Turf in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Attended the Perm Medical Institute, studying medicine, but after graduating
in 1990 entered the fertilizer business. In 1994, named chairman of the
board of Uralkali, Russia's largest producer of potassium fertilizers,
founded by the Soviets in 1930. Cancelled a planned 2006 listing of the
company's shares in London, but 2007 brought vindication. The listing, the
first by a Russian chemicals company, raised $1 billion. He owns 66% of the
Uralkali.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father's sudden death Premji, then 21, took over family's cooking fat cooking oil company. Has since transformed Wipro into $3.5 billion (sales) technology services giant. Stock of Wipro, which gets 80% of its sales overseas, hit lately by appreciating rupee. Unfazed, acquired outsourcing firm Infocrossing; bought Southeast Asian personal care products outfit Unza; opened software development center in Mexico and outsourcing center in the Philippines. Son Rishad, Harvard Business School grad, started at Wipro last July, setting off speculation about succession plans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Orascom conglomerate founder Onsi Sawiris. Has continued to expand his telecom empire in Europe via his holding company, Weather Investments. In addition to Orascom Telecom, Weather's assets include Italian phone company Wind and leading Greek telecom companies Wind Hellas and Tellas. Orascom recently sold it's 19% stake in Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Telecommunications; also its high-risk Iraq operation, Iraqna, the first mobile phone provider in Iraq. Swiss-educated, loves to tango.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of James M. Cox (d. 1957), newspaper reporter who bought the Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. High school dropout became 3-term governor of Ohio; Democratic presidential nominee in 1920 with FDR as his running mate. Built media empire. Today Cox Enterprises owns 17 newspapers, 15 TV stations, 80 radio stations, Manheim Auctions (used cars), stake in AutoTrader.com (online classifieds). Sister Barbara Cox Anthony died last year.

name: Billionaires
bio:
One of Russia's most mysterious tycoons. Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, lived
in Tashkent, then graduated from local university with degree in oriental
studies. Put Arabic-language skills to use in various Soviet military
organizations in Libya and Iraq. First moves as a businessman were with
Trans-World Group, once the largest metals-trading operation in Russia. Now
the main owner of UGMK-Holding, Russia's second largest copper producer in
terms of output and the biggest piece of his fortune. With other partners,
acquired stakes in large coal companies and transport-machinery production
outfits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Derives fortune from Bharti Airtel, which he cofounded with two brothers and built into country's largest mobile phone operator; now has 60 million customers. Also has interests in life insurance with Axa; fruits, vegetables with Del Monte Pacific and the Rothschild family. Wholesale cash-and-carry venture with Wal-Mart still to get off the ground. Plans to launch direct-to-home satellite television services. Mittal is currently president of CII, an influential industry lobby.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In 1982 graduated from the Moscow Institute of Physics & Technology; then
worked as the head of a research lab before Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992
established a precursor to EvrazHolding; made a fortune exporting metals and
coal from the Urals and Siberia. After 1998 Russian financial crisis, bought
up steel companies and coal mines on the cheap, purchased a big stake in
Russia's electric monopoly RAO UES. In 2006 Russia's richest man,
billionaire Roman Abramovich, became Abramov's partner in Evraz. In 2007,
made a number of acquisitions, including U.S. firms Claymont Steel Holdings
of Delaware and Oregon Steel Mills.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York mayor, media maven has given away $715 million to charity in the past 5 years. Despite rumored pressure from many advisors, says he won't run for President. Running for mayor is cheaper: despite 67% approval rating, spent $85 million on reelection in 2005; sum was $11 million more than in first election 2001. Boston-born son of accountant studied engineering at Johns Hopkins. Then Harvard M.B.A. Trader at Salomon Brothers 1970s, quit with $10 million in stock after merger. Created firm in 1981 to sell financial data, analytic tools to Wall Street. Renamed Bloomberg LP 1987; added news service to take on Dow Jones and Reuters 3 years later. Then magazine, cable network, radio station. Plans to sell his 68% stake one day (Merrill Lynch, private investors hold 32%), perhaps give away fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Ukraine-born oil and aluminum baron studied at the Moscow State University
of Railroad Engineering in 1970s. Through his management company, Renova,
orchestrated Russia's first successful hostile takeover, of the Vladimir
Tractor Factory, in 1994. Later bought medium-size aluminum smelters and
bauxite mines and united them into Sual Holding, one of the largest aluminum
companies in the world. Made bulk of his fortune when his Sual Holding and
fellow billionaire Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group took over the Tyumen Oil
Company (TNK), which merged with British oil giant BP in 2003. In 2007 the
European Commission approved acquisition of Sual and aluminum trader
Glencore by fellow billionaire Oleg Deripaska's Rusal (Sual retains 22% of
the new company, UC Rusal). In fall 2007, funded the return to Russia of 18
famous church bells that had been hanging at Harvard since their rescue from
the Soviet Union nearly 80 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of Ferrero, one of Europe's largest chocolate makers. Brands include Ferrero Rocher, Nutella, Tic Tac and Kinder Eggs. Tied up in legal battle that pits Ferrero against a Chinese chocolate maker that also makes a gold-wrapped candy. Ferrero nonetheless is determined to expand in Asia, particularly  India, where it plans to begin building a $35 million Tic Tac plant in 2009. Has relinquished day-to-day oversight to sons Pietro and Giovanni, who are co-chiefs. Passions: church and chocolate. Lives in Monte Carlo, Monaco; sons live in Belgium.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family fled Nazi Germany 1938, settled in Oklahoma. Parents developed oil and gas business. Took over 1969; expanded into real estate, banking, derivatives. Today Kaiser-Francis produces 12 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalents annually. Owns 45 million shares of BOK Financial worth $2.3 billion. Also runs liquefied natural gas outfit Excelerate Energy; has invested more than $1 billion in LNG ships and terminals over past few years. Fights childhood poverty through George Kaiser Family Foundation; pledged $60 million to redevelop a blighted community alongside a 42-mile stretch of Arkansas River.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Greece's richest has stakes in financial services, oil refining, real estate, shipping, and high-class travel. His private banking group, EFG International, went on an acquisition spree last year; analysts now expect pace of buyouts and earnings to slow. Single largest shareholder in Hellenic Petroleum. In 2004 started PrivatSea, an exclusive yacht club that promises members an exceptional experience onboard some of the world's most spectacular yachts, including the Alexander, at 400 feet reportedly the world's fourth-largest private yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Orascom conglomerate founder Onsi Sawiris. Took over construction division from his father in 1998. Successfully cracked tough French market in late December when blue chip company Lafarge agreed to buy Orascom Construction's cement division for $13 billion; as part of deal Nassef was granted 11.4% stake and a seat on the board. Has continued father's tradition of pursuing business in high-risk countries: company recently invested $115 million in North Korean cement plant.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Born in Kirov in northern Russia and studied at Moscow Institute of Steel &
Alloys with Mikhail Fridman, now a fellow billionaire. In 1989 was one of
original partners of Fridman's Alfa-Eco group, which later became Alfa
Group. In 1990s headed Alfa-Eco's international sales and in 1992 moved to
Crown Resources, an Alfa subsidiary for international commodities trading.
Alfa has exited that business, but Kuzmichev trades Russian oil on
international commodity exchanges. Main source of wealth is his stake in
Alfa Group; he serves as chairman of Alfa's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shoe baron ran track for U. of Oregon, teamed up with coach to start sneaker company 1964. Gained traction with innovative waffle sole, swoosh logo, superstar endorsements. Partnered with Apple to create Nike iPod Sport Kits; units allow runners to synch sneakers with iPod Nanos to track workout data, exercise to favorite tunes. Signed sponsorship deal with 2008 Beijing Olympics. Gave $105 million to Stanford Business School 2006; largest single donation ever made to a business program.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio:
Began career at Magnitogorsk Iron & Steel mill (MMK) in the 1960s, becoming
general director in 1997. Defended plant from takeover attempt the following
year. Kept his mill, but Magnitogorsk was still on the defensive: The state
and competitors owned 40%, and the mill had problems with iron ore supply.
He solved the problems by buying the shares (with partners)and one of the
biggest iron ore deposits in Russia. Today he owns just under 88% of the
company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took helm of biotech company Serono in 1996; inherited the business after father’s death in 1998. Ran it for a decade and was credited with turning the company into a global leader in pharmaceuticals. Put Serono on the block in 2006, eventually selling to Germany’s Merck, which took it private in an all-cash deal. With his sisters pocketed $9 billion. Avid sailer won the America&#39s Cup for the second time with his Team Alinghi in 2007. Married to British beauty queen .

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited commodities conglomerate Aditya Birla Group from late father 13 years ago. Expanded into financial services, telecom, retail. Last year acquired North American aluminum maker Novelis for over $6 billion and listed telecom arm Idea Cellular; now in court battling former partner Tata Group. Birla bought Mumbai school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sent to an orphanage at age 7. Worked as an apprentice at a factory that made molds for auto parts, eyeglass frames. Founded Luxottica in 1961 and started making his own eyeglasses. Still chairs Luxottica, now reportedly the world&#39s largest manufacturer and retailer of high-quality eyeglasses and sunglasses, with $7.5 billion in sales. Group owns over 6,000 retail stores, including U.S. chains Sunglass Hut and LensCrafters; brands include Ray Ban and, after shelling out $2.1 billion in November 2007, the Oakley line. Holds ten-year eyewear license agreements with Tiffany & Co., Burberry and Polo Ralph Lauren. Has a 203-foot yacht with a pool and dining room that seats 16. Son Claudio owns men’s retailer Brooks Brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs family-owned conglomerate Grupo Votorantim, which is active in steel, finance, cement and pulp and paper. Owns cement plants in the Great Lakes region of the U.S. Net worth soared in 2008 compared with 2007 amid a commodities boom that is benefiting many in Brazil and a stronger Brazilian currency. His three siblings and their heirs also have stakes in Votorantim. The company is actively managed by Antonio and his siblings' children. Antonio writes a weekly column in one of the leading Sao Paulo newspapers, Folha de Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second wife, and now widow, of billionaire Andronico Luksic, who died of cancer in 2005. Family controls Antofagasta, one of world’s largest copper miners. Also holds big position in Quinenco, a consumer packaging and beverage maker.

name: Billionaires
bio: With family, controls Fidelity Investments, America's largest mutual fund company. Assets under management: $1.6 trillion. Father, Edward II, founded Fidelity Management & Research Co. 1946; phenomenal stock picker. "Ned" joined firm as an analyst 1957, president 15 years later. Created mutual funds for almost every investment strategy to increase market share. Renowned for frugality, reduced ownership for estate planning 1995; family owns 49%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold his share in packaging giant Tetra Laval, the company founded by his father, Ruben, in 1944, to brother Gad for an estimated $7 billion in 1995.  Has since invested in Ecolean, a small packaging company that produces environmentally friendly biodegradable packaging materials. Moved to U.K. in early 1980s to avoid punitive Swedish taxes. Now resides on a 900-acre estate in the village of Wadhurst in East Sussex where he collects vintage cars. In 2006 was awarded an honorary knighthood for his services to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former plastics engineer transformed his Moscow municipal Committee for Science & Technology into a commercial enterprise; gained access to lucrative government contracts, real estate and capital. His London-listed empire AFK Sistema (the System) now consists of some 200 companies with holdings ranging from microchips to toy stores. Most valuable is stake in NYSE-listed Mobile Telesystems (MTS), Russia's largest cellular carrier. His daughter, Tatiana, sits on MTS board. Sistema has announced plans to spend billions of dollars on expansion in India.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In 2001 his coal mines and coal trading outfit Yuzhny Kuzbass bought a
controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metallurgical Plant from U.S. billionaire
and commodity trader Marc Rich's Glencore. Out of these assets he created
steel and mining Mechel Group, which went public in 2004 on the NYSE. In
2006 became Mechel's largest investor, buying out shares of partner and
fellow billionaire Vladimir Iorikh.

name: Billionaires
bio: This French senator is chairman of Groupe Dassault, which has interests in software and media. It owns "Le Figaro", the venerable conservative French daily founded in 1826. Group also owns 50% of Dassault Aviation, founded by his father Marcel Dassault, makers of Mirage and Rafale jets. An outspoken right-winger and longtime supporter of Jacques Chirac. His Fondation Serge Dassault supports initiatives in favor of mentally handicapped adults, youth oncology, organ donations, and Christmas presents for hospitalized children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of metals and mining group Industrias Penoles, the leading Latin American producer of refined gold, lead and zinc and reportedly the world's top producer of silver. Stock more than doubled in the past year, dramatically boosting Bailleres' net worth. Also has interests in upscale department store El Palacio de Hierro and insurance company Grupo Nacional Provincial S.A.

name: Billionaires
bio: Structural engineer moved into real estate in 1985 to build middle-class homes. His publicly traded Unitech, run by his two sons, is building a 350-acre community of luxury homes in Delhi suburb with Greg Norman signature golf course. Partnering with Marriot Hospitality on a chain of hotels and with Indonesia's Salim group for townships in eastern India. Recently got prized national license to launch mobile phone services.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Frito-Lay analyst switched to selling satellite dishes 1980, later expanded into broadcasting. Founder of direct-satellite service EchoStar. Gaining on DirecTV. Partnering with Google to better focus ads: E-Trade targets stock traders by demographics and region; company pays only when a viewer watches a spot. Spun-off set top boxes and several wholesale divisions as EchoStar Communications in January, renamed pay-TV company DISH Network. Appointed DISH President in February.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad left father's buyout business in his 30s; bought $1.9 million stake in jewelry distributor Cohen-Hatfield 1978. Sold jewelry operation to Sam Walton 7 years later. Purchased licorice maker MacAndrews & Forbes, used as a holding company for buyouts. Bought cosmetics company Revlon 1985; stake once worth billions is valued at less than $325 million today. Sold Golden State Bancorp with Gerald Ford (see) to Citigroup in 2002 for $6 billion. Sold camping gear outfit Coleman to Sunbeam 1998; took Morgan Stanley to court 7 years later after learning the investment bank had not informed him that Sunbeam's financial statements were cooked. Won jury trial; appeals court overturned the ruling last year. Betting on biotech: Siga Technologies looking for ways to battle bioterrorism; TransTech Pharma trying to cure Alzheimer's. Owns 75 acres of prime East Hampton, N.Y. real estate. Recently donated $50 million to enhance heart care and reproductive medicine research at New York-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sometimes down, but never out, three-time Italian prime minister may well have another shot at the top job in 2008; Romano Prodi, who bested Berlusconi in spring 2006, stepped down after losing a confidence vote in January 2008. Berlusconi's people say polls give him a "confident lead" for a third term in office. Started out singing on cruise ships. Eventually built fortune through Fininvest, which now has interests in media, life insurance, movie production and soccer team A.C. Milan. Always seems to skirt trouble: 2007 saw the dismissal of decade-old corruption charges; last year wife, Veronica, sent an open letter to press demanding an apology for her husband's public flirting. He then published his own letter begging her for forgiveness.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout, spurned father's textile trading business; imported scarce plastic polymers, then moved into commodity exports. Listed Adani in 1994. Diversified into infrastructure 1998, building Mundra Port, one of first private-sector ports, on western coast; listed it last November. Yoga fanatic.

name: Billionaires
bio: When the Czech government began privatizing nationalized companies in 1992, used a $1 million loan he got through his small office-supplies business to start an investment fund; later used this fund to buy a controlling stake in Ceska pojistovna, the largest Czech insurer. Last year the company entered a joint venture with Italy's Generali; owns 49% of the new entity Generali PPF Holding. In 2005 sold his stake in Czech Nova TV to American billionaire Ronald Lauder for a $580 million net profit; put majority of proceeds into private equity group PPF Investments. PPF Investments now suing the majority shareholder of insurance company Ingosstrach, Russia's richest person, Oleg Deripaska, for diluting the 38% stake it purchased from billionaire Alexander Mamut. Deripaska has filed a lawsuit against the original transaction between PPF Investments and Mamut.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The co-owner of several steel and iron-ore factories has been expanding into
telecom and media, buying Kommersant newspaper from billionaire and former
oligarch Boris Berezovsky. Apparently close to Kremlin officials, in 2007
bought stake in Telecominvest, a diversified holding company that had been
the subject of controversy, due to lawsuits alleging it was owned by a
government minister. Also bought a TV channel. Significantly for British
soccer fans, purchased a 23% stake in Arsenal, a professional soccer club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold his insurance company Allianz and his private bank Merck, Finck to Barclay's Bank in 1990. Invested proceeds in real estate, restaurants, hotels, breweries, a chemical manufacturer, an insurance group and a champagne maker. Manages it all from his tax-free hideaway in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founding patriarch of Orascom, one of Egypt's largest conglomerates. Was forced to rebuild his construction company from scratch after it was nationalized by the government in the 1960s. Now serves as chairman of Orascom Construction. His three sons run construction, telecommunications and tourism divisions. On his sons' independent business interests, Sawiris has told press "[they] do not believe that obeying their parents is a sacred duty." Through his foundation, sponsors university scholarships for Egyptian students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Ethiopia and now a Saudi citizen, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before betting on energy. Owns Swedish refinery Preem as well as Svenska Petroleum, which made big plays in Guinea-Bissau, Nigeria and Angola this year. Has invested more than $1 billion in Ethiopia, from hotels to gold mines. Last fall celebrated the year 2000 in the Ethiopian Orthodox calendar with international artists performing in his new 20,000 seat concert hall in Addis Ababa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime rice and sugar trader heads multinational Kuok Group with interests ranging from shipping to real estate to media. Has offered to privatize the SCMP Group, which publishes the South China Morning Post. Merged extensive Malaysian, Indonesian palm oil interests with Singapore's Wilmar International, run by his nephew. Also has stake in Transmile Group, air cargo outfit that has admitted to overstating revenues from 2004 to 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Budapest, family survived Nazi occupation of Hungary. London School of Economics; founded famed Quantum Fund with "Adventure Capitalist" Jim Rogers 1969. With Stanley Druckenmiller (see), "broke" British pound in 1992, made $1 billion profit. Lost hundreds of millions with ill-timed investments in former Soviet Union 1996. Locked out new investors 2000; much of Quantum Endowment Fund's assets are his. Handed off day-to-day operations to sons Robert and Jonathan; Robert recently stepped down as chief investment officer. Dedicated philanthropist has given away $5 billion since 1979 via his Open Society Institute and other charitable groups; strives to promote democracy throughout the globe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Mashreq, a leading United Arab Emirates commercial bank founded by his father during the Gulf's first oil boom in 1960s. Bank celebrated its 40th anniversary last year with multimillion-dollar rebranding campaign; recently announced plans to expand into Egypt. Family's diverse business interests also include investments in cement, petrochemicals, insurance and Masafi, the region's leading mineral-water brand. Foods division operates one of the largest flour mills in the Middle East. Paragliding enthusiast also serves as chairman of Arab Business Angels Network, a nonprofit that funds startups by young Arab entrepreneurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: The more public of two billionaire brothers. In mid-2006 Joseph bought, for an undisclosed sum, his brother (and fellow billionaire) Moise's 50% share of their financial empire, including Banco Safra, Brazil's tenth-largest bank, Safra National Bank of New York and Banque Safra-Luxembourg. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother, Edmond Safra, had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife, Lily, also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner John Sall as a graduate student at North Carolina State. Cofounded SAS Institute 1976, now believed to be largest privately held software maker in the world; massive databases, customer analysis, business intelligence. 2007 sales: $2.2 billion. Goodnight owns two-thirds, Sall the rest. At work employees get free candy, on-site health care and day care, and scholarships for their kids to attend affiliated Cary Academy. Goodnight: claims U.S. should open borders to skilled overseas IT workers. "Why restrict the best and the brightest people from coming into your country?" Founded Cary Academy 1996; school emphasizes technology.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samuel Newhouse Sr., first-generation American who parlayed tiny Bayonne Times into nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. With brother Donald Newhouse (see) took over after father's death in 1979; expanded, diversified. Today own, operate Bright House Cable; also pieces of the Discovery Channel, Learning Channel. Donald oversees weakening newspaper division (Cleveland Plain Dealer, Newark Star-Ledger). "Si" heads magazines via Conde Nast (New Yorker, Vanity Fair, Vogue). Stumbling online: nearly all Conde Nast Web sites used mainly to sell subscriptions, deliver magazine content. Launched business magazine Conde Nast Portfolio last April. Valuation revised this year to include stunning art collection (Johannes Lingelbach, Rubens).

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samuel Newhouse Sr., first-generation American who parlayed tiny Bayonne Times into nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. With brother Donald Newhouse (see) took over after father's death in 1979; expanded, diversified. Today own, operate Bright House Cable; also pieces of the Discovery Channel, Learning Channel. Donald oversees weakening newspaper division (Cleveland Plain Dealer, Newark Star-Ledger). "Si" heads magazines via Conde Nast (New Yorker, Vanity Fair, Vogue). Stumbling online: nearly all Conde Nast Web sites used mainly to sell subscriptions, deliver magazine content. Launched business magazine Conde Nast Portfolio last April. Valuation revised this year to include stunning art collection (Johannes Lingelbach, Rubens).

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother and son jointly own one of the world's largest producers of roller bearings, $13 billion (revenues) INA Waelzlager Schaeffler KG. Maria-Elizabeth runs the company. Well-known in Bavaria where she lives; has been awarded the Bavarian Order of Merit, for her commitment to social issues, and the German Cross of Merit, for her entrepreneurial achievements. Opera fan rumored to have named her two dogs Fidelio and Tosca. Son Georg practices international business law at Haynes & Boone in Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Al Rajhi Bank, Saudi Arabia’s largest Islamic bank. Owns the largest cut of the bank&#39s shares; three of his brothers also have significant stakes. Has a range of side business interests from cement production to organic agriculture. Owns one of the largest poultry processing plants in Middle East. Wrote a letter to the Wall Street Journal denouncing its July 2007 article discussing the bank&#39s alleged role in financing Islamic extremism. The family also posted an open letter on bank&#39s Web site, calling the story "false and abhorrent," stating that the bank and family "unequivocally" condemn terrorism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Knighted in 2006 for his services to the retail industry, Sir Philip heads two of the U.K.'s top retailers, British Home Stores and Arcadia. Plans to export his cheap-chic clothier Top Shop to the U.S. in September 2008. The London resident, who is known for circulating with celebrities, also spends time at his home in tax haven Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Australia-born, U.S.-naturalized tabloid titan pays too much, then makes it work. 
In August his 20-year crush culminates in deal to buy Wall Street Journal, parent Dow Jones. Price tag: $5 billion (over 90% cash) plus $600 million in assumed debt. Bancroft family (and Dow Jones execs) succumbed after flirting with 21 other possible suitors; there were no takers. Reason: Murdoch's 60% premium. Doubters said he overpaid for MySpace, too ($630 million in 2005); a year later Google agreed to pay $900 million for 3 years of access to MySpace, other Weblets. Oxford grad, started with one paper, inherited at age 23. WSJ adds class to News mass: New York Post, Fox film, broadcast and cable channels. New rival to business network debuted last October. Last year gave $600 million in stock to his 6 kids. Reason: estate planning. Succession is still unsettled. Son James runs BSkyB in U.K.; son Lachlan, who quit in 2005 and stayed onboard, could yet return.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dot-com pioneer defies gravity, survives tech crash. Took company public in 1997 and expanded from bookselling into thousands of products online. Decade later books still big piece of virtual mall's $14.8 billion sales. Computer whiz worked at hedge funds after graduating from Princeton in 1989; quit before 30th birthday to sell books online from Seattle garage. Space cadet building base and testing center on 300,000 acres of Texas land for his Blue Origin commercial space-travel venture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairperson of O.P. Jindal Group since husband, Om Prakash, its founder, died in 2005 helicopter crash. Her four sons, Prithviraj, Sajjan, Ratan and Naveen, run the $8 billion (sales) steel, power empire; Sajjan, the most ambitious, says he plans to invest $15 billion in aluminum, cement and infrastructure over next three years. Youngest, Naveen, who last July inked $2.1 billion deal to mine iron ore in Bolivia, is a member of parliament.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Len" immigrated to U.S. from former Soviet Union 1978 at age 21; arrived penniless. Found way to Harvard Business School. Started industrial holding company Access Industries 1986. Partnered with school friend, now billionaire, Victor Vekselberg, and later Mikhail Fridman. Acquired stakes in newly privatized Russian companies. Trio made first fortune merging Tyumen Oil Company and British Petroleum; firm became Russia's 2nd-largest oil company. Reinvested in chemicals, metals. Serves on board of Warner Music. Said to have paid $27 million for an apartment on Fifth Avenue in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: World’s leading oil tanker tycoon through control of Frontline Ltd. Made early fortune moving crude through the Persian Gulf during Iran-Iraq war. Now consolidating deepwater oil rig business through Seadrill. Ocean Harvest a leading fish farmer. Big investment in 2007 in German shipper Tui; Fredriksen would like to hive off its Hapag-Lloyd container shipping biz. Born in Norway but renounced citizenship in favor of tax-friendly Cyprus. Runs empire from grand home in London’s Chelsea district; in 2006 fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich offered him $200 million for the manse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifteen years ago was a down-and-out air force lieutenant colonel and a veteran of the Afghan war. Was helped along the way by good connections: While working at a brokerage firm  met Leonid Fedun, also a former military officer, who was a privatization consultant for Lukoil. After setting up Nikoil (later Uralsib) in partnership with other top Lukoil managers such as Vagit Alekperov, Tsvetkov helped them gain a controlling stake in the oil company; for his services was rewarded with a sizable Lukoil stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timber giant Empresas CMPC made $1.6 billion in capital investments from 2004 to 2006. Now reaping the benefits of growing world pulp demand. His conglomerate holds millions of acres of pine and eucalyptus in Chile and Argentina. University of Chicago-educated Matte also betting on Chile increasing its share of international trade, by expanding his huge port complex in Lirquen, Chile. Owns stakes in telecom and banking outfits, too.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns the Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest food retailers, plus a 53% stake in U.S. grocery chain A&P. Now retired, turned over reins to sons Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian. Also owns extensive land in Washington State, buffalo ranch in Wyoming and ski resort Sun Mountain Lodge in the Cascades. Local celebrity in Tacoma, Wash., thanks to his contribution to the town's revitalization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads conglomerate New World Development, with interests in property, infrastructure and telecom. Transformed tech affiliate New World Cyberbase into hot mining stock, Mongolia Energy. His private Chow Tai Fook Nominee invested in more than 15 recent listings. Also has a stake in billionaire Stanley Ho’s Macau casino group. Upped number of family’s bodyguards after headquarters, one of its hotels and 16 of its telecom shops were ransacked.

name: Billionaires
bio: French-born computer programmer launched online auction Ebay in 1995. Today more than one million people use it as primary or secondary source of income. Handed exec control to Meg Whitman (see) in 1998, remains chairman. Active blogger philanthropic via Omidyar Network; finances small businesses in developing economies, donates to nonprofits. Gave $100 million to alma mater Tufts in 2005.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Cathay Financial Holdings, which was founded as a life insurance group by his later father Tsai Wan-lin. Has been expanding the financial conglomerate further into banking and securities and real estate. Shares fortune with his three brothers:  Tsai Cheng-yu, who runs Cathay's commercial banking unit; Eric Tsai (also known as Tsai Cheng Chiu), who is responsible for nonlife insurance; and Tsai Cheng-ta, who is not actively involved in the business? operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over tiny screw business from his father at age 19. Today Wurth Group has $12.5 billion in sales. Company also has interests in a bank and solar energy company. Daughter Bettina succeeded him as head of the supervisory board last year; son-in-law Markus runs group's wood division. Wurth has professional pilot's license; rides a Harley-Davidson; vast art collection, which includes works by Emil Nolde, Ernst, Leger, Alfred Hrdilicka, Edvard Munch and Pablo Picasso. Received an honorary doctorate in art history and museography from the University of Palermo in May 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Mori Trust is a big landlord in Tokyo and elsewhere in Japan, with properties including hotels, apartment complexes, office buildings and resorts in the countryfs mountains. Will soon open a new marquee tower near Tokyo Station, to include a posh Shangri-La Hotel. Hobbies: golf, Japanese chess, and reading.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy investor hoping to bank it like Beckham; last year signed international phenom David Beckham to 5-year, $250 million deal to play for his L.A. Galaxy pro soccer squad. Owns stakes in pro basketball's L.A. Lakers, hockey's L.A. Kings. Also arenas: Staples Center in L.A., the O2 (formerly Millennium Dome) in London. Son of oil driller bought out dad 1961, struck big in Utah and Wyoming. Moved to railroads (Union Pacific), fiber optics (Qwest), movie theaters (Regal Cinemas), ranches. Sold billions worth of Qwest shares in forward sales in recent years. Donated $100 million to U. of Colorado's medical campus, pledged $500 million in Qwest shares to Anschutz Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daddy's girl received 58% stake in real estate developer Country Garden from its main founder, her father, Yeung Kwok Keung. She's now China's richest woman. Not much else known about her other than the fact she is an Ohio State grad and her wedding video is posted on YouTube.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a coal miner, built his Ukrainian coal-and-steel empire in the mid-1990s by forging ties with then prime minister Viktor Yanukovych. After his ally lost 2004 presidential election, had his key asset, Ukraine's largest steel company, Kryvorizhstal, reprivatized. Things were looking up when his Party of Regions briefly was back in the majority for part of 2006 and 2007; but that changed this fall when the opposition, led by Yulia Tymoshenko, won elections and almost immediately began reviewing his energy holdings. Continues to reorganize assets for potential public offering. In December his metal-and-mining holding company Metinvest finalized plans to merge assets with SMART holding company; Akhmetov will retain a 75% stake in Metinvest. Pledged $50 million to Ukraine's Foundation for Effective Governance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited 25% stake in Dutch brewer Heineken 6 years ago from her late father, Freddy Heineken. Heineken is one of the world's great brewers with more than 170 premium brands in over 65 countries. Mother of 5 enjoys photography, music and architecture. She is also a member of St. Moritz's elite Corviglia Ski Club. Her husband, investment banker Michel de Carvalho, sits on Heineken's supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Grupo Mexico, the mining company that his late father founded. Company has thrived as a result of soaring copper prices. Also mines silver and zinc and, through a subsidiary, has a transportation business that includes Mexico's largest railroad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built barns to pay U. of Wisconsin tuition. Founded hardware store chain Menard's 1972; expanded, undercut competition pennies at a time. Now third-largest home improvement firm in U.S. behind Home Depot, Lowe's. Stores in 11 midwestern states. Sports car junkie funds Team Menard at Indy 500 each year; sponsors Nascar's Dale Earnhardt Jr.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In June 2007 he took his telecom company, Maxis, private in a $5 billion deal. Planning to list his shipping company, Bumi Armada, on Bursa Malaysia.
