Capped off already busy year: His satellite TV provider Astro launched a joint venture with India's Sun TV Group. Also signed joint venture with A&E Television Network.

name: Billionaires
bio: King of cork. Turned small cork factory his grandfather started in 1870 into the world's largest producer of cork, $650 million (sales) Corticeira Amorim, which today also has real estate and tourism interests. No longer involved day to day but still owns 50% of the group. Has invested heavily in finance and energy. Inside his portfolio: 8% of Banco Popular; 27.5% of investment company Finpro; 18% of Galp, the former state energy company in Portugal; and 25% of bank BIC Angola. Also investing in land in northern Brazil planned for tourism development.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1982 succeeded her father as head of the Axel Johnson Group, a diversified trading company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873. The privately held $12 billion (sales) group has interests in everything from energy to telecom to real estate. Axfood AB, in which it holds a 45% share, is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia. Attended Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass. as an exchange student in the early 1960s. Holds a master's degree in psychology and business from the University of Stockholm, a doctor of civil law degree from Bishop's University in Canada and a doctor of humane letters degree from Middlebury College of Vermont. Avid horsewoman and a member of numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the Swedish queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and president of George Weston Ltd., founded by his grandfather George 1882 and now one of North America’s largest bakers. Also owns controlling stake in Canada’s largest supermarket chain, Loblaw, at which his son Galen is executive chairman. Has other investments in privately held high-end retailers like Canada’s Holt Renfrew, Ireland’s Brown Thomas and London’s department store Selfridges, which he purchased in 2003 for $958 million through his Wittington Investments. Daughter Alannah is Selfridges&#39 creative director. Wife, Hilary, is Ontario’s former lieutenant governor. Avid collector of avant-garde artist Christo, Weston regularly hosts exhibits of influential artists at Windsor, the private residential community he founded in Vero Beach, Fla. Plays polo with Prince Charles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Texas teachers graduated from U. of Texas 1952. Got taste for takeover tactics as a bank examiner. Bought Dallas drugstore in 1961 for $5,000 cash plus $95,000 loan; sold 100-store chain to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million 1973. Built publicly traded holding company Valhi with hostile takeovers. Now invested in titanium (Timet, Kronos), waste management (Waste Control Specialists), computer components (CompX International). Donated $175 million to build cancer center at alma mater.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad traded options at Gruntal & Co. 1978; netted $8,000 on first day. Founded hedge fund SAC Capital 1992 with $25 million in assets. Today manages $14 billion across 9 funds. High fees, higher returns: charges 3% of assets, 35% of profits on most funds; has returned an average of 34% net of fees each year since 1992. Has spent an estimated $600 million on works by Warhol, Picasso, Pollock for large art collection. Also owns Damien Hirst's "The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living," featuring a shark carcass suspended in formaldehyde.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 17% stake in automaker BMW, which his late father, Herbert Quandt, rescued from bankruptcy almost five decades ago. Trained engineer, owns and manages Delton AG, a $3.8 billion (sales) holding company whose subsidiaries include a maker of homeopathic drugs and a supplier of electricity. Also owns stakes in publicly traded power equipment manufacturer CEAG and logistics company and smart card maker Data Card Corp. Once considered one of the world's most eligible bachelors, Quandt is now married.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boston-born tycoon had year of living irritably: publicly dumped Tom Cruise, longtime lieutenant Tom Freston in 2006. Last July bought out son Brent's Viacom stake for $240 billion after a falling-out. Now clashes with daughter Shari, 53; says to succeed him she must "change her behavior" to win over board. Meaning: be less confrontational than Dad. Reality: pros, not kin, will succeed him--if he ever dies. Harvard Law 1947; joined father's theater business, now National Amusements, 1954. Expanded into TV, movies with Viacom. To boost value, split company into 2 year-end 2005: Viacom (Paramount Pictures, MTV Networks), CBS (CBS, CW, CBS Radio). Bought DreamWorks live-action studio for $1.5 billion from founders David Geffen (see), Steven Spielberg (see), Jeffrey Katzenberg in 2006.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: The brothers' secretive and sprawling empire, founded in 1881 by their grandfather J.D. Irving, dominates the economy of  the Maritime Provinces including New Brunswick. Speculation continued that the company could be broken up. Its Irving Oil, which owns Canada's largest refinery, is benefiting from the global boom in fuel prices. With Spain's Repsol, developing a liquid natural gas terminal with 1-billion-cubic-feet daily capacity in St. John, N.B. Irving trio also controls 600 gas stations, 3.6 million acres of timberland in Canada and Maine, and 4 daily newspapers. New Brunswick's first non-Irving owned newspaper in years was published in 2007 by ex-Irving employee, ending media monopoly in province, despite injunction filed by Irvings that was eventually lifted.

name: Billionaires
bio: The famously press-shy, Monaco-based, Romanian-born Israeli and his family control a vast global shipping empire, plus interests in banking and real estate. The family controls Israel Chemicals, Zim (shipping) and refineries through his umbrella holding company, Israel Corp., which has seen its stock price double in the past year. The family also has a stake in Royal Caribbean, the world’s second-largest cruise line. Sons Eyal and Idan have taken more visible roles in the Ofer businesses. New York City resident Eyal handles real estate, most recently buying Manhattan’s Altria building for $525 million; Idan, who resides in Tel Aviv, is chairman of Israel Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began as a gold miner, then moved into running an iron ore mining company. This college dropout now cutting multibillion dollar deals with Anglo American, which has agreed to pay $5.5 billion for a chunk of Batista's majority-owned, publicly traded MMX mining outfit. Also branching into oil and gas exploration; logistics business, to get iron ore from mines to ports; and energy generation, building coal-fired plants in Brazil. Has attracted talented executives by promising them equity in his companies,and keeps minority shareholders happy by giving execs some of his own equity. One-time champion offshore powerboat racer; formerly married to Playboy cover girl. His father was former mining minister of Brazil and revered executive at Brazilian mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of BASF founder Friedrich Engelhorn, he studied chemical engineering in Texas after World War II. In May 1997 engineered sale of pharmaceutical companies Boehringer Mannheim and DePuy to Roche for $11 billion. Personal take was $4.4 billion. Engelhorn, whose mother was American, funded the new Heidelberg Center for American Studies at the University of Heidelberg. Retired, lives in Switzerland with fourth wife, Heidemarie.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grown-up at Google spent past few years buying into Web videos (YouTube), blog-hosting (blogger.com), presentation software (Tonic Systems, Zenter). Ads remain the driver of the high-profit search engine, posting 99% of sales. Earned electrical engineering degree from Princeton and Ph.D. from UC, Berkeley. Joined Bell Labs, then Xerox. Developed Java technology at Sun Microsystems 1980s. Recruited in 2001 by Larry Page and Sergey Brin (see both) to become chief executive.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Lithuanian immigrants born in the Bronx, raised in Detroit. Bought first patch of real estate at age 20. Cofounded Kaufman & Broad with $25,000 borrowed from his in-laws; became one of nation's largest affordable home builders, focusing on homes for parents of baby boomers. Acquired Sun Life Insurance (later renamed SunAmerica) in 1971. Sold to AIG in 1998 for $18 billion. With Ronald Burkle (see), made failed bid for newspaper company Tribune. Remains interested in buying L.A. Times. Owns art collection worth $1 billion. Favorite piece: Jeff Koons' "Balloon Dog." Philanthropy focused on education reform, scientific and medical research. "American economic security is at risk without better public education."

name: Billionaires
bio:
The mining magnate nicknamed Twiggy became Australia's richest man for the
first time this year. Shares of his publicly traded Fortescue Metals Group,
which he founded in 2003, soared in the past year, thanks to Chinese demand
for steel and to red-hot speculative interest in iron ore mining companies
in general. Curiously, the western Australian company, which he still heads,
has yet to mine anything, though it will start shipping ore this year.
Forrest is a descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia,
Lord Forrest of Bunbury. He founded his first mining company Anaconda Nickel(now called Minara) in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of Danish toymaker Lego. Ran the company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains its sole owner and vice chairman of the board. Thanks to restructuring and the sale of assets like its four Legoland amusement parks, the world's sixth-largest toymaker by sales ($1.5 billion) is finally making a profit again.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Peter Peterson and Hamilton James, took their investment house Blackstone public last June. Perhaps facing the end of the golden age of private equity. Schwarzman was worth nearly $10 billion immediately following offering; shares down 50% since. Company sold just under 10% stake to Chinese government weeks before the offering. Wall Street giant manages nearly $100 billion across private equity, real estate, corporate debt, hedge fund operations. Schwarzman and Peterson cofounded Blackstone Group 1985 with $400,000. Net profits in 2006: $2.3 billion. Paid $39 billion for Sam Zell's (see) Equity Office Properties last February, then agreed to buy Hilton Hotels for $26 billion last July. Schwarzman attended Yale with President George W. Bush. Harvard M.B.A. Managing director at Lehman Brothers 1978 at age 31. Threw himself a lavish 60th birthday party at New York's Park Avenue Armory February 2007.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Blackstone Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
Former military man turned financial whiz. In 1990s helped privatize Lukoil,
which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties; now he is
billionaire's Lukoil Chief Vagit Alekperov's right-hand man. As vice
president, responsible for strategic development and external relations. "My
wealth is a virtual thing; 99% of my money consists of Lukoil shares," Fedun
has said. An avid soccer fan: When Russia qualified for the 2008 European
championship in late 2007 Fedun, who owns Spartak of Moscow, offered four
new Mercedes sedans to players on the Croatian team which had beaten the
Brits, giving Russia a spot. The Croats, while flattered, reportedly
declined the gift.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner (and now billionaire)
Vitaly Malkin, set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. Ivanishvili owns two-thirds of
the bank's shares and Malkin the remainder. The two share other assets with
the same stockholding ratio, but Ivanishvili now focuses on managing his
personal portfolio of Russian securities. Also owns interests in hotels, a
Russian chain of pharmacies, and is planning an deluxe housing development
outside Moscow. Has been the subject of some interest in the art world
following his reported auction purchases, for far above their estimated
prices, of works by Picasso and the contemporary artist Peter Doig.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of August Kuhne, a founder of transport and logistics group Kuhne & Nagel. Holds 56% of the publicly traded group, which he has run for four decades. Hamburg-born Kuhne must really miss the sea: although he lives in landlocked Switzerland, has built an extravagant house said to look like the main command deck of an ocean liner.

name: Billionaires
bio:
A native of Yekaterinburg, studied to become an electrical engineer but left
to go into business. Through the 1990s made his way through the murky world
of metals and oil trading in the Urals and Siberia, selling pipes and copper
cable. As a client of MDM Bank, got to know the bank's young owner, Andrei
Melnichenko, now a billionaire. After collapse of the ruble in 1998
persuaded Melnichenko to buy Russian steel mills, chemical companies and
coal mines on the cheap. The partners established three industrial giants:
TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest
mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal
producer. In October 2006 TMK head and fellow billionaire Dmitry Pumpyansky
bought them out, and in December Melnichenko and Popov began dividing up the
rest of the business. Melnichenko unloaded his stake in MDM and acquired
Popov's stake in Eurochem. They continue to jointly control SUEK, which in
2007 formed a joint venture with Gazprom to buy up power-generation plants
being auctioned off by the country's energy monopoly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down from corporate leadership in 2005 but still a big shareholder in Nintendo. The gaming company, which he inherited, revamped and chaired for 55 years, hit it big in the last two years with the Wii video-game console and DS portable gaming device, both worldwide sellouts. That’s done wonders for the company’s revenue, expected to jump by 60% this year. Those record-high numbers should help boost profits by 40% in the year that ends in March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Barbara Cox Anthony, who died last May. Anthony: daughter of James M. Cox (d. 1957), newspaper reporter who bought the Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. High school dropout became 3-term governor of Ohio; Democratic presidential nominee in 1920 with FDR as his running mate. Built media empire. Today Cox Enterprises owns 17 newspapers, 15 TV stations, 80 radio stations, Manheim Auctions (used cars), stake in AutoTrader.com (online classifieds). James: Cox chief since 1988.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first department store in 1948; sold his Massa chain in 1985 but smartly held on to the underlying Real estate, which he now rents to retailer Metro. Kipp also owns real estate in the U.S., notably several high-end properties in New York City. His true love these days appears to be his Swiss luxury hotels and resorts including the Hotel Eden Roc in Ascona, the 105-room Carlton Hotel in St. Moritz and the Tschuggen Grand Hotel (where he lives).

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Barbara Cox Anthony, who died last May. Anthony: daughter of James M. Cox (d. 1957), newspaper reporter who bought the Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. High school dropout became 3-term governor of Ohio; Democratic presidential nominee in 1920 with FDR as his running mate. Built media empire. Today Cox Enterprises owns 17 newspapers, 15 TV stations, 80 radio stations, Manheim Auctions (used cars), stake in AutoTrader.com (online classifieds). Blair: lives in Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his family's discount retailer, Grupo Elektra, in 1987. Seven years later launched television network TV Azteca, now the nation's number two network. Later launched a low-cost mobile carrier, Unefon, in part to undercut Carlos Slim Helu's America Movil. Today he is pushing into banking; his Elektra chain was the first retailer to enter the business when it opened Banco Azteca in 2002, and today has more than 7 million low-income clients. Recently started selling Chinese cars in Mexico through Elektra.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Son of a respected Soviet physicist. With some former schoolmates sold
computers and established a chain of currency-exchange booths; in 1993
founded MDM Bank, which handled the accounts of oil tycoon (and now
billionaire) Roman Abramovich and others. In 1998 teamed up with metals
trader, and now billionaire, Sergei Popov; two years later they began
accumulating an industrial empire. In October 2006 sold their stake in pipe
producer TMK to fellow billionaire Dmitry Pumpyansky and months later began
dividing up their other businesses. Melnichenko sold Popov his stake in MDM
and acquired Popov's holding in Eurochem, the largest producer of mineral
fertilizers in Russia. They continue to jointly control SUEK, one of
Russia's biggest coal producers, which in 2007 formed a joint venture with
Gazprom to buy up power-generation plants being auctioned off by the
country's energy monopoly. In a stab at foreign expansion, bought a stake in
leading German fertilizer firm K+S Group, which has operations in Chile and
France.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate lawyer joined father's Tana Oil & Gas 1980; merged production properties with Texaco (now Chevron) for stock and cash 1989. Rebuilt Tana, sold to Unocal 1999. Last year exchanged $400 million worth of shares back to Chevron for cash plus oil and gas prospects to be developed. Well diversified: largest piece of fortune in Omni Hotels. Also owns Gold's Gym, Mexican retail chain Waldo's; stock in PG&E, Pogo Producing, Bank of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's most eligible bachelor is living up to his new persona.  Gou made his fortune working nonstop to build Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract manufacturer but now he is a frequent subject of society and gossip pages, with tales of trysts and racy entertainment at company dinners. Rumours of the future Mrs. Gou have been flying since he told the local press that he is in the market for a long-term partner.  Plans to give most of his fortune away, beginning with a reported $500 million for a cancer research facility in Taiwan.  His brother died from leukemia in July and his wife died from breast cancer two years ago.  Placed another 100 million of his Hon Hai Precision shares in trust for his employees late last year.  He was worth a lot more before shares in all his listed companies ? Hon Hai Precision Industry, Foxconn and Innolux ? took a tumble on increasing labor costs in China and worries about a slowdown in demand for the i-Pods, cellphones, game systems and other devices they assemble.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her three children and her brother-in-law Eliezer (also a billionaire), this widow controls one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN), though isn't involved in running the business. In 1993 son Benjamin used money from the family's textile business to purchase stake in steel company. He now serves as CSN's chairman and chief executive. In early 2007 CSN lost a bid to acquire Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus Group to India's Tata Steel. No matter: Shares nearly doubled in price in 2007 amid booming demand for steel. The family also owns Banco Fibra, which has $5.7 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Metals, mining magnate chairs London-listed Vedanta Resources. Outbid Lakshmi Mittal and Kumar Birla to clinch majority stake in Indian iron ore miner Sesa Goa from Japan's Mitsui for more than $1 billion. Raised $2 billion last year via listing of copper, zinc, aluminum producer Sterlite Industries on NYSE Euronext. Building Vedanta University, to which he has pledged $1 billion, in eastern India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood's richest man is cashing in on the soaring art market. Sold classic drip painting by Jackson Pollock for $140 million in 2006, believed to be the largest sum ever paid for single piece. Also unloaded a Jasper Johns, Willem de Kooning. U. of Texas dropout sorted mail at famed William Morris Agency. Founded Asylum Records 1970, then Geffen Records. Started DreamWorks with partners Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg in 1995. Holiday hit last year with Dreamgirls; says he is done with movies. Bid against billionaires Eli Broad, Ronald Burkle for Tribune-owned Los Angeles Times; all lost out to Sam Zell last April. Democratic fundraiser ditched the Clintons for Obama.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Like many tycoons from Russia's resource-rich Ural mountain region, started
out as a trader. Graduated from the Ural Polytechnic Institute1s department
of metallurgy. Throughout most of 1990s headed sales at several regional
metallurgical plants. In 1998 became sales manager at Sinarsky Pipe Works
and soon took control of the company. Two years later Sinarsky Works became
part of the pipe conglomerate TMK, which had been assembled by MDM Group
founders (and fellow billionaires) Sergei Popov and Andrey Melnichenko. He
became chief executive and acquired 35% stake in the company, which
controlled three large pipe plants and later acquired a fourth, despite
fierce competition from fellow billionaire Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group. In
2006 bought out Melnichenko and Popov, then listed TMK on London Stock
Exchange. The third-largest pipe producer in the world, it sells to gas
behemoth Gazprom and oil transport company Transneft, as well as Total of
France and Norway's Statoil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former secretary and third wife of the late Herbert Quandt, who rescued automaker BMW from bankruptcy. Retired from BMW's supervisory board in 1997; still owns a 17% in automaker. Lives quietly in spa town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Synthes, a Swiss-based medical-implants and biomaterials company, has presided over the firm for 30 years, leading it to the fore of medical technology. Harvard M.B.A. is also a committed environmentalist. Heads Wyss Foundation, which gives scholarships to students getting their master’s in conservation. Wine connoisseur owns a 900-acre ranch and vineyard in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bearded baron of Chicago real estate now writing headlines. Engineered $8.2 billion leveraged buyout of newspaper giant Tribune Co. last March; beat out billionaires Eli Broad, Ron Burkle, David Geffen. Sold real estate investment trust Equity Office Properties to Stephen Schwarzman's Blackstone Group for $39 billion cash last February. Parents fled Poland for America weeks before Nazi invasion. With Robert Lurie (d. 1990), built business buying, selling cheap real estate. Still owns large stakes in Equity Residential and Equity Lifestyle REITs. Other investments: low-income housing projects in Egypt, shopping malls in Brazil, office parks in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded the JCDecaux outdoor advertising company in 1964. Started out putting ads on "street furniture" such as public toilets and bus shelters. Since then has expanded advertising to airports, malls, subways and billboards. Remains chairman of $3 billion (sales) JCDecaux and still oversees strategy. Sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles are cochief executives. Are the number one outdoor advertiser in China. Company touts its "greenness", placing recycling bins for batteries, glass or other waste near its street furniture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment banker turned beer baron. With former banking partners and fellow billionaires Marcel Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira shares control of global-powerhouse brewer InBev of BelgiumDa company born of 2004 merger of AmBev of Brazil and Interbrew of Belgium. The Lemann-Telles-Sicupira trio also controls Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. His first big success was at investment bank Banco Garantia, which he founded 1971 and sold to Credit Suisse First Boston in 1998 for $675 million. Tennis player, once played in Wimbledon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former plantation field supervisor now heads IOI Group, one of world's leading operators of palm oil plantations, refineries. Making inroads into Indonesian palm oil estates via a JV with that country's Harita Group. His plants produce specialty oils, metallic stearates, fats used in soaps, detergents, cosmetics, food additives. Leading real estate developer also building townships, shopping malls, resorts in Malaysia. Rumored to scope out Asiatic Development for a possible acquisition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamonds may be forever, but Nicky Oppenheimer's De Beers diamond empire is constantly changing. Over the past few years the firm has hived off a piece of its South African operation, welcomed its first black executive and settled a long-standing price-fixing class suit that prevented it from opening offices in the U.S. In 2006 Nicky sold off a third of his family's interest in global mining giant Anglo American, founded in 1917 by grandfather Ernest, to Chinese billionaire Larry Yung. On behalf of De Beers, Oppenheimer courted Russian President Vladimir Putin in fall of 2006; two months later De Beers and Russia's state-owned Alrosa diamond mining firm signed a joint prospecting deal. De Beers sold $400 million worth of Alrosa diamonds in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited majority stake in media empire Publishing & Broadcasting (PBL) after his father died in December 2005. In the two years since taking over, the younger Packer has made significant changes, first by spinning off major PBL media assets and more recently by splitting PBL into 2 separate public companies: casino group Crown and Consolidated Media Holdings. Packer received a $675 million dividend from the demerger. In June married model turned singer/songwriter Erica Baxter in a lavish ceremony on the French Riviera reportedly attended by friends Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford grad opened doors to eponymous discount brokerage firm in 1971. Client accounts swelled during dot-com craze, then deflated when Internet bubble burst. Relinquished chief executive post in 2003; returned to helm a year later after profits fell. Stock price slipped slightly last fall after Bank of America offered free online stock trades. Last year: $2.3 billion stock buyback, $1.2 billion special dividend. Dyslexic; opened the Charles & Helen Schwab Foundation for children with learning disabilities and ADHD in 1989.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
Grew up in Moscow, attended a well-regarded high school for the city's
elite and prestigious Moscow State University. Later worked at the Institute
for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 went to the
Ministry of Foreign Affairs; worked simultaneously as a senior researcher at
the Vienna International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis. Two years
later was tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations. In 1994 met
Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman (now a billionaire) and soon became a
shareholder of Alfa-Bank, a business within the Alfa Group conglomerate; he
is now its president. Owns largest private collection of Russian art in
Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Texas wildcatter Perry Bass (d. 2006). Struck out on own after Dad passed family oil business to brother Sid (see). Today his Oak Hill Capital private equity firm manages $25 billion. Early investments: St. Petersburg Times, Continental Broadcasting. Sold New York's Plaza Hotel to Donald Trump 1994. Led $700 million leveraged buyout of Duane Reade drugstore chain 2003. Bought 9 TV stations from New York Times Co. for $575 million in 2007; agreed to purchase another 8 from News Corp. for $1.1 billion in December. Owns stake in private jet maker Aerion; expanding freight outfit Cargo 360 with $1.4 billion order for 6 Boeing 777 planes. Dollars helping dollars: another Oak Hill company, Primus International, major Boeing parts supplier.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Became publicly known in 2005 when steel giant Evraz Group listed on the
London Stock Exchange; Frolov, responsible for all of Evraz's operations, at
the time owned the second-largest stake. In 2006 sold part of his holdings
to fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich, now Evraz's largest shareholder.
Prior to joining Evraz worked as research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov
Institute of Atomic Energy. Like Evraz partner and fellow billionaire
Alexander Abramov, graduated from the Moscow Institute of Physics &
Technology and holds a Ph.D. in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads 111-year-old Godrej Group, which started out as a lockmaker. Product portfolio includes furniture, appliances, insecticides, soaps, foods, medical diagnostics. Has joint ventures with Sara Lee and candymaker Hershey's. Family also has extensive landholdings in suburban Mumbai, where long-standing land ownership restrictions were recently lifted. An Islamic group recently called on Muslims to boycott Godrej, after Adi and wife Parmeshwar hosted author Salman Rushdie in their Mumbai home in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Teamed up with cousin George Roberts (see) and fellow Bear Stearns colleague Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Winning strategy: use junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, rework balance sheets, sell for profit. First billion-dollar deal: Wometco 1984. Kohlberg exited 1987. Best known for famed $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Barbarians at the Gate took Thomas Frist's (see) HCA private with Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity in 2006 for $33 billion. With David Bonderman and James Coulter's (see both) TPG and Goldman Sachs, agreed to buy power firm TXU for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt a few months later. Net profits in 2006: $1.1 billion. Filed to go public last summer.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Vancouver magnate parlayed car dealerships, started shortly after college, into advertising, fishing and supermarket empire. Also runs eclectic tourist attractions including Ripley's Believe It or Not. Bought Guinness World Records in February. Played host to Oprah Winfrey aboard his 150-foot, white-carpeted yacht, the Nova Spirit, in August in Alert Bay, B.C. Gave $1 million to Vancouver's Stanley Park restoration one year after it was battered by severe storm. Owns massive Palm Springs lair that once belonged to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers were born in Mumbai and raised in the U.K. Simon started out importing carpets and buying real estate; David in metals trading. Later joined together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested heavily in Russia and Kazakhstan. Brothers cashed out of the business and the region after fallout with partners. Fortune is now mostly in real estate; developments range from a 1.8-million-square-foot commercial and residential space in Merchant Square in London's Paddington to seafront condominiums in Tel Aviv. Also building data-center business, Global Switch, via acquisitions. Invested in racecourses this year, buying Northern Racing for over $150 million. David lives in London in the same house he has owned for the past 20 years; Simon resides in Monaco. Both active in their Reuben Foundation, which funds health care and educational causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Teamed up with cousin Henry Kravis (see) and fellow Bear Stearns colleague Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Winning strategy: use junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, rework balance sheets, sell for profit. First billion-dollar deal: Wometco 1984. Kohlberg exited 1987. Best known for famed $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Barbarians at the Gate took Thomas Frist's (see) HCA private with Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity in 2006 for $33 billion. With David Bonderman and James Coulter's (see both) TPG and Goldman Sachs, agreed to buy power firm TXU for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt a few months later. Net profits in 2006: $1.1 billion. Filed to go public last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once Colombia’s top builder, Sarmiento parlayed his construction fortune into a sprawling financial services empire. Dealmaking filled 2007 for Colombia’s richest man. His Grupo Aval banking conglomerate acquired Colombia’s Megabanco in a government-run auction for $357 million. With Venezuelan billionaire Gustavo Cisneros, announced that the two would bid on license for a new Colombian television network. Launched plan to build Latin America Trade Mart in Bogota with U.S. developer Trammell Crow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied math at MIT, then Ph.D. from UC, Berkeley. Deciphered codes for U.S. Department of Defense during Vietnam; taught math at SUNY Stonybrook after war. Founded Renaissance Technologies 1982. Quantitative hedge fund uses complex computer models to analyze and trade securities. Fees as high as 5% of assets, 44% of profits. Worth the price: a $2.5 million investment in his funds in 1990 would be worth $1 billion today. Hires Ph.D.s over M.B.A.s. Vowed to retire in 2005, can't walk away. Raised $25 billion for institutional fund RIEF in 2006; so far performing below expectations.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Smooth sailing for the admiral of world's largest cruise ship operator. Now commands 82 ships across 10 brands including Carnival, Princess, Holland America; shuttles 7 million buffet-loving passengers around the world each year. Sales: $13 billion. Katrina helped hamper business in 2005: storm left 2 ocean liners without a home after access to New Orleans was cut off; hurricane fears caused fall and winter Caribbean bookings to dry up. Extended port contract with New Orleans last year. Owns pro basketball's Miami Heat.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailed as the "igod" on magazine cover for advent of iPhone--slickest, most-hyped gadget ever. Black-clad digi-god suddenly a Dark Angel falling to earth. His creation sells a million units in 10 weeks at $600; instant $200 price cut riles disciples. Then gets a Tinseltown takedown when he tries to muscle Hollywood as he did music biz; NBC Universal pulls shows from iTunes. Result: iFlop for Apple TV. New novel "Options" by "FakeSteve" (a FORBES writer) depicts him as narcissistic jerk. Adopted by working-class couple, dropped out of Reed College, starts Apple in proverbial garage. Fired 1985. Best revenge: One year later he buys Pixar graphics startup from Star Wars creator George Lucas (see) for $10 million. Sells it to Disney 20 years later for $7.4 billion--thanks to heavenly hit list (Toy Story, Monsters Inc., Finding Nemo, The Incredibles). In interim had second coming at Apple 1996. Now Mickey's largest individual holder. Never mind the setbacks. Still coolest tech superstar ever.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of family of Iraqi Jews who settled in Asia decades ago. Chairs CLP Group, Hong Kong electricity provider; investing in renewable energy. Chairs the Hong Kong & Shanghai Hotels, which is opening Shanghai Peninsula 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded German software giant SAP with four former IBM colleagues. Its chief executive for 30 years before retiring in May 2003. Sports enthusiast, skis, snowboards, plays golf and tennis. Sails his Morning Glory Yacht competitively. Owns luxury golf course and hotel, Fancourt Estate, in South Africa's Western Cape province. Supports HassoPlattnerVentures, which incubates promising IT technology companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jet-setting beer magnate turned over operations of his Bavaria brewery to SABMiller in 2005 but still holds big stake in the beer giant. Returned family investment arm Valores to profitability by slashing holdings from 120 companies to only 20. Now controls stakes in broadcaster Caracol, petrochemical firm Propilco and packaging maker Biofilm. Keeps homes in New York City, Paris and Baru, his private island off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Son, Andres, appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of MBI International group of companies with interests in real estate, hotels, food, oil and gas. In past years has been focusing on ramping up luxury division of extensive hotel portfolio: recent acquisitions totaling $340 million include last summer's purchase of five U.K. boutique hotels ("The Eton Collection") and two properties in Austria. In January 2008 acquired four 5-star properties in Portugal for $268 million. Twenty-five years ago got start in real estate, developing residential compounds for expats in Saudi Arabia and raising amenities to 5-star level. Noted philanthropist; sponsors a scholarship program for Arab students to study at universities in U.K., France and Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $3 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, publisher of such well-known German magazines as Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Well-known philanthropist, supports the Bambi prize (Germany's academy awards) and the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature. He holds the Leo Baeck Prize for his efforts at bringing together Jewish and non-Jewish communities in Germany. Is married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: The pachinko gambling-machine maker he founded 40 years ago, Sankyo Co., had a down year after Japanese government regulations hit the industry hard, changing the rules on payouts. The listed company posted $1.8 billion in revenues for the latest year, down 8% from the previous year, while profits fell 21% to $323 million. Projections for next year don’t look good. The company burnishes its reputation with its annual Sankyo Ladies Open golf tournament, a big event on the Japan ladies’ tour; golf is Busujima&#39s favorite sport.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older sister Esther (see) inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. The sisters ran the company jointly from 1989 to 1997; sold her share to Esther in 1997 for $800 million. Invested proceeds in companies such as Acerinox, Inmocaral and Banco Sabadel; hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; and U.S. real estate. Has received regulatory permission to create one of Spain's first hedge funds. Ably advised by Oscar Fanjul, former chief executive of oil and gas company Repsol, who sits on boards of such companies as the London Stock Exchange and The Marsh & McLennan Companies. Through her charitable foundation, sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. (Columbia, NYU, Pittsburgh). Has been linked romantically with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a commodities trader, dabbled in jute trading, banking before moving into infrastructure. Got noticed when he won bids to modernize Delhi airport and build a new one in Hyderabad. GMR's new international airport in Hyderabad was set to open in March 2008. Group expanding overseas. Snagged $2.7 billion contract to build new airport terminal in Istanbul in a consortium with Malaysia Airports. His two sons, son-in-law help run empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of Swiss-German industrial fortune heads Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Holds an engineering degree from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology and a doctorate in sustainable development from Tufts University. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland. Wine connoisseur has vineyards from California to Australia to Argentina as well as the small Weingut Schmidheiny, a vineyard in Balgach, Switzerland, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former tow truck driver now known for astute leveraged purchases. His Rank Group sold remaining stake in food industry with the $500 million sale of its shares in leading Aussie food company Goodman Fielder. In past year has made major acquisitions in packaging industry: bought Swiss food and beverage packager SIG in April for $2.3 billion followed by North Carolina’s Blue Ridge Paper Products in June and Alcoa&#39s packaging division in December. Rank now stands as second-biggest producer of drink cartons in the world. Enjoys boating and water sports. Reported owner of 190-foot yacht, Ulysses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief executive of SoftBank, Japan’s leading Internet and telecom services company. SoftBank is now Japan’s number three mobile phone carrier, after buying Vodafone’s operations two years ago behind NTT Docomo and KDDI au. SoftBank’s revenue doubled this year to $23 billion, thanks to a boost from the new phone unit. But losses related to the investment sliced profits in half, to $262 million. SoftBank also runs Yahoo Japan, the country’s top Internet site, as well as baseball team Fukuoka Hawks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Best known for his apparel, designer Armani now also makes perfume, baby clothes, home décor, five-figure watches and he just inked a deal with Samsung to produce LCD TVs. Continues to market brand as lifestyle: Has licensed his name for a string of hotels; in fall 2007, opened his first spa, at the new Armani complex in Tokyo’s Ginza district. Armani spent two years in medical school at the University of Bologna before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer. Goes to the gym for at least an hour a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns some 19% of retailer Metro AG, the group he founded 1964. Metro is one of the biggest and most international retail groups worldwide. Beisheim also manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in internet and technology companies. A widower with no children, he divides his time between his homes in Switzerland, Paris and Rottach-Eggern in Germany. An avid sports fan, has several foundations which mainly fund athletic programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Wolfgang (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Helped push out brother Gunter and sister Daniela in a drawn-out family feud. Now holds 34% stake in $5.7 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, makers of a well-known Germany coffee brand. Group also has 50.46 % stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. He and brother Wolfgang now call the shots on the key holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of apartment managers started out running Wyoming hotel and gas station. Bought 10% share in the business, expanded to Utah, Arizona. Purchased Sinclair Oil 1976. Now boasts 3 refineries, 1,000 miles of pipeline, 2,600 filling stations. Sold Barnett Shale natural gas acreage to Chesapeake Energy for $300 million in 2006. With Holly Corp., plans to build a $300 million pipeline from Salt Lake City to Las Vegas. Owns Sun Valley Ranch, location of Herb Allen's (see) media mogul confab.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made Saudi businessman made bulk of fortune through profitable aviation-contracting services with the Saudi government. Later expanded into banking, real estate and media. Owns 55% of Albaraka Banking Group, a network of Islamic investment banks with 11 subsidiaries in the Middle East and Africa. Chairman of Islamic Chamber of Commerce, Kamel has lobbied to create one commission tasked with collecting and distributing the Zakat, the charitable donation required of all Muslims. Last April Kamel sponsored education and housing for 1,000 Indonesian children left homeless by 2004 tsunami.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of brewer and sodamaker Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela’s largest private companies. Grandson of company founder. Leftist president Hugo Chavez publicly threatened to nationalize Polar if it was caught hoarding food; Polar said it has no role in the country’s food shortages. Runs one of Venezuela’s largest charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive construction magnate chairs the over 135-year old Shapoorji Pallonji group, now run by sons Shapoor and Cyrus. Group developed several landmark buildings in Mumbai. Got big break in 1971 to build a palace for the Sultan of Oman. Projects in India include factories for Coca-Cola and Volvo and two development centers for Dell. Derives bulk of fortune from 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, holding company of $29 billion (sales) Tata Group. Postponed plan to list group firm Afcons. Recently became citizen of Ireland following wife and sons who are Irish citizens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma, used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990, now one of the world's largest producers of steel pipes. Owned Ukraine's largest steel company, Kryvorizhstal, with fellow billionaire Rinat Akhmetov until it was reprivatized in 2005. This year finalized sale of his Ukrsotsbank to Italy's UniCredit Group for $2.2 billion. Planning to list 25% of Interpipe on the London Stock Exchange this spring after rumored talks to merge with steel pipe maker TMK fell through. Owns multimillion-dollar art collection that includes works by Damian Hirst, Jeff Koons and Andreas Gursky.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Michael (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Now holds 34% stake in $5.7 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, makers of a well-known Germany coffee brand. Group also has 50.46 % stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. He and brother Michael now call the shots on the key holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to the German REWE group in 1996. Invested the proceeds in prime Austrian real estate and is now one of the largest, possibly the largest, private real estate owners in Austria. His assets include the five-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange and four palaces in Vienna. The former jazz pianist, whose stage name was Charlie Walker, enjoys hanging out at the Cafe Central, an old coffee house he renovated in Vienna. Has an authorized biography: "Karl Wlaschek: A Success Story".

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own 13% of retailer Metro. Also control Travel Charm chain of 11 luxury hotels and spas located along Germany's Baltic coast and in Austria. Their Mercator Foundation supports extracurricular language and professional skills programs for immigrant children in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs 300-year-old family real estate portfolio, which includes posh area of London&#39s Chelsea and Knightsbridge lined with marquee fashion labels like Chloe, Jimmy Choo and Fendi. New arrival: Saatchi Gallery in the Duke of York Square. Cadogan began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg. Took on the management of family’s property portfolio in 1974. Also involved in animal welfare and cancer-research charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads copper producer Kazakhmys, which went public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. Sold his personal 18.8% stake in another Kazakh commodity firm, Eurasian Natural Resources, owned by billionaires Alijan Ibragimov, Patokh Chodiev and Alexander Machkevich, to Kazakhmys for $806.5 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Won&#39t this guy ever go public? Gives staff stock options anyway. Construction worker&#39s son built computer from scratch as teenager; invented an unbeatable tic-tac-toe game that won him a scholarship to MIT. Studied biophysics. Founded International Data Group 1964; launched trade rag Computerworld 1967. Added magazines MacWorld, PC World, book publishing (For Dummies series), trade shows, Web sites. Sales: $3 billion. Firm&#39s $1.4 billion investment arm has dumped $350 million into China; funding $100 million venture capital fund in Korea, $150 million fund in eastern Europe. Personally hands out cash bonuses to all 1,600 employees at Christmas.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
His father headed the largest pipeline construction trust in the Soviet
Union. From that he managed to build independent gas company Novatek, which
has large deposits in the Yamal-Nenets region in northwestern Siberia. Has
proven to be complementary to state-owned Gazprom, since he supplies Russian
regions with gas at local prices, allowing the gas giant to keep more
reserves on hand for lucrative export markets. In 2006 Gazprom bought nearly
20% of Novatek from Mikhelson and his partners, a deal widely seen as a way
for the firm to ensure its survival. An avid art collector, sponsored an
exhibit of Russian art at the 2007 Venice Biennale.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout drafted by Army 1943, moved to Detroit after WWII. Borrowed $1,800 to buy diner, flipped for tiny profit. Built homes in Arizona; real estate market crashed, moved to California. Buyouts: Castle & Cooke (Hawaii real estate), Dole Food (bananas, pineapples). Dole's profits hampered last year by European Union's new banana tariff. Health fanatic funding $1.5 billion research campus in Kannapolis, N.C. dedicated to nutrition. "It's the most spectacular thing I've ever been involved in."

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother, Thomas, in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In February 2005 sold business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Said to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin brother, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany's second-largest generic drugmaker. In 2005 sold business and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Is said to be the more extroverted of the brothers. Reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once strident adversary of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez caught flak in 2007 for toning down opposition rhetoric on his Venevision television network. Reaped more than $700 million from March 2007 sale of U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban. Also owns Venezuela’s Regional brewery and Leones baseball team, among many other assets. Boasts an important collection of Latin American art: one favorite piece is an Amazonian landscape by German artist Frank W. Post.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Henry (d. 1990), founded sand, stone and gravel firm Material Service with 2 brothers in 1919 after getting fired from $4-per-week job. Chicago firm became world's largest building materials distributor; merged with General Dynamics 1959. Today family retains massive stake in company; also stock in Alltel, JPMorgan Chase. Chairman of American foreign policy think tank, Chicago Council on Foreign Relations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father&#39s one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built into Power Corp., a $23 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. Company owns Montreal daily La Presse as well as 6 other newspapers in Quebec and Ontario. It also controls Power Financial, which includes life insurer Great-West Lifeco and Investors Group, the largest mutual fund company in Canada. In a deal worth $3.9 billion, Power Financial last year announced it was acquiring beleaguered U.S. mutual fund company Putnam Investments. Desmarais’ son Paul Jr. is chairman of Power Corp.; Dad collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec. Family is friends with French President Nicolas Sarkozy. Desmarais gave $15 million to the University of Ottawa for the Desmarais Building, the new home for the school&#39s Telfer School of Management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of one of world1s biggest shopping mall chains, Westfield. Owns 119 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.S. and Britain. Czech-born Frank Lowy moved to Hungary, then Palestine, arrived in Sydney in 1952 and opened a delicatessen. His three sons, David, Peter and Steven, work in the business. Frank is still executive chairman, as well as president of Football Federation Australia, which runs the national soccer team.

name: Billionaires
bio: From one billionaire to another. In May 2006 Warren Buffett&#39s Berkshire Hathaway paid $4 billion for 80% of Iscar, the manufacturer of precision carbide metalworking tools founded by Stef Wertheimer in 1952. His son Eitan has continued to run the company with Buffett&#39s support. Stef lobbies on behalf of his “Marshall Plan for the Middle East,” based on the idea that industrial parks like one he has in the Galilee can bring peaceful coexistence by having Jews and Arabs work together. Also invested in a handful of other Israeli businesses, including Blades Technology, a maker of jet-engine blades.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers control 18.5% of the Bouygues Group, a diversified industrial group founded by their father in 1952 with interests in telecom, media and construction. Martin is chairman and chief executive. Olivier is deputy chief executive. Over the years the $38.5 billion (sales) group has helped build the University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; the English Channel Tunnel; the Hassan II mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; and the restructuring of a wing of the Louvre Museum in Paris. The company donates to the Toulouse Midi-Pyrenees Association of guide dogs for the blind.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical innovator developed cardiovascular catheter using blowtorch, soldering iron and plastic tubing after stint as an Army surgeon. Founded Cook Group from apartment bedroom workshop in 1963 in Bloomington, Ind. Added pacemakers, syringes, ultrasound, penile grafts; now company is the world's largest privately held medical device manufacturer. Estimated sales: $1.5 billion. Rival Guidant proposed $3 billion buyout in 2003; deal collapsed after new drug-coated stent produced dismal results. Expanded into gambling: opened $380 million casino resort in French Lick, Ind. Early riser drives himself to work, arrives at 5 a.m.; eats meals in company cafeteria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., created mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. With half-brother Rupert (see) took reins 1969. Expanded via acquisition: Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Today publicly traded Franklin Resources manages $600 billion. Yale grad, former Army lieutenant; chairman. Believed to have paid $15 million for 5,300-square-foot island home off Palm Beach.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: The largest cutter and polisher of diamonds on the planet is now becoming one of New York City’s biggest landlords. His portfolio of trophy properties, acquired via his Tel Aviv-traded conglomerate, Africa Israel Investments, includes the New York Times Building and the tony Apthorp condo      complex. In November he opened the New York outpost of his growing luxury diamond jewelry franchise called, of course, Leviev. The devout Lubavitcher recently decamped from B’nei Brak to Hampstead, a London neighborhood, a move the press chalked up to Israel’s onerous taxes. (He denies the claim.) Leviev’s new home is the $65 million Palladio, a seven-bedroom bulletproof estate replete with in-house nightclub and gold-plated indoor pool—the most expensive new home in Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of late Forbes 400 member Max Fisher (d. 2005) founded real estate outfit Related Companies 1972. Initially focused on building, financing low-income housing; moved into riskier luxury buildings in New York. Nearly went bankrupt early 1990s, recovered; today company has developed more than $16 billion worth of property across the U.S., including Manhattan's massive Time Warner Center. Met Jorge Perez (see); duo made billions developing Florida condos. Partnership continues via Perez's condo and hotel projects in Latin America. Recently purchased Virgin Megastores North America from British billionaire Richard Branson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese-literature major opened store selling air conditioners in his native Nanjing 1990. Nowadays his Suning Appliance is one of the nation's two biggest electronic retailers, with 600 stores. Facing new pressures from foreign retailers like American chain Best Buy. His brother, property developer Zhang Guiping, is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brash entrepreneur founded Virgin 37 years ago as a mail-order record retailer. Now group revenues exceed $20 billion. Launched his long-grounded Virgin America, a low-cost airline; sold Virgin Megastores, the business that launched the Virgin brand; Virgin Airlines plane became world’s first commercial flight to be powered by biofuel. Virgin Galactic space flights inched closer to takeoff: recently unveiled models of aircraft meant to carry civilian space travelers. Added spate of new ventures: private jet charters, medical care and health insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of 13 children grew up poor; parents picked cotton, raised entire family in one-bedroom house in Oklahoma. First job: gas station attendant. Founded Harold Hamm Tank Truck Service 1966; sole asset a Bobtail Ford truck used to service oil wells. Company became one of the largest oilfield fluid transporters in U.S. Started oil & gas exploration, production outfit Continental Resources 1967; today drills nearly 1,600 wells in 13 states across the Rockies, Midwest and Gulf Coast. Took company public last May. Also holds stakes in oil firms Hiland Partners and Hiland Holdings.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Continental Resources', 'uri': 'companies/continental-resources', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A golf course magnate, Itoyama is known for his shareholder activism, an unusual strategy in Japan. Oversaw a shake-up at Japan Airlines, in which he held the largest stake. Owns part of broadcaster TV Tokyo. Likes to collect expensive wines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs media powerhouse Bennett, Coleman & Co. since husband Ashok's death. Sons Samir and Vineet run private group, which includes daily Times of India; also FM radio stations and Times Now, a television channel in partnership with Reuters. Jain is involved with the Times Foundation, its philanthropic arm. She and company sued FORBES for invasion of privacy. Judge issued ruling in FORBES' favor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to giant grain-trading concern Cargill. Company founded by William and Samuel Cargill, sons of Scottish sea captain, as grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Whitney: last family member to serve as chief executive, stepped down 1995. Family owns 90% of company, employees the rest. World's largest producer of plastics made from renewable resources (corn). Combined fertilizer division with another firm, took public as Mosaic 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to giant grain-trading concern Cargill. Company founded by William and Samuel Cargill, sons of Scottish sea captain, as grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Whitney: last family member to serve as chief executive, stepped down 1995. Family owns 90% of company, employees the rest. World's largest producer of plastics made from renewable resources (corn). Combined fertilizer division with another firm, took public as Mosaic 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to giant grain-trading concern Cargill. Company founded by William and Samuel Cargill, sons of Scottish sea captain, as grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Whitney: last family member to serve as chief executive, stepped down 1995. Family owns 90% of company, employees the rest. World's largest producer of plastics made from renewable resources (corn). Combined fertilizer division with another firm, took public as Mosaic 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to giant grain-trading concern Cargill. Company founded by William and Samuel Cargill, sons of Scottish sea captain, as grain storage house in Iowa after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Whitney: last family member to serve as chief executive, stepped down 1995. Family owns 90% of company, employees the rest. World's largest producer of plastics made from renewable resources (corn). Combined fertilizer division with another firm, took public as Mosaic 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner James Goodnight (see) as a graduate student at North Carolina State. Cofounded SAS Institute 1976, now believed to be largest privately held software maker in the world; massive databases, customer analysis, business intelligence. Goodnight owns two-thirds, Sall the rest. At work employees get free candy, day care, 35-hour workweek and scholarships for their kids to attend affiliated Cary Academy. Sall: soft-spoken statistician heads software development.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs real estate, shipping outfit Wheelock & Co. Invests in new Chinese listings. Relinquished chair of the Trade Development Council, which had made him the de facto trade ambassador, a post he held since 2000. Considered possible candidate for city's chief executive in 2012; lost race 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Manuel and Placido, founded Bodega Aurrera discount supermarket chain in 1958. Through his Grupo Cifra, expanded into VIPS and El Porton restaurants and Suburbia clothing stores. Cifra teamed up with Wal-Mart in the early 1990s and was later bought out; renamed Wal-Mart de Mexico (known as Walmex). Deal extended Sam Walton's empire south of the border and netted Arango more than $2 billion. Owns real estate in Acapulco and the Baja Peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father opened Rimi discount supermarket in the late 1970s, later partnering with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Royal Ahold. In 2004 Hagen exercised an option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Bought into department store chain Steen & Strom, then took the whole thing private in late 2007. Has been boosting his stake in consumer-goods company Orkla, which named him chairman of the board in 2006. Also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group. Said to have transferred 30% of his Canica holdings to each of three children in order to start estate planning but retains control over all shares. Reportedly owns island in the Caribbean and one of the biggest sailboats in Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Turkcell mobile phone company, the only Turkish ADR to trade on the NYSE. British-schooled entrepreneur returned to billionaires list last year after paying off more than $3 billion of debt accumulated at two of his banks, Pamukbank and Yapi Kredi. Also active in media sector as co-owner of TV and newspaper assets. His Genel Enerji, Turkey's only giant oil company expanding business into Iraq, expects 40 oil wells there by 2010 to produce more crude than all of Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Socialite heads Hong Kong property developer, Chinese Estates Holdings. Group posted $428 million loss from securities investments in January 2008; stock reeled in response. Owns stakes in other companies including retailer Lifestyle International. Art collector dropped $39 million for Paul Gauguin’s “Te Poipoi” (“The Morning”) in November. Paid $150 million for his fourth jet, Boeing 787 Dreamliner, last May. Also said to be one of largest collectors of red wine, with at least 10,000 bottles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Texas cotton broker joined Navy, became IBM salesman. Founded Electronic Data Systems 1962. Sold to General Motors 22 years later for $2.5 billion. Created data processing outfit Perot Systems 1988; public 1997. Ran for President twice; railed against Nafta, budget deficits. Perot Systems opened a technology center in Mexico 2006, uses offshore labor in 20 countries. Son, Ross Jr., runs Dallas real estate firm Hillwood. Redeveloping 6-million-square-foot Air Force base into industrial complex in San Bernadino, Calif.; building 4 million square feet of office, retail, residential space around American Airlines Center in downtown Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Fubon Group may weigh in on big decisions, but his two U.S.-educated sons Daniel (Tsai Ming-Chung) and Richard (Tsai Ming-Hsing) now otherwise run the show. Older son Daniel chairs Fubon Financial, the banking unit which has been expanding rapidly in recent years. Richard is in charge of the insurance and telecom businesses. The brothers work closely together and serve as each other’s deputy at the companies they head. Apparently live in the same apartment building.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Powerful wife of Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov started out as a factory worker,
then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when
they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal
commission. In 1991 started plastic-products company Inteko, which produced
furniture and crockery but has since expanded into construction and
construction materials. Inteko sued the publisher and the editor of FORBES
RUSSIA over a December 2006 cover story about the company. So far, she's
won; litigation is ongoing. Husband Luzhkov was reappointed mayor by
Vladimir Putin in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in the early 1990s; today bank is estimated to be worth $4 billion. This year sold iron ore and coke interests to Lanebrook Ltd., the major shareholder of Russian miner and steelmaker Evraz Group; received cash and shares in Evraz. Battling with government over stake in oil company, Ukrnafta; wants to either buy the government's share or get the government to buy Privat's share back. Trying to gain control of 1+1, one of Ukraine's top television channels, in partnership with American billionaire Ronald Lauder's Central Media Enterprises.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Russian immigrants grew up in the Bronx. Became Brooks Brothers clerk; left business school to design ties for Beau Brummel 1967. Launched Polo with $50,000 later that year. Sold 28% of company to Goldman Sachs for $138 million 1994; took public 1997. Today classic designs span men's and women's clothing, luggage, house paint, furniture, fragrances; new line Rugby now experimenting with "punk meets preppy" for younger generations. Signed exclusive deal with Wimbledon to dress umpires, ballpersons in French navy RLX Tennis duds. Collection of European cars was on display at Museum of Fine Arts in Boston: Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, Porsche, Jaguar. Son David runs Polo advertising. Daughter Dylan runs Manhattan candy store.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel’s richest woman controls Bank Hapoalim, the nation’s largest bank, with $614 million in operating profits for the first three quarters of 2007. Arison also owns a majority stake in Housing & Construction, Israel’s largest real estate development group. Through Arison Holdings, the 50-year-old heiress will invest some $100 million in clean and renewable energy ventures, and will invest another $100 million in real estate in India with fellow Israeli billionaire Yitzhak Tshuva. In June Arison’s husband was released from prison following a three-month stint for a sexual harassment conviction.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined father's Hartz Mountain Pet Products at the age of 21; sold company for $350 million in 2000 to private equity firm J.W. Childs. Began buying land in New Jersey 1960s; today owns 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail properties from Newark to Jersey City. Also hotels: Manhattan's tony Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand. Plans to redevelop 98-acre site of a former Ford Motor plant in Edison, N.J.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Turkey's largest construction company, Enka. Narrowing asset mix by selling out of retail supermarket chains in Europe and Russia. Born in Macedonia, he established Enka at age 27 in Istanbul with brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salesman's son dropped out of college, took to road selling plush toys. Sold first line of stuffed animals 1986. Beanie Babies hit shelves 1993; created collecting craze. Sales down an estimated 30% to $375 million in 2006 as popularity of bean-filled cuties wanes. Trying to rehab toy business; now has licensing deals, partnerships with Nascar, Paramount. Also dolls: recently released Ty Girlz can be registered online to allow kids to shop, take vacations virtually. Owns Four Seasons hotel in New York, resorts in California, Hawaii, Mexico. Recently renovated the Kennedy Cottage at his San Ysidro Ranch in California; travelers pay $2,990 per night to sleep in cottage occupied by John and Jackie Kennedy on their honeymoon.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Metals magnate is experiencing a rebirth of sorts. In 1990s was one of the
best-known Russian businessmen, co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank
Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000 sold all his holdings in Russia and was quiet for
four years. Then in 2004 made a triumphant comeback as co-owner, with fellow
billionaire Alisher Usmanov, of Metalloinvest Holding, one of Russia's
largest ore mining and processing firms. Has postponed a London initial
public offering of Metalloinvest but plans to build, with partial government
financing, a large affordable-housing development outside Moscow. Daughter
Anna Anisimova, a high-profile member of the growing diaspora of wealthy
Russians in the U.S., plans to launch her own perfume line.

name: Billionaires
bio: After graduating from the Moscow Institute of Civil Engineering started out at one of the divisions of Soviet construction behemoth Glavmosstroi. In 1993 Construction Department 155 became a private company, with Balakin its largest shareholder. Later worked in highly-placed jobs in the Moscow city government and in 2005, after four years as a bureaucrat, turned his focus to his business. SU-155 annually builds 1.3 million square meters of affordable housing in the Moscow area and other regions. Two notable projects: a new office for the KGB successor agency, the FSB, and suburban Moscow's first indoor ski resort.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tycoon cashed in on the golden age of private equity in 2007: sold 18% stake in his Apollo Management for $1.2 billion to California Public Employees' Retirement System, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority last July. Studied philosophy, history at Dartmouth. Then Harvard M.B.A. Took job at Drexel Burnham Lambert 1980s; firm bankrupt 1990, created Apollo later that year. Claimed average annual return: 40%. Recently bought casino outfit Harrah's Entertainment for $27.8 billion in cash and assumed debt with Texas Pacific Group. Owns one of country's most renowned art collections: impressionists, contemporary, old masters. Bedford, N.Y. estate features an apple orchard, sculpture garden, reflecting pool.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in the early 1990s; today the bank is estimated to be worth $4 billion. This year sold iron ore and coke interests to Lanebrook Ltd, the major shareholder of Russian miner and steelmaker Evraz Group; received cash and shares in Evraz. Battling with government over stake in oil company, Ukrnafta; wants either to buy the government's share or get the government to buy Privat's share back. Via his private company, Palmary Enterprises, won control over Australia's manganese ore miner Minerals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jazz musician's son executed first trade at age 12. Studied finance at Long Island U., went to work in commodities division of Merrill Lynch 1972. Harvard M.B.A. 1973. Traded futures at brokerage CBWL-Hayden Stone; left after feud with boss. Founded money management and hedge fund outfit Bridgewater Associates 1975. Assets under management: $150 billion. Shuns public markets: "The notion of selling hedge funds is ridiculous." Young employees routinely asked to critique upper-level management.
title: Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Bridgewater Associates', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Fujian Province, Hui is one of China's largest  property barons. Owns properties in Beijing, on Nanjing Road and in Fujian  Province. Recently opened Hyatt on the Bund, overlooking Shanghai's financial district. As of summer 2007, had 26 projects under construction in 17 mainland cities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Texas wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), who founded company with poker winnings and was said to be the inspiration for J.R. Ewing character on TV's Dallas. Half brothers Herbert and Bunker lost fortunes trying to corner silver market. Ray Lee stuck with oil, made huge finds in Yemen; now fighting with Yemeni government over control of fields. Constructing new liquefied natural gas projects in Yemen and Peru, spending $730 million expanding oil refinery in Alabama. Hunt Oil recently inked deal to explore for oil in Kurdish region of Iraq. Owns Hyatt hotels, office parks in Dallas/Fort Worth area.

name: Billionaires
bio: Housing market may be heading down the toilet, but chrome and porcelain thrones are still making millions for third-generation chief of Kohler Co. Grandfather founded company 1873 to make cast-iron and steel farming tools and cemetery accessories for Midwesterners. Today empire includes plumbing fixtures and faucets, tile, furniture, cabinets, engines, generators, golf resorts in Wisconsin and Scotland. Bulk of revenues generated with goods sold through wholesalers, retailers like Home Depot and Lowe's. Now focusing on higher end of market; selling cast-iron bathtubs, $3,000 sinks. Yale grad also breeds Morgan show horses.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya (see), created Red Bull energy drink and marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme sports sponsorships. Company also has stakes in two Formula One teams and two soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and the New York Red Bulls. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $4.4 billion (sales) company which is expanding into China and strengthening its position in Japan but still doesn't sell in France, Denmark, Norway, Iceland and Uruguay due to regulatory restraints on the drink's contents. Mateschitz concentrates these days on his many other interests including a construction company, a magazine and Hangar-7, the event center situated on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historic aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls. Also owns a luxury resort on Laucala, an island in Fiji.

name: Billionaires
bio: After graduating from the economics department of St. Petersburg State University started a residential construction business with a classmate in 1994. During the privatizations, bought one of the largest city-owned construction firms, Lenstroireconstruktsiya, or LSR. Listed its shares in 2007 offering. Today LSR also owns building-materials businesses and builds more than half the affordable housing and nearly a quarter of high-end homes in St. Petersburg. Has embarked on an expansion to other regions of the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made founder of Finansbank in Turkey sold out to National Bank of Greece for $2.76 billion in 2006. Still works 11-hour days tending to business projects in Russia, Romania and Turkey. Claims he's giving away 2% of net income every month for the construction of primary schools and girls' dormitories in poor Turkish neighborhoods. Now plans to spend up to $1 billion over the next 15 years on a new, eponymous private university in Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher's apprentice owns and runs $10 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain; group's 14,000 locations account for 70% of Germany's drugstores. Have also expanded into Austria, Holland, Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal and Eastern Europe. Wife Christa and children Lars and Meike help run the business. Football fan; enjoys sport cars, apparently owns a Ferrari, Aston Martin, Porsche and Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sun Pharma in 1983 as maker of psychiatric drugs. Now a leading generic drug maker, with 46% of sales overseas. Plans to buy Israeli generics firm Taro Pharma. Spun off research arm into listed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brooklyn-born investor Preston Tisch. "Bob" with brother Laurence, bought New Jersey hotel in 1946, leased hotels in once posh Atlantic City. Later managed NYC's Drake, Belmont Plaza, Regency. Took control of Loews Theatres 1959; varied interests now include watches (Bulova), tobacco (Lorillard), oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk). Bob served 2-year term as U.S. Postmaster General, eventually co-owner of pro football's New York Giants. Company remains under family control. Family contributions to NYU exceed $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of T.C. Pharmaceuticals, a producer of energy drinks in Thailand. Met up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago and the two decided to found an energy drink company. Chaleo provided the beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. The result: Red Bull, which now has $4.4 billion in sales and in which they each own 49%. Son Chalerm, who holds the remaining 2% stake in Red Bull, owns one of Asia's leading wine producers, Siam Winery, whose labels include Monsoon Valley and Sabai, an herb-and-wine drink.

name: Billionaires
bio:
