Born in a small town near Moscow, studied economics at Moscow State
University, where he got a doctorate. Headed several investment firms before
joining Alfa Group in 1995. Worked in the firm's
food-and-commodities-trading subsidiary, Alfa Eco, then led the group's
takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. Later became a lobbyist and member
of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament. Since then his
relations with other Alfa shareholders have become strained. However,
maintains a large stake in Altimo, a company that inherited Alfa Eco's
assets and now has major holdings in Russia's telecom industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beijing's richest resident owns very visible properties in the city, including Glory China Center, on East Chang, an avenue leading into Tiananmen Square. Also has stake in China Minsheng Banking, country's largest nongovernment-owned bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star Wars creator working with fellow billionaire Steven Spielberg (see) on 4th installment of Indiana Jones franchise; newest chapter slated for May. Directed first movie, THX 1138, while studying film at U. of Southern California. Then Star Wars: original 1977 film remains 18th-best-grossing movie of all time with $800 million worldwide. Combined worldwide box office of all 6 Star Wars films: $4.3 billion. Combined sales toys, other merchandise even richer: $13.5 billion. Founded Industrial Light & Magic special-effects shop in 1975; now handles trickery for myriad blockbusters (Harry Potter, Pirates of the Caribbean). Moving to TV: CG-animation series Star Wars: The Clone Wars set for this year; partnered with Turner Broadcasting Network and Warner Bros. Pictures in February to release full-length film, TV series.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a district judge in southern India, cofounded HCL in 1976 to make country's first computer. Converted HCL into $4.7 billion (sales) outsourcing, hardware firm with operations in 18 countries. Clients include Cisco, Boeing, IBM. Built 46-acre technology hub near Delhi to accommodate 15,000 engineers. Recently awarded the Padma Bhushan, one of nation's highest civilian honors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of bingo parlor operator studied at U. of Pennsylvania, became keno manager at Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas. Bought Golden Nugget before building Mirage, Bellagio resorts. Sold Mirage Resorts to Kirk Kerkorian (see) for $6.4 billion in 2000. Took Wynn Resorts public 2002; opened $2.7 billion Wynn Las Vegas megacasino 3 years later. Now building expansion Encore. Unveiled $1.2 billion Wynn Macau casino resort 2006; complex features 600 hotel rooms, 4 restaurants. Elbowed Picasso&#39s "Le Rêve" just before he planned to sell the painting to hedge fund manager Steve Cohen (see) for $139 million.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., created mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. With half-brother Charles, took reins 1969. Expanded via acquisition: Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Today publicly traded Franklin Resources manages $600 billion. Washington & Lee grad, former marine; vice chairman.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable yet reclusive head of publicly-traded Swiss luxury group Richemont, which owns Cartier, Chloe, Dunhill and other premium brands. Weathering a U.S. slowdown in luxury spending with growing demand in key European and Asian markets. Reportedly negotiating a deal to invest $19 million in Saracens, the English rugby club. With family relatives, owns two of South African's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and LOOmarins; also owns own of the country's most exclusive golf clubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start supplying building materials to state oil firm at age 22. Later moved into woodworking and eventually paper manufacturing. Today his privately held RGM Group owns April, one of Asia's largest pulp and paper makers, and Asian Agri, one of Indonesia's top five palm oil producers. His Tanoto Foundation has donated millions to schools and earthquake victims. Now spends most of his time in Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paired up with high school buddy Jay Van Andel (d. 2004) to create Amway, giant direct-seller of cosmetics, nutritional supplements. Entrepreneurial duo opened drive-in diner after stints in the Army. Began pushing all-purpose cleaner to friends, strangers, door-to-door 1959; today more than 3 million salespeople generating $7.1 billion in sales a year under Alticor name. Richard retired 1993; second generation now at helm. Owns pro basketball's Orlando Magic; with wife, Helen, has donated more than $400 million to health, education, the arts. Son Dick spent $30 million on failed Michigan gubernatorial bid 2006; took heat for laying off workers in job-strapped Michigan while Amway expanded in China during the 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who turned Formula One racing into one of the world’s most popular sports. Also a clever dealmaker: In 2005 he sold his remaining 25% stake in Formula One to CVC Capital Partners, a leading European private equity firm, then turned around and reinvested with CVC in a new joint company called Alpha Prema. The new corporation now controls 100% of Formula One Group, and Bernie still gets to direct the empire.  With pal Flavio Briatore, acquired Queens Park Rangers soccer club in September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulk of fortune comes from 1998 sale of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro for $2.1 billion. Faria kept some of Banco Real assets, around which he has since built Banco Alfa, with $6.9 billion in assets, now Brazil's 17th-largest bank. Also owns Agropalma, a company reported to be Latin America's largest palm oil producer, which is benefiting from the growing demand for biodiesel. Another holding is C&C, a chain of do-it-yourself home improvement stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparently met Helmut Horten, founder of the eponymous German department store chain, in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19 years old. Despite 30-year age difference, they wed 7 years later. In 1987 he died and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune. Austria's merry widow now divides her time between a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas; a residence in Tessin, Switzerland; a penthouse in Vienna and a house by the Worthersee in Austria. Owns one of world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. Said to enjoy hunting and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ardent cricket fan, spurned family's trading business to start finance firm. Snatched prized license to convert it into a bank 2003. Stock soaring since buying out longtime partner Goldman Sachs in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Accidental entrepreneur" studied chemistry at UC, Berkeley, got Ph.D. from Caltech. Researched weapons propulsion at Johns Hopkins and inadvertently dreamed up the integrated circuit that spawned the PC revolution. One of the Traitorous Eight cofounded Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957. Created chipmaker Intel with Robert Noyce 1968; introduced first microprocessor 3 years later. Coined Moore's Law: components on chip (and hence computing power) would double approximately every two years; only recently has this begun to slow. Intel still reigns as world's biggest chipmaker, sales pass $35 billion. Stepped down as chairman emeritus last year. Donated $5 billion worth of shares to Gordon & Betty Moore Foundation in 2000.
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1978 became president of the board of his father’s Eternit, a construction materials manufacturer. Soon halted the company’s production of asbestos-containing goods. In 2003 donated $1 billion to support sustainable-development programs like community organizations, educational programs, corporate social responsibility and the effective management of natural resources. Much of his wealth is now held in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments and is handled by professional managers. Art collector favors contemporary painters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Budapest-born immigrant fled to Sweden during Soviet occupation of Hungary; landed in New York 1958. Learned English from nuns at Holy Trinity School. Started plane brokerage business while studying economics at UCLA; disguised his youth by communicating via telegram. With fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda, started plane rental outfit International Lease Finance with $150,000 savings, $1.7 million bank loan. Business took off as deregulating airline industry lined up for low-risk leases. Sold to AIG 1990. Has donated more than $100 million to Stanford U.; gave $65 million to National Air & Space Museum.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Biggest individual shareholder in American IT Software firm Computer Associates. Haefner's 24% stake can be traced back to 1968 when he sold his data processing business to University Computing, which was later acquired by Computer Associates. Back home in Switzerland, his Automobil-und Motoren AG (AMAG) is the country's biggest importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda, Audi and Porsche. His Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland has approximately 100 horses and has bred such winners as Simple Exchange and Media Puzzle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. In 1999 sold his stake to MG Technologies in exchange for $1 billion in cash and 21% stake in the combined group. In March 2006 sold that stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million. Runs financial consulting firm, Luserve AG, from Switzerland, where he lives with his wife and six children. Enthusiastic hobby sailor, owns the yacht Hetairos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former exec at real estate syndicate Property Research started storage business 1972 after stopping at warehouse on road trip and learning it was full. Lost potential customers with confusing signs: people thought "Private Storage" meant closed to general public. New name brought them in droves. Today Public Storage nation's largest self-storage company. Bought rival Shurgard for $5.5 billion in 2005. Staunch Republican gave $1 million to Schwarzenegger in 2005, $500,000 to ultraright Progress for America in 2006. Horse racer seeking first Kentucky Derby win.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded BlackBerry maker Research In Motion while student at University of Waterloo. Company's co-chief executive, along with fellow billionaire James Balsillie, drives its technology and research. Both individuals' fortunes more than doubled in past year thanks to strength of RIM's stock and a 3-for-1 stock split. Threw an employee appreciation party that featured Van Halen at the Air Canada Centre in Toronto in November. Reportedly building a $13.2 million house just outside Waterloo on 76-acre property with private lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad took job in arbitrage at Goldman Sachs 1982; worked with billionaires Edward Lampert, Richard Perry. Left to found Och-Ziff hedge fund with $100 million initial investment from Ziff brothers. Assets under management: $33 billion. Took public in November; stock down since. On board of poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation. Hedging bets: donated money to 4 presidential candidates (2 Democrats, 2 Republicans).
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Och-Ziff Capital Management Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold electronics for father's distribution company after high school. Opened car stereo store 1966. Used superstore concepts to attract customers, thicken margins. Renamed operation Best Buy 1983; took public 1985. Pioneered big-box-store concept: stacked inventory on sales floor, let customers touch merchandise. Purchased 8-year-old computer-repair firm Geek Squad 2002 for $3 million; today all U.S. Best Buy stores have Geek Squad service available.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebay's first president and full-time employee, Skoll remains its second-largest shareholder. He is no longer involved with the company, though, and has turned his attention to philanthropy and movies. Skoll was executive producer of An Inconvenient Truth, the global-warming documentary that featured former Vice President Al Gore. The film, which was made by Skoll's Participant Productions, won two Oscars in 2007. Skoll pumped gas in Toronto before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold houses as a student at Santa Clara U. Expanded into commercial real estate 1960s. Built portfolio erecting campuses for tech titans Apple and Yahoo. Today Sobrato Development owns and manages 100 buildings in Silicon Valley, 8.5 million square feet of commercial space, 8,500 residential units; another 400 acres ready for development. Increased demand for prime office space, rising rents pushing up profits as tech companies expand. Tax-efficient philanthropy: donates buildings, office parks to foundations to sell or use. Donated $200 million to Sobrato Family Foundation in 2007; focuses on giving general operating support to Silicon Valley non-profits.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Born and raised in Israel, Steinmetz served in the army after the Yom Kippur War and moved to Belgium in 1978 to run his father's diamond business. Eventually became chairman of the Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group, which is De Beers' largest buyer of rough diamonds. Now back in Israel, Steinmetz has expanded into natural resource mining and real estate. His Beny Steinmetz Group mines copper and cobalt in Congo and Zambia, iron and bauxite in Guinea and diamonds in Sierra Leone, to name a few. He and his wife oversee the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of Japan's best-known discount clothing brand, Uniqlo, which is sometimes referred to as the Japanese version of the Gap. His company, Fast Retailing, last business year posted record sales of $3.9 billion from its sales of Chinese-made jackets, shirts and other clothing that retail for as little as $5. Yanai is taking the Uniqlo brand overseas: last year, opened a branch in New York City's swank Soho neighborhood. It was followed by an outlet in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation head of engineering behemoth Bechtel Group; company built Hoover Dam, Trans-Alaska Pipeline and Channel Tunnel. Father, Stephen (see), became company president 1960, chairman 1973; Riley now chairman, chief executive. Both believed to own 20% of company. Sales exceed $20 billion. Recently pulled out of Iraq after completing $2.3 billion in reconstruction work. Other projects: Tacoma Narrows Bridge in Seattle; New Doha International Airport in Qatar. Also owns stake in money management firm Fremont Group.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Bechtel Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation leader of engineering behemoth that built the Hoover Dam and Channel Tunnel. Became Bechtel president 1960; chairman 1973. Son Riley (see) now in command; both believed to own 20% of company. Revenues exceed $20 billion. Recently pulled out of Iraq after completing $2.3 billion in reconstruction work; lost 52 workers to war since 2003. Other projects: Tacoma Narrows Bridge in Seattle, New Doha International Airport in Qatar. Owns stake in money management firm Fremont Group.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Bravo brewery in Russia and created popular Botchkarov beer brand. Sold to Heineken February 2002. Used proceeds to go on buying spree in native Iceland and eastern Europe. Big year for Thor: In July 2007, successfully orchestrated an $8 billion takeover of Iceland’s generics maker Actavis in the biggest generics deal globally and third largest pharmaceuticals deal. Also sold stake in Bulgarian Telecommunications Company (BTC) for $2.4 billion to AIG and stake in Bulgarian EIBank for $300 million. Shareholder activist is now trying to gain seats on board of Finnish telecom operator Elisa, in which his investment firm Novator has a 13% stake. Other holdings include stakes in Iceland’s Landsbanki, Polish telecom Play, real estate in Romania, Scandinavia, Spain, Turkey and elsewhere in eastern Europe. Lives in London with longtime girlfriend, who is a movie producer, and their son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a grocery store manager spent childhood stacking bread, chasing shopping carts. Joined union local as a box boy at age 13. Tried college, returned home to stock shelves at dad's Stater Bros. store. Rose to store manager, eventually vice president of Stater Bros.' parent, Petrolane. Tried to purchase company via leveraged buyout; failed, was fired. Severance: $8,450. Founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralph's. Often buys distressed operations in poor neighborhoods to pay low prices, avoid bidding wars. Worker friendly: uses union sources to find hidden value in possible takeovers. Internal rate of return from 1985 to 2003: 43% a year. Failed to buy Tribune newspaper company with fellow Los Angeles billionaire Eli Broad; advised Dow Jones' union during company's negotiations with Rupert Murdoch over sale of Wall Street Journal, other assets to News Corp. Close friend of Bill Clinton; former president became Yucaipa advisor in 2001, reportedly cashed out recently for perhaps $20 million.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sound of silence produces pile of profit for Oregon-born, San Francisco-bred electrical engineer. Played clarinet as child, became fascinated by reed vibrations. Worked at Ampex in high school, on early videotape recording system. Engineering Ph.D. at Cambridge. Founded Dolby Labs in London 1965, relocated to San Francisco 1975. Made fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate hiss and background noise. Dolby now industry standard for movies, stereos. First blockbusters in 1977: Star Wars, Close Encounters of the Third Kind. Went public 2005. With wife, donated $16 million for a new stem-cell lab at UCSF. Now polishing 3-D digital cinema technology.
title: Founder and director emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Dolby Laboratories', 'uri': 'companies/dolby-laboratories', 'title': 'Founder and director emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Pennsylvania native attended Bowdoin College; became stock analyst for Pittsburgh National Bank, started Duquesne Capital Management 1981. Became money man for George Soros (see) 1988; famously orchestrated his boss' billion-dollar raid on the British pound in 1992 with timely short position. Believed to help generate string of 30% returns for Soros' Quantum Fund. Duo parted ways in 2000. Returned to Duquesne Capital, runs No Margin Fund from Pittsburgh. Runs Harlem Children's Zone; nonprofit provides educational services to thousands of children and adults.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in April 2004 then sold his 55% stake in company to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006. Holds a 5% stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program to drive New York City taxi. Studied harpsichord at Juilliard. Started trading soybeans; turned $3,000 he borrowed on his credit card into $45,000. Forgot to hedge, lost half the profits. Went to work for Michael Marcus at Commodities Corp. Founded Caxton Associates 1983. His Caxton Global Investments hedge fund has returned 25% annually net of fees since. Chairman of Juilliard donated 140 original musical scores, sketches by Bach, Beethoven, Brahms, to school last year. Created School Choice Scholarships Foundation; nonprofit pays high school tuition for needy kids. Recently paid $70 million for a cluster of beachfront properties in Santa Barbara, Calif.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of ESL Investments kept busy during high school reading corporate reports, financial textbooks. Member of Skull & Bones at Yale; took summer job at Goldman Sachs. Snagged early investment from Richard Rainwater. Founded own firm 1988. Pulled off what was one of the greatest corporate comebacks in history with 2005 merger of Kmart and Sears, Roebuck. Spent several hundred million dollars buying distressed Kmart bonds; brought company out of bankruptcy, took public 2003. Shares vastly soared between May 2003 and April 2007. Now faltering: SHLD shares down since last spring. Other investments: AutoZone, AutoNation. Client roster includes fellow billionaires Michael Dell, David Geffen, Tisch family's Loews Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started making vaccines for India's poor in a corner of his father's stud farm in 1966. His Serum Institute, which his son Adar helps run, is now one of world's biggest makers of children's vaccines. His Poonawalla Stud Farm, jointly owned with brother Zavary, has produced 287 Classic winners. Chairs the Royal Western India Turf Club. Collects custom-built limousines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied at Brooklyn College 1954, then M.B.A. from NYU. Made fortune issuing junk bonds secured by metals companies he acquired; stopped interest payments, companies went bankrupt, bought assets back for pennies on the dollar. Acquired military contractor AM General for $133 million 1992; maker of U.S. Army's all-terrain Humvee vehicles created luxury-SUV market with 2.5-ton Hummer. Sold majority stake to Ronald Perelman's (see) MacAndrews & Forbes holding company for $930 million in 2004. Built palatial compound in the Hamptons; mansion believed to be 100,000 square feet and have 30 bedrooms. Compound recently estimated to be worth $185 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a street vendor of fried mussel pancakes in Bangkok, Charoen made his fortune in whiskey and beer. Took his Thai Bev company public in Singapore in September 2006 after attempts to list in Thailand were derailed by protests against the promotion of alcohol; in June, company reportedly said it would try to list in Thailand again. Group’s best-known brand is Chang Beer, Thailand’s top-selling beer. Exporting Chang abroad: brand became official sponsor of Liverpool&#39s Everton soccer club in 2004 and shipped its first cases to the U.S. in May 2007. Other brands include low-alcohol-content beer Archa and liquor brands Sangsom and Mekong.  Also owns Plaza Athénées in New York City and Bangkok; residential buildings in Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father was a doctor in China; family fled during WWII, moved to South Africa. Graduated from high school at 16, a doctor by age 23. Joined UCLA faculty 1980, launched research leading to first human islet cell transplant. Left to commercialize research. Quit first company, VivoRx, after feuding with investors. Founded American Pharmaceutical Partners 1997; invented cancer treatment Abraxane. Company renamed Abraxis BioScience. Holds more than 30 patents with other inventors. Actress wife, Michele Chan, famous for roles on 1980s TV shows.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in
Moscow hotels. In 1990 worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary
Ferrero Rocher; then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive
contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 created the first ever upmarket brand
of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999, with help of McKinsey & Co.,
set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering consumer credit market; became
market leader three years later. Came under fire in 2007 from the Russian
government, which investigated the bank's fee structure. As a result, Russky
Standart, as it's known, has removed monthly account fees and is doing more
to attract deposits, focusing less on issuing credit.

name: Billionaires
bio: The low-key real estate and energy mogul spends most of his time in New York City, home of the iconic Plaza Hotel that he bought in 2005 for $675 million and refurbished under the direction of his designer daughter, Gal. The building, now part condo, reopened in October, its 100th birthday, with a spectacular party punctuated by fireworks and a duet of “My Way” performed with Paul Anka. (Tshuva maintains a residence in the Plaza.) Plans are already under way to extend the Plaza brand to Las Vegas, Europe and the Far East. Via Elad Holdings (named after his son, the 27-year-old heir apparent), Tshuva also owns a vast portfolio of residential buildings in North America and Europe. In Israel his publicly traded Delek operates 232 gas stations, and has interests in insurance, car dealerships and cable television.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With brothers Dirk and Robert, reinvests proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities. Family trust believed to now exceed $10 billion in assets. Sold shares of Och-Ziff hedge fund in company's recent public offering; remain passive investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With brothers Robert and Daniel, reinvests proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities. Family trust believed to now exceed $10 billion in assets. Sold shares of Och-Ziff hedge fund in company's recent public offering; remain passive investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With brothers Dirk and Daniel, reinvests proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities. Family trust believed to now exceed $10 billion in assets. Sold shares of Och-Ziff hedge fund in company's recent public offering; remain passive investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-chief executive of BlackBerry maker Research In Motion with fellow billionaire Mike Lazaridis. Both individuals' fortunes more than doubled in the past year thanks to strength of RIM's stock and a 3-for-1 stock split. Donated $50 million to create a new school of international affairs in Waterloo, which will be named after him. This will support the nearby Centre for International Governance Innovation, a think tank he started. Failed in his bid to move NHL's Nashville Predators to Canada. Helped establish the Waterloo Regional Children's Museum and donates to other causes like Lazaridis' Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics. Competes in men's long-course triathlons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Delisted his Nan Fung Textile 1989; moved into real estate. Apparently partnered with Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong on some projects. Has stakes in China Aoyuan Property Group, Singapore billionaire Ng Teng Fong's Sino Land.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang's wealth comes mainly from stakes in three China-listed companies: gem trader, producer Xinhu Zhongbao; conglomerate Zhejiang Xinhu Venture Investment; and Harbin High-Tech Group. In spare time, runs Chinese chess club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Purveyor of Mighty Morphin Power Rangers still making deals. Last March sold 50.5% controlling stake in German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media to buyout firms KKR and Permira for $4 billion, over double the $1.7 billion he and partners had paid for it in 2003. His original $270 million bet paid back more than 3-fold; made $970 million including fees. "What can I say? I&#39m a lucky man." That same month closed deal to buy controlling stake (with partners) in A. Jerrold Perenchio&#39s (see) Spanish-language broadcaster, Univision, for $13.7 billion. Co-owns controlling stake of Israel&#39s Bezeq Israeli Telecom. In 2001 sold Fox Family Channel, joint venture with Rupert Murdoch (see), to Disney for $5.2 billion. Egyptian-born, Israeli-bred U.S. citizen. Paid $300 million in back taxes on gains from Fox Family sale after IRS probed tax shelter he, others used; told Congress that accountants gave him bad advice. Ardent Democratic benefactor for Hillary Clinton. Wrote theme song for Inspector Gadget.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked construction jobs in Alaska before borrowing a bulldozer on credit and founding his own company in Montana. Grew with federal highway contracts. Rescued bankrupt Morrison Knudsen in 1996. Reorganized, renamed Washington Group International in 1998; lost in bankruptcy after dispute over later acquisition from Raytheon. Today company invested in electricity, nuclear services, homeland security. Personally owns stakes in Montana's regional railroad; largest tug and barge fleet in British Columbia; Butte copper mine. Yachtsman spends time cruising on his 226-foot yacht, Attessa; ship sports a helipad, movie theater, gym, two 2,000hp diesel engines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine's youngest billionaire started out as finance director of bank Finance & Credit in 1992 when he was just 19. Eventually gained a majority stake in its holding company, Finance & Credit Group. Planning to take public Finance & Credit Bank in the next two years; this follows the successful initial offering of iron ore producer Ferrexpo in London in May 2007. Also a deputy in Ukraine's parliament; ally of current Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko.

name: Billionaires
bio: With James Coulter, cofounded private equity behemoth Texas Pacific Group. With KKR and Goldman Sachs, agreed to buy power company TXU for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt last year. Duo managed money for the Bass family; split to start TPG 1992. Bought Continental Airlines for $66 million; later sold for $640 million profit. Other hits: Burger King, J. Crew. With Leon Black's Apollo Management, paid $27.8 billion in cash and assumed debt for Harrah's Entertainment casino company. Both prefer complex deals others shy away from. Tinkered with idea of selling stake in company to outside investors last spring; put on hold after markets turned downward last summer. "Bondo" attended U. of Washington, then Harvard Law; became a civil rights attorney for Department of Justice. Later studied Islamic law in Cairo; speaks several languages. Paid the Rolling Stones to play his 60th birthday party in Las Vegas in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Record-label tycoon started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father’s death. Moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba Recordings, whose crown jewel is Jive Records. Ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, later Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and &#39N Sync. Sold Zomba Recordings to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. Now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on charitable foundation that works in nine African countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Machkevich (both also billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; listed 20% of Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation in London last November. A native of Uzbekistan, Chodiev studied international law and Japanese and lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals. Traveled to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nigeria's first billionaire hit the jackpot when his sugar-production company listed on the Nigerian stock exchange last year. Meanwhile, proposed initial public offerings of his flour and cement companies have stalled. Began career as trader at 21 with loan from his uncle; built his Dangote Group into conglomerate with interests in sugar, flour milling, salt processing, cement manufacturing, textiles, real estate, haulage and oil and gas. Closely linked to Nigeria's former president Olusegun Obasanjo.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Saudi-born Lebanese parliamentary majority leader heads a bloc intent on carrying out legacy of his politically moderate father, slain Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. Takes cover in Riyadh when security gets shaky in Beirut. Also serves as general manager of Saudi Oger, the family's $9 billion (revenues) construction company. Georgetown grad likes to scuba dive; smokes Cuban cigars.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; listed 20% of Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation in London last November. Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with six sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Memphis native studied economics at U. of Virginia. Early success trading cotton on Wall Street. Founded Tudor Investment Corp. hedge fund 1980. Predicted 1987 stock market crash, returned 125% net of fees that year. Estimated average annual returns 24%; down last year amid summer's violent market turmoil. Hunter, fisherman owns land in Zimbabwe. Started New York City poverty-fighting group Robin Hood Foundation 1988; group raised $70 million at a single banquet last May.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, was former chairman of New York Stock Exchange. Joined Wall Street specialist firm in 1945; firm became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. Peter joined as director in 1973, sold to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion in 2000. Owns 3,000-acre hunting range in New Jersey.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger sister, Alicia, (see) inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. The two ran the company jointly from 1989 to 1997; Esther then bought out her sister for $800 million. Now owns 44% of $13 billion (sales) group; sits on its supervisory board. Last year received the Spain-U.S. Chamber of Commerce business leader of the year award. In January was awarded the Gold Cross for Social Solidarity for her social work through her Esther Koplowitz foundation. A member of Spanish nobility herself, she is married to Fernando Falco, Marques de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family. Apparently loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of beauty queen Estee Lauder, who started selling face creams in 1946 with help of chemist uncle. Company now peddles 27 brands, including Clinique, Aveda, Bobbi Brown, La Mer. Leonard took company public 1995; son William now chief executive. Brother Ronald (see) owns big stakes in Central European Media, Israeli TV; served as ambassador to Austria under Reagan. Paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait, one of the largest sums ever paid for a painting. Longtime Wharton supporters partnered with business school to design personalized executive education program for Estee Lauder employees.
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; listed 20% of Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation in London last November. Native of Kyrgyzstan studied literature and became one of the youngest deans of a university in Kyrgyzstan at the age of 26. Moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded generic drug maker Apotex in 1974. Has since relentlessly battled big pharma over exclusivity patents, gradually building the company into the largest Canadian-owned drugmaker, with an estimated $1 billion in revenues. Locked in court fight with relatives who allege they are owed a piece of the family fortune. Sherman filed countersuit, dismissing their claims.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minority partner in Russian oil tycoon Roman Abramovich's Millhouse LLC; firm created 2001 to manage assets owned by Abramovich and his partners. Duo founded oil-trading outfit Runicom early 1990s. Took control of oil firm Sibneft 1995; sold stake to Russian state-owned gas monopoly Gazprom for $13.1 billion a decade later. Agreed to buy 41% of Evraz, Russia's largest steelmaker, in 2006. Took drugmaker Pharmstandard public last May. Other investments: Russian meat processor, Moscow real estate. Abramovich gave Shvidler his yacht 2006; Le Grand Bleu (The Big Blue) came complete with 65-man crew, helicopter, aquarium, speedboat. Boat was originally purchased from Paul Allen (see).

name: Billionaires
bio:
Like former business partner and fellow billionaire Lev Kvetnoi, was born in
a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the same school of athletics,
the Institute of Physical Culture, but later got a degree in teaching. In
early 1990s, worked for Moscow's MontazhSpetsBank. With Kvetnoi joined
fellow billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metallurgical business; Kvetnoi was
sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. Later
Usmanov joined the two firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest
conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. Became a member
of the Russian parliament's lower house in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bank clerk used profits from real estate deal to open bank in 1966. Today Public Bank has 14,000 employees, 241 branches, including 66 in Hong Kong and China and nine in Cambodia. Enjoys soccer and photography. Donates to medical institutions supporting heart and dialysis research and to the Malaysian Nature Society to fund planting of trees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns major stake in Saudi Islamic banking giant Al Rajhi Bank. Three brothers also hold substantial shares. Other lines of business include cement and agriculture. The secretive family issued a rare public statement after a Wall Street Journal article was published in July 2007 about bank's alleged role in supporting Islamic extremism. Brothers denied the allegations and stated they "unequivocally" condemn terrorism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sam (d. 1971), founded Distillers Corp. 1924, after emigrating from Russia to Montreal. Made fortune smuggling whiskey over U.S. border during Prohibition. Acquired Joseph E. Seagram & Sons 1928. Edgar Sr. took over U.S. operations, brother Charles ran business in Canada. Diversified into other brands: Absolut (vodka), Tropicana (juice). Also stake in DuPont. Son Edgar Jr. staged ill-fated entrance into Hollywood: sold off juice, nylons businesses, bought MCA/Universal for $5.7 billion 1995. Rest of Seagram empire snatched up by Vivendi for $34 billion 2000. Entertainment companies lost family billions; Edgar Jr. now runs Warner Music Group. Edgar Sr. succeeded by son Matthew as head of World Jewish Congress last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap-metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil. The resulting conglomerate, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille, sold its stake in media giant Bertelsmann in 2006. Known as a workaholic who claims he'll never retire, Baron Frere is always on the verge of a new business venture. In 2007 CNP's subsidiary Suez announced a planned mega-merger with French utility Gaz de France, which when completed, will result in a $123.3 billion (market cap) European energy giant called GDF Suez. In 2006, partnered with good friend and billionaire Bernard Arnault to start a joint investment group concentrating on European companies. Already owns two French vineyards with the LVMH mogul.

name: Billionaires
bio: Run his real estate and private banking business from Geneva. Eldest son of the slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri leaves the political games to brother Saad (see), also a billionaire. Bahaa's Horizon Development is planning a $5 billion mini city in the Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea. Close pal of the House of Saud is also beginning construction on a $300 billion development in northwestern Saudi Arabian city of Tabouk, designed to lure 700,000 international dwellers. Chairs two soccer clubs in Lebanon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of beauty queen Estee Lauder, who started selling face creams in 1946 with help of chemist uncle. Company now peddles 27 brands, including Clinique, Aveda, Bobbi Brown, La Mer. Brother Leonard Lauder (see) took company public 1995; son William now chief executive. Ronald owns big stakes in Central European Media, Israeli TV; served as ambassador to Austria under Reagan. Paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait, one of the largest sums ever paid for a painting. Longtime Wharton supporters partnered with business school to design personalized executive education program for Estee Lauder employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor (products include semiconductors and electromechanical components). Supports the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second-generation Greek immigrant studied petroleum engineering at Texas A&M before founding Mitchell Energy & Development 1946. Wildcatter made fortune in north Texas gas fields; sold ground to Devon Energy in 2001 for $3.5 billion. Invested proceeds in real estate: Bald Head Island in North Carolina, hotels in Galveston, Tex. Nature enthusiast donated $35 million to alma mater to develop physics department.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained physicist, he and four former IBM colleagues founded German software company SAP in 1972. Retired from the company in 1998 and last May stepped down from SAP's supervisory board. Devotes most of his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, dedicated to pursuing whatever scientific research and cultural projects capture his imagination; such as sponsoring a communications and computer camp for blind and vision-impaired youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esprit's primary sourcing agent eventually bought rights to the clothing brand in Europe and Asia; listed Esprit Far East on Hong Kong stock exchange in 1993. Stepped down as chief executive in 2003; now non-executive Director. Has sold almost $2 billion worth of Esprit stock in past few years but still holds stake worth $1.3 billion. Married to former Taiwanese movie star Lin Ching Hsia (Brigitte Lin). Reportedly an amateur paleontologist

name: Billionaires
bio: Identical twin brothers continue to make news with their vast property and retail holdings. In June, via their property arm Ellerman, the brothers doubled their stake in Intercontinental Hotels Group. Since then, the stock tanked-- losing 50% of its value-- on worries over the economy in the U.S. where most of IHG's Holiday Inns are located. The retail side also came up negative this year with their Littlewoods home shopping company posting a loss. Brothers' main media interest is the U.K.'s conservative Telegraph newspaper.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In 1990s created Russia's largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. Later
invested in cement, purchasing the Stern Cement plants and the cement
business of fellow billionaire Elena Baturina's Inteko. Now his Eurocement
Group, with 16 plants, is the country's largest producer, with 40% of the
market (and up to 80% in some regions). After purchasing the Inteko plants,
was able to nearly double cement prices, dramatically improving profits.
Russia's antimonopoly authority sued Eurocement but failed to prove that the
price hike was illegal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built riches on a marketing surprise. Met partner Gary Burrell at AlliedSignal, left and founded Garmin in 1989 to make navigation devices for aviation, boating, using newfangled Global Positioning System. Original office: 2 folding chairs and a card table. But U.S. Army servicemen loved GPS during Gulf war (though Garmin never had a military contract), and now in Iraq. In 1998 duo realized GPS could sell to directions-starved drivers on U.S. highways, too. Spouses stop bickering. Building third plant in Taiwan. Kao: Garmin chief executive; donated $17.5 million to U. of Tennessee for science and engineering research.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
Former intelligence officer, banker and, from 2003 to 2007, member of
Russia's lower house. Fortune mainly comes from his stakes in banking and
insurance companies, and in Russian airline Aeroflot. A vociferous critic of
the authorities. Has frequently clashed with Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov,
skewering him in particular for the city's intractable traffic problem (Luzhkov responded by asking the senator to oversee the issue). Has also
suggested he'd run for mayor. Nevertheless, keeps a substantial part of his
funds in state companies: the government may be a bad business partner, but
it's the largest in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: His tour outfit Globus & Cosmos was founded in 1928 by father, Antonio, with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano where Sergio also owns a portfolio of lakeside property. Today Globus tours escort travelers seeking adventure in Europe, Africa and Asia. Real wealth comes from family's investments, largely in the bond market. Also owns a series of charter airline businesses. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter, a yacht (Lady Marina) and a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods&#39 day-to-day operations in the 1990s after family feud; remains vice chairman and still has one-third stake in the world’s largest producer of frozen french fries. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods 1995, where son  Michael is chief. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and National Gallery of Canada. Financial Post Business Magazine gave McCain a lifetime achievement award in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former biochemistry student and soccer player successfully transformed his family’s fledgling fertilizer company into a $125 million chemicals business. Later began bankrolling films for U.S. directors before going on to produce such classics as Pretty Woman, The War of the Roses, Fight Club and Mr. and Mrs. Smith. Enjoyed a stellar year thanks to savvy currency trades (he bet against the dollar) and unlikely blockbusters produced by New Regency film outfit, jointly owned by Milchan, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp. and James Packer’s Publishing & Broadcasting. The Regency-backed Alvin and the Chipmunks has so far grossed $340 million worldwide, more than five times its budget. Milchan celebrated the windfall by jumping off the 709-foot-tall Bloukrans Bridge in South Africa, the world’s highest commercially-operated bungee jump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transformed struggling Univision into world's leading Spanish-language broadcaster. Bought channel for $550 million in 1992 with Latin American partners; sold in March to a Haim Saban (see) group for $13.7 billion. "Jerry" began as talent agent for MCA. With Norman Lear (All in the Family), formed Embassy Communications; sold programming interests to Coca-Cola for $485 million 1985. Press-shy mogul one of largest landholders in Malibu. Lifelong Republican, campaign finance co-chair for John McCain.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Set up mid- to high-end real estate developer, Guangzhou R&F Properties, with Hong Kong partner Li Sze Lim in 1994 after starting his career as a hotel industry executive. Zhang is its cochairman and president. R&F, now traded in Hong Kong, plans Shanghai listing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall developer famous for bringing snow skiing to the Dubai desert continues to expand his dominant retail brand, MAF Holding, across the Middle East. Has mega-malls under construction in Bahrain, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Lebanon and Yemen. Company's joint venture with French hypermarket chain Carrefour has created the fastest-growing grocery chain in the Gulf, with 25 locations and $1.9 billion in sales in 2006. Built up reputation in mall industry after splitting business empire with brother, fellow billionaire Abdulla, in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first apparel store in Barcelona 1984. Today his Mango group, known for making reasonably priced trendy women's apparel, has more than 900 stores in 89 countries and $1.78 billion in sales. Also has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups; sits on its board. Otherwise little known about him other than that his family came to Spain from Turkey in 1960s, that he is married with children and apparently an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968; brother Robert split same year. Bass Enterprises Production Co. pumps estimated 8 million barrels of oil and gas a year. Sold stake in firm to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Now looking for oil in harsh waters of maritime Canada. Lee invests with Sid; billions of dollars held in Cayman Islands investment accounts. Guest at 2007 White House dinner for Queen Elizabeth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968; brother Robert split that same year. Bass Enterprises Production Co. pumps an estimated 8 million barrels of oil and gas a year. Sold stake in firm to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Now looking for oil in harsh waters of maritime Canada. Sid: known to invest with brother Lee; billions of dollars held in Cayman Islands investment accounts. Pals of President George W. Bush; guest at 2007 White House dinner for Queen Elizabeth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family's shoe business. Turned it into Europe's largest shoe retailer Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH. Also owns U.S. retail chains Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. Son Heinrich runs daily operations. Committed philanthropist, Deichmann regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started investing as a Harvard undergrad; read article in Forbes about Home Shopping Network, became interested in the stock market. Managing $1 million of family's, friend's money by senior year. Convinced by investor Frank Meyer to move to Chicago; founded Citadel Investment Group 1990 with Meyer's money. His hedge funds said to have averaged 20% net of fees annually. Wife, Anne Dias, worked for investing legend Julian Robertson; runs Aragon Global hedge fund. Paid $80 million for Jasper Johns painting "False Start."
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Kenneth Hendricks, who died in December after fall from home construction site. Kenneth: Wisconsin native dropped out of high school, later joined family roofing business. Founded first construction supply operation 1982. Today ABC Supply largest supplier of roofing and siding materials to professional contractors in the U.S. with 404 stores. Diane: met Kenneth at age 21 through mutual love for real estate. Remains positive despite housing market downturn.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, three brothers (Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang) and sister Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led him and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in 140 year old German shipping co, Germanisches Lloyd. Raises horses at his stud farm; races his yacht, All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to steel-and-coke fortune diversified family firm into real estate. Early backer of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers (venture capital), Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (leveraged buyouts); co-owner of downtown Pittsburgh's PPG Place. Family private in business matters. Prominent Pittsburgh philanthropist gives via various family foundations; has donated $20 million to U. of Pittsburgh for cancer research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Harry started developing New York City real estate 1901. Father, Sam, became paragon of mass-market home building: "I produced an apartment every 16 minutes." Richard studied at Amherst College, joined family business early 1970s; became chairman after dad died in 2003. Now runs company with 2 sons, Harrison and Jamie. Portfolio includes 5,000 apartments at LeFrak City in Queens, N.Y., 7-million-square-foot-commercial, residential, retail complex in Newport, N.J. Expanding Newport project; $10 billion "mini-city" will soon include a new office tower, 429-room Westin hotel and 4,500 more apartments and condos. On board of the American Museum of Natural History.

name: Billionaires
bio: Currency speculator made big news in 2007 when he paid $1 billion for an almost 10% stake in troubled investment bank Bear Stearns.  Nicknamed “the boxer” on Wall Street in part because his name recalls that of legendary heavyweight fighter Joe Louis but also because of his dealmaking style. Main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies; sold Hot Spot FX, its currency trading business, for $80 million last year. Owns several homes including one at Lyford Cay; one at Isleworth, an Orlando golf community he bought out of receivership 1990s; also land in Patagonia. Developing 6,700-acre medical community in Lake Nona, near Orlando, and resort in the Bahamas, Albany Golf & Beach, with friends Tiger Woods, Ernie Els. Born in London’s East End, Lewis made initial fortune expanding family’s catering business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls Sany Heavy Industry, one of China's largest nongovernment makers of construction equipment. Liang made waves when he tried to block U.S. private investment firm Carlyle from investing in one of his rivals, arguing that it was a matter of national security. In September 2007 Sany announced its own high-profile foreign investment: a $30 million assembly plant in Peachtree City, Georgia, the company's first North American facility.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then husband Amancio Ortega make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. Home business became one of world most successful apparel manufacturers, Inditex, which also owns Zara retail stores. Couple divorced years ago, but Mera still holds 7% stake in the now $12 billion (sales) business. Also got $600 million in cash at time of Inditex's public offering. Has invested the cash in Spanish film production outfit; marine fish farming group; a company that looks for cancer treatment in compounds found in the sea; and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Has received various awards for her contributions to Spanish society via her Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Native New Yorker studied at NYU, then Harvard M.B.A. "J.P" landed job at Odyssey Partners, private equity and hedge fund operation run by Leon Levy and Jack Nash. Became managing director in mergers and acquisitions at Bear Stearns before founding Paulson & Co. in 1995. Made billions betting against the housing market last year; funds gained $15 billion. Predicts more carnage to come. Also betting against credit cards, auto loans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oklahoma native studied geology at Oklahoma State; graduated 1951, worked for Phillips Petroleum for 3 years before striking out on own. Founded Mesa Petroleum 1956 with $2,500. Produced plenty of oil and gas, lots of debt. Sold to Richard Rainwater (see); made name with attempted hostile takeovers of Gulf, Phillips, Unocal. His BP Capital hedge fund made $1 billion in profit in 2006 betting on crude oil, natural gas, Canadian tar sands. Predicts his next fortune will be made in water; owns vast water rights in Texas Panhandle. Also plans to build world's largest wind farm. Staple on Republican giving circuit has donated over $500 million to charity in past 3 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four brothers, helped turn family's property management firm into leading real estate developer in Mumbai. After family split in 1996, moved into building offices, malls and IT parks branded as Mindspace. Also has four hotels in Mumbai, three of them managed by Marriott. In 2006 listed Ishaan, a property fund, on London's AIM. Keeps low profile. Sons Ravi and Neel, who help him run operations are more visible.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of middle-class wholesaler studied at Stanford; brief stint at Goldman Sachs before leaving to run Bass family's $50 million portfolio in 1970, lost money first 2 years. Acquired large stake in Disney 1984; went solo 2 years later to manage personal investments. Cofounded Columbia Hospital Corp. 1987, merged with Tom Frist's (see) Hospital Corporation of America 1994. Made billions betting on oil; claims to be the largest individual shareholder of Chevron, ConocoPhillips. Part owner of Pebble Beach golf course.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Al, started storage and transfer service 1938 from converted horse stable; dropped storage element 1944. Don took over trucking firm in 1983 after Wharton M.B.A. Early adopter of satellite tracking technology, transportation logistics. Became one of nation's largest haulers by buying up competitors. Expanding internationally: China, Czech Republic, Mexico. Director emeritus of pro football's Green Bay Packers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood's hugest hitmaker raised in Arizona, rejected by best film schools. Enrolled, then dropped out of Cal State Long Beach. First movie, Duel, made for TV. Third movie, Jaws, started unparalleled run of blockbusters (E.T., Indiana Jones movies, Jurassic Park, many more) and epic dramas (Schindler's List, Saving Private Ryan). Produced Clint Eastwood's WWII epics, Letters from Iwo Jima and Flags of Our Fathers 2006; twin bill cost $70 million to make, grossed $175 million worldwide, despite wide critical acclaim. Working on 3 videogames for Electronic Arts. Pulled out of artistic director spot at Olympic Games over Darfur conflict.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Became one of the leading marketers of replacement joints. Public 1979. Aging, active baby boomers boosting bottom line: net profits soared 21% to $778 million in 2006. Third generation controls 30% of company's shares. Ronda only family member to sit on board; director of Greenleaf, first trust-only bank in Michigan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his $1 billion (sales) Olav Thon Gruppen owns 400 properties in Norway and 20 abroad. The portfolio includes shopping malls (53 of them), office buildings, retail stores, hotels (6,700 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs. Also makes raw ingredients for soap and cosmetics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Brooklyn developer borrowed heavily, built big, lived large, became a billionaire during 1980s. Eviscerated in 1990 real estate crash; stayed flamboyant, embraced reality TV. Now other builders pay him millions to license "Trump" brand. Despite looming housing woes, the Donald's retail, office and hotel business is up. Recently signed Gucci in record lease in New York's Trump Tower; Trump Chicago hotel opened January. Annually disputes FORBES' net worth estimate: "I'm worth $7 billion."

name: Billionaires
bio: Once China's richest person, Yung is a member of country's most celebrated business families (late father Rong Yiren was nation's vice president). Yung's main business interest is CITIC Pacific, a Hong Kong-listed conglomerate with investments in steel, Cathay Pacific Airways, real estate; also mining rights in Australia. Spun-off Citic Telecom. Has personal stake in mining giant Anglo American. Lives in Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beijing property developer. She and husband, Pan Shiyi, who are SOHO China's chief executive and chairman, respectively, are one of China's best-known business couples, renowned for their stylish buildings. (Pan transferred shares to Zhang, prior to listing.) Zhang got start at international firms Goldman Sachs, Travelers Group.
title: Cofounder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Soho China Ltd.', 'uri': 'companies/soho-china', 'title': 'Cofounder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime go-between for major oil companies and state-owned oil fields in the Gulf settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing the late Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Much of his fortune is in commercial real estate and a healthy international stock and investment portfolio. He is in a protracted legal struggle against French oil giant Total, accusing its former directors of fraud. Also wired $3.5 million in April 2007 to Chicago developer and pal Antoin (Tony) Rezko, the Syrian-born businessman who helped raise money for Sen. Barack Obama's early political campaigns and is now on trial for fraud and extortion charges. Pet charitable cause: gives money to grassroots organizations that repatriate young boys forced to race camels outside Pakistan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Verlagsgruppe Bauer, mass-media company founded by his grandfather 1875. The $2.6 billion (sales) group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and Kochen & Geniessen (cooking), to magazines like Neue Post and Das Neue Blatt. U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and InTouch. Sells in 14 countries including Mexico, Russia and China. Is now one of Britain's largest radio producers after acquiring various divisions from British media company Emap.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings, Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto, all billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. Now deputy chairman of the $2.5 billion (sales) clothing company that sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at more than 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Is also deputy chair of Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, formerly Autostrade, one of the world's largest toll road companies; and Autogrill restaurants, which serve nearly 900 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 42 countries. Formerly headed production for Benetton Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Carlo, also billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.5 billion (sales) clothing company sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at more than 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Chairs Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, formerly Autostrade, one of the world's largest toll road companies; and Autogrill restaurants, which serve nearly 900 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 42 countries. A sports enthusiast, Gilberto promotes Benetton's sponsorships of rugby, basketball and volleyball. Through Fondazione Benetton, he created La Ghirada, an indoor-and-outdoor sports complex with beach volleyball, golf and swimming in Treviso, Italy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings, Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto, also billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.5 billion (sales) clothing company sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at more than 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Is also a director of Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, formerly Autostrade, one of the world's largest toll road companies; and Autogrill restaurants, which serve nearly 900 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 42 countries. It was Giuliana who started the family's fashion business, knitting sweaters that brother Luciano would then peddle by bicycle. Originally sold under the Tres Jolie label, before eventually renaming it Benetton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto, also billionaires, formed Benetton Group in 1965. Now chairman of the $2.5 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at more than 5,000 stores in 120 countries. The family also owns a large chunk of Atlantia, formerly Autostrade, one of the world's largest toll road companies; and Autogrill restaurants, which serve nearly 900 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 42 countries. Luciano ran Benetton Group for 40 years. Son Alessandro, a former Goldman Sachs analyst, is now executive vice chair of the board and potential heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother, Ingeburg, and four brothers, Gunter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang (see all), inherited a fortune from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led her and her older brother Gunter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding - now Maxingvest AG - to their mother and other three brothers and mother for estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now she and her brother own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in 140 year old German shipping co, Germanisches Lloyd.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Enron president left firm 1996; uncomfortable with "asset-light" strategy. Bought Enron pipeline business with college chum William Morgan. More pipe from ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Shell; added Terasen for $5.6 billion 2005. Today operates 38,000 miles of pipeline, more than 150 terminals. Recently took company private for $22 billion with management and investors; deal backed by Goldman Sachs and billionaire Fayez Sarofim. Renamed company Knight Inc. Flies coach on company time; fly fisherman.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Math major at Chinese University of Hong Kong cofounded developer R&F Properties in China with Chinese billionaire Zhang Li. Holds stakes in brokerage firm Haitong Securities, KWG Property Holding. Reportedly paid $200,000 to buy a white truffle at auction.

name: Billionaires
bio: Repulsed by smelly feet, he came up with an idea in 1994 to put tiny holes in the bottoms of shoes to release sweat. Initially tried to sell the concept to Nike, which turned him down. So started his own brand, Geox, now publicly traded. Geox’s iconic soles are everywhere-even the Pope is a customer-but Moretti Polegato has his heart set on expansion into the apparel arena. Enjoys his success: He owns two Lamborghinis, a Ferrari 360 Modena Spider, five Arabian horses (one named Geox) and six antique Moto Guzzi motorcycles. Before starting his shoe business, ran family’s prestigious Villa Sandi winery.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father's death in 2005 became sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, makers of Werther's Original, Merci, Riesen, Toffifee and nimm2, among other well-known candies. Fourth generation of his family to run the $1.9 billion (sales) group. Company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dyslexic fisherman reportedly told by schoolteacher he&#39d never amount to anything. Started his fortune selling fish off a single boat in Seattle; returned to Norway and built up fleet—and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Lived large with a giant yacht and his own Boeing jet but nearly drove his shipping empire into the ground by 2003. Sold yacht, paid off debt and has turned around his businesses, especially Aker ASA, a maritime conglomerate that operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood and shipping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Middle son of Orascom conglomerate founder Onsi Sawiris. Samih runs family's Orascom empire real estate and hotel division which owns and operates hotels in Egypt, Jordan, Oman, UAE and Switzerland. Also has plans in pipeline to develop prime property in Mauritius and Morocco. After record growth in 2006, hotel group's Ebitda for first half of 2007 was up 105%. Recently established Orascom Housing Communities in Cairo dedicated to developing low-income housing. Fluent in German, has engineering degree from Berlin Institute of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year stepped down as chief executive of United Overseas Bank, the largest in Singapore, after three decades at the helm. Remains chairman; son Wee Ee Chong is chief executive. Not just a banker, his property companies have been the largest land buyers in Singapore over the past three years. Plays tennis three times a week with friends he has known for more than 50 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Uncle to Mashreq chairman and fellow billionaire Abdul Aziz, Saif Al Ghurair oversees the retail and manufacturing-centered Al Ghurair Group, which includes some of Dubai's swankiest shopping centers. Region's strong market for retailing has helped fuel Group's recent expansion. Family's steel subsidiary recently broke ground on a new plant in Abu Dhabi. Five sons all involved in the business, son Majed is chief executive and was named a Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Gulf Bank, Kuwait's second-largest and fastest-growing commercial bank; shares were up over 100% in 2007. Joined older brother Kutayba, also a billionaire,  at family trading company, Alghanim Industries, in the 1980s after finishing studies at UC, Berkeley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother to Gulf Bank Chairman, Bassam, also a billionaire, Kutayba started at father's trading conglomerate Alghanim Industries in 1970s after graduating from UC, Berkeley. As Alghanim's chairman, oversees group operations in consumer goods, auto trading, shipping and financial services spanning four continents. Son Omar is now chief executive. In 2002 opened office in Guangzhou, China; is now largest importer of Chinese products in the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband and wife founded Mediterranean Shipping Co. in 1970 as a small ship operator. Today MSC is the world's second-largest container shipper with 362 container vessels. MSC serves six continents and calls at 270 ports through 170 liner services. The company's cruise ship arm, MSC Cruises, boasts authentic Italian cuisine, an Italian crew and ship christenings by cinema legend Sophia Loren.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ties with older brother Chung Mong-Koo for title of Korea's richest this year. The youngest son of Hyundai's late founder, Chung is the largest shareholder of world's largest shipbuilder, Hyundai Heavy Industries, whose shares have more than doubled in the past year. But it's politics, not business, that is Chung's passion: a 5-term national assemblyman, he ran unsuccessfully for president in 2002. Member of FIFA's executive committee. Said to have close ties to newly elected president of Korea, a former Hyundai executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hyundai Motor chairman is focusing his attention on the automaker's move into the luxury sedan market. It's a good distraction from his previous legal problems, in which Chung was convicted of embezzling some $100 million of company money. Only spent a few months in jail, however, before an appeals court judge suspended the sentence, noting Chung's importance to the Korean economy; Chung agreed to donate $1 billion over several years to Korean society.

name: Billionaires
bio: With David Bonderman, cofounded private equity behemoth Texas Pacific Group. With KKR and Goldman Sachs, agreed to buy power company TXU for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt last year. Duo managed money for the Bass family; split to start TPG 1992. Bought Continental Airlines for $66 million; later sold for $640 million profit. Other hits: Burger King, J. Crew. With Leon Black's Apollo Management, paid $27.8 billion in cash and assumed debt for Harrah's Entertainment casino company. Both prefer complex deals others shy away from. Tinkered with idea of selling stake in company to outside investors last spring; put on hold after markets turned downward last summer. Duo are equal partners in TPG. Coulter: Studied at Dartmouth, then Stanford M.B.A. Runs firm's daily operations, makes most of firm's investment decisions. Trustee at Stanford University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited chunk of Wal-Mart stock from father James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail giant with brother Sam 1962. Husband Stanley (see) made fortune developing commercial and retail properties. High school sports star owner of pro hockey’s Colorado Avalanche, basketball’s Denver Nuggets. Also stakes in football’s St. Louis Rams, English soccer squad Arsenal; 5 ranches across Montana, Wyoming, California, Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Duke grad cofounded Chesapeake Energy in 1989 with former rival Tom Ward (see). Oklahoma company now 3rd-largest natural gas producer in U.S. Diversified: venture capital, hedge funds, commodities trading, real estate. Owns 18% stake in pro basketball's Seattle Sonics. Collects wine and maps; enjoys ranching and farming.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Merieux, a former laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur. Founded BioMerieux in 1974, a company that had roots in his father's first laboratory, Institut Merieux, and an interest by Becton Dickinson. Now chairman of the board. Their biotech outfit specializes in the diagnosis of bacteria in the human body and infectious diseases like HIV and tuberculosis. Eldest son Rodolphe was killed in 1996 at the age of 27 when TWA Flight 800 crashed over Long Island. Second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over from his father, died of cardiac failure in July 2006 at age 39. Son Alexandre, 32, is a board member.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven (see), left father's real estate firm 1979. Founded Equity Group Holdings. Bought up small manufacturing companies during junk-finance frenzy 1980s. Acquired near-bankrupt REIT, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher Corp.; named company after Montana stream where 2 once fished for trout. Public 1987. Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years. Recently acquired water treatment products firm ChemTreat for $435 million. Mitchell a trustee of National Gallery of Art; personal collection includes contemporary art, photography.

name: Billionaires
bio: This scion of a Middle Eastern banking family cut financial ties with his younger brother, Joseph (also a billionaire), in mid-2006. Joseph bought Moise's stake in Banco Safra, Brazil's tenth-largest bank, as well as his stakes in the brothers' banking holdings elsewhere in the world, including Luxembourg and New York City, for an undisclosed sum. Moise still owns shares in Brazilian pulp and paper maker Aracruz Celulose. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother, Edmond Safra, had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife, Lily, also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shanghai's richest resident. Got a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the academic cradle of China's software industry, Zhejiang University, and created a huge following for his Zhuhai Giant Hi-Tech Group in 1991, based on the popularity of a single videogame. Zhuhai Giant collapsed under the weight of massive debt incurred for a 70-story skyscraper that was never built. His recent return to games through an online services provider he founded, ZTgame, has given new life to his entrepreneurial reputation. ZTgame's lineup includes racy and sensational fare said to be more suitable for adults than adolescents; it is known for unconventional marketing. He recently listed the company on NYSE Euronext. Almost half his fortune comes from stakes in financial institutions China Minsheng Banking and Huaxia Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to the Campbell Soup fortune once tried unsuccessfully to pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic life. Not much has been heard from him since he moved to Ireland in 1994, reportedly to avoid U.S. taxes. Sold his Campbell stake in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Victor, heads Li & Fung, the global outsourcing giant that supplies clothes and accessories to such retailers as Disney and Bed Bath & Beyond. Made several acquisitions last year, including Peter Black International, shoe supplier to U.K. retailer Marks & Spencer, and Tommy Hilfiger’s sourcing operations. Links American and European consumers to factories in 40 countries. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s. William is managing director, Victor chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard Business School grad became friends with Warren Buffett in 1962. Early investor in Berkshire Hathaway; today owns 10,000 shares worth $1.4 billion. Founded investment advisory firm First Manhattan 1964; today assets exceed $14 billion. Joined Berkshire board of directors in 2003. Shuns the billionaire lifestyle. Swimmer, serves on board of American Museum of Natural History in New York City.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant married Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson (d. 1983). Inherited 36 million J&J shares, expansive Jasna Polana mansion in New Jersey.
