Spent $17 million in legal fees battling stepchildren over husband’s estate. Converted estate into lavish golf club, moved to Monaco. Active collector of old masters paintings and furniture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wife Ann (see) inherited chunk of Wal-Mart stock from father James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail giant with brother Sam 1962. Stanley made fortune developing commercial and retail properties. High school sports star owner of pro hockey’s Colorado Avalanche, basketball’s Denver Nuggets. Also stakes in football’s St. Louis Rams, English soccer squad Arsenal; 5 ranches across Montana, Wyoming, California, Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbaev owns large stake in Halyk, Kazakhstan's third-largest bank, which went public in 2006; wife, Dinara Kulibaeva, also owns shares and is a billionaire. Recently removed from deputy chairman's seat at Samruk, which oversees the government's stakes in the energy sector, reportedly on orders from father-in-law. Moscow-educated economist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second daughter of Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbaev. With husband Timur Kulibaev, also a billionaire, owns shares in Halyk, Kazakhstan's third-largest bank, which went public in 2006. Executive director of education foundation named after her father.

name: Billionaires
bio: With three brothers, Liu started Hope Group 1982 with about $120; eventually became China's second-largest animal feed maker. In 1999 restructured into four entities, each owned by a brother. Now runs New Hope Group, with interests in milk and meat as well as feed. Also has stake in China Minsheng Banking. Brother Liu Yongxing is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attended Lehigh U.; worked for aluminum company Alcoa. Bought Chevy dealership. Started Penske Corp. 1969; distributor for GM's Detroit Diesel. Expanded into truck leasing 1970s, diesel engines 1988. Acquired, became chief executive of second-largest U.S. auto dealer United Auto Group 1999. Company renamed Penske Auto Group last July. Currently controls more than 300 retail auto dealerships and 26 collision repair centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of visionary oil baron John D. Rockefeller focusing on where his fortune will go after he is gone. Pledged $100 million living endowment to Rockefeller University in 2005. Bequeathed another $225 million to Rockefeller Brothers Fund a year later. Lifetime charitable donations approaching $1 billion. Concerns: sustainable development, higher education, medical research. Grandfather, John D., fueled American industrial revolution via Standard Oil. David: former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank. Beetle enthusiast has one of largest collections in world: 160,000 specimens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Keyence Corp., a sensormaker. Strong sellers include measurement and control devices for factories. Sales have doubled in the past four years and the company plans a stock split this spring.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minnesota farm boy paid way through college working at a print shop; persuaded owner to sell for $2 million over 10 years. Paid off debt early, built Taylor Corp. on invitations, stationery, books. Chairman; sold portion to daughter last year. Runs budding agribusiness on his Iowa and Minnesota farmland: chickens, liquefied eggs. Former Republican state senator owns pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Biggest builder of apartments in Australia, as founder of Meriton
Apartments. Is focusing on a holding strategy, renting out rather than
selling new apartments because of flat Sydney market. Born in China to
Russian parents who fled the country during the Bolshevik Revolution.
Learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a
builder, at work sites in Tianjin, China; immigrated to Australia at age 28.
Drove a taxi and owned a milk run before being the first to spot the trend
toward the inner-city high-rise apartments that dominate Sydney1s skyline.
Owns three Bentleys; on alternate days his license plates read HOT1 and HOT2
(for his initials) and OSCAR1 (his middle name).

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2006 backed Lakshmi Mittal in his successful attempt to merge pan-European steel group Arcelor with Mittal Steel to form ArcelorMittal, world's largest steel company, with $88.5 billion in sales. Now holds 3% of new entity and is one of the biggest shareholders along with Mittal and Romain Zaleski (see both). Press shy, reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. Owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce, in south of Spain, on which he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Often called the Siberian hermit; rarely leaves remote town of Surgut.
Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller,
he was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas at 33. In early 1990s
privatized the company with his fellow managers; it's now Russia's
fourth-largest oil concern but considered one of its least transparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns more than 50% of Caltagirone SpA, an industrial holding company with cement, real estate and media interests. Subsidiary Caltagirone Editore controls Italy&#39s leading free daily newspaper, Leggo, with daily distribution of over 1 million copies. Dubbed Franco the Taciturn by media for his quiet ways. Son Francesco Jr. is president of Caltagirone&#39s cement subsidiary, Cementir. Also personally holds a stake in Acea SpA, Italy’s main water-and-energy provider.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bartender launched early Internet audio and video portal Broadcast.com with Indiana University buddy Todd Wagner. Sold to Yahoo in 1999 for $5.7 billion. Used proceeds to buy pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks from Ross Perot (see) in 2000 for $285 million; team has been to playoffs every season since. Famous for courtside antics; has accumulated $1.5 million in fines for mouthing off to NBA referees. Vying to buy pro baseball's Chicago Cubs from Tribune Co. Building media empire: owns film production, distribution, theater firms. Spends spare time writing blog. Recently competed on ABC's Dancing with the Stars.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Poland's largest leasing business, Europejski Fundusz Leasingowy, in 1991. Sold his stake 10 years later to French bank Credit Agricole for $280 million. Since then has concentrated on building a banking, insurance and real estate conglomerate. His publicly listed bank Getin Holding is considering spinning off operations abroad into a separate entity called Getin International; also rumored to be negotiating selloff of entire company to foreign buyer. Last year took public his Noble Bank, which targets high-net-worth Poles, and his property arm, LC Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Born in Kazakhstan, where his Ingush family had been deported after World
War II. Later became president of state oil company Slavneft. In 2002 was
dismissed before privatization, but was able to return to big oil: Over four
years Swiss trader Glencore helped him buy a number of small Russian oil
firms which he united into RussNeft. At the end of 2006 was accused of
violating the terms of his oil licenses and failure to pay taxes (Gutseriev
denies the charges). In 2007 had to sell RussNeft and move to London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stockbroker's son partnered with frat brother to start cable company 1963. Duo split 1981. Later built Continental Cablevision into nation's largest privately held cable concern. Sold to US West for $11 billion in 1996 on condition company remain in Boston. Outfit promptly relocated to Denver; took company back, renamed MediaOne. Sold to AT&T for an astounding $58 billion 3 years later--5 times the old price even though he had only increased firm's subscriber base 30% to 5.5 million homes. Today invests via Pilot House Associates; owns $200 million stake in Energy Transfer Equity.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio:
Son of a Moscow department store director; graduated from the Moscow
Aviation Institute and set up a computer-trading firm in late 1980s. Later
became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and through
privatization bought local fertilizer producer Azot. Renamed it Akron and
made it the basis for his chemicals empire, now publicly traded. A
passionate collector of paintings by Russian artists of Jewish origin,
chairs Russian Jewish Congress. Spends most of his time at his mansion in
Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built Sun TV into India's biggest regional broadcaster. Merged Gemini TV and Udaya TV into Sun. Had falling-out with powerful granduncle M. Karunanidhi, chief minister of southern state of Tamil Nadu, over story in Maran's paper on granduncle's sons. Karunanidhi, whose wife sold Maran her Sun stake three years ago, now sponsors rival channel. Brother Dayanidhi forced out as minister for communications and IT last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Lebanese Prime Minister founded telecom company Investcom with brother at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. Thrived in challenging, underpenetrated markets, including Sudan, Liberia, Yemen. Sold company in June 2006 to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion. Served as Lebanon's Minister of Public Works before his brief stint as PM in 2005. With brother and business partner, Taha, recently funded public policy studies fellowship at University of Chicago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded telecom company Investcom with brother at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. Company thrived in challenging, underpenetrated markets, including Ghana, Syria, Sudan. In June 2006 sold company to South Africa's MTN for $5.5 billion. Got start in construction in Abu Dhabi in the late 1960s. Trained as civil engineer, helped found Arabian Construction Company. Later sold out to focus on telecom sector. With brother and fellow billionaire, Najib, recently funded public policy studies fellowship at University of Chicago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Internet entrepreneur has run online shopping mall Rakuten, Japan’s sixth most popular Web destination, for the past decade. Last year renovated a former Sony office building in seedy bayside Tokyo into a sleek new headquarters tower and moved his staff there from pricey digs in the Roppongi neighborhood. Mikitani is reported to have said that he is making money on the move even if he gives his 2,500 employees free meals at the office. Launching Rakuten’s e-commerce business in Taiwan this year, aiming to run 3,000 virtual shops there within three years.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell (see), left father's real estate firm 1979. Founded Equity Group Holdings. Bought up small manufacturing companies during junk-finance frenzy 1980s. Acquired near-bankrupt REIT, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher Corp.; named company after Montana stream where 2 once fished for trout. Public 1987. Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years. Recently acquired water treatment products firm ChemTreat for $435 million.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Banking maven studied economics at U. of North Carolina, then Harvard Business School. "Dick" salvaged father's Bank of North Carolina before it merged with NCNB in 1982 (now Bank of America). Today owns 32 million shares of BofA worth $1.4 billion. Other investments: National Gypsum (drywall), C.D. Spangler Construction (real estate). Became UNC President 1986, took students to lunch to learn what was happening on campus. Stepped down 1997; donated $27 million to UNC to fund various professorships last May. Repairs grandfather clocks in spare time. Favorite indulgence: "I never hesitate to order chocolate milk."

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State Law School dropout started women's sportswear store 1963 with $5,000 loan from aunt. Went public as Limited Brands 1969. Expanded; launched Limited Express 1980, bought Victoria's Secret 2 years later for $1 million. Opened first Bath & Body Works 1990. Last July sold 75% of Limited Brands operation to Sun Capital Partners and 75% of Express apparel chain to Golden Gate Capital. Plans to improve Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works operations, buy back stock, reduce workforce. Supports Jewish causes with wife, Abigail, and Wexner Foundation.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Limited Brands', 'uri': 'companies/limited-brands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive retailer has been called the U.K.’s Howard Hughes. In spotlight after listing his Sports Direct International athletic retailer in February 2007. Company, which has 465 stores and owns brands like Lillywhites and Lonsdale, lost half its value since then in part because of what analysts see as lack of transparency. In June purchased soccer club Newcastle United.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968; brother Robert split same year. Bass Enterprises Production Co. pumps estimated 8 million barrels of oil and gas a year. Sold stake in firm to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Now looking for oil in harsh waters of maritime Canada. Ed spent $200 million building Biosphere 2 project in Arizona 1990s; sold with surrounding land to housing developer for $50 million last year, leased laboratory to U. of Arizona.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pittsburgh-raised money man studied economics at Bucknell before graduate studies at San Diego State. Became disciple of value investor Benjamin Graham. Founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974; today manages more than $100 billion. Painstaking due diligence: only invests in high-intrinsic-value companies with low stock prices, waits for market to adjust. On boards of Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Whittier Institute for Diabetes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Fuyao Group, which makes glass used in automobiles. Customers include Audi, Ford, Fiat, Nissan. More recently profiting from booming auto sales to China's burgeoning middle class. U.S. investment bank Goldman Sachs is awaiting final government approval to purchase 10% stake in group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Daniel D'Aniello and David Rubenstein (see both) founded Carlyle Group 1987; used politically connected advisers--including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major--to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's 2004 movie, Fahrenheit 9/11, for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Cut ties with lightning-rod advisers; brought on ex-IBM chief Louis Gerstner, former Time Inc. editor in chief Norman Pearlstine. Diversified portfolio. Today firm manages $76 billion across 55 buyout, leveraged finance, real estate, venture capital funds. Last year firm sold 7.5% stake to Abu Dhabi government's investment group Mubadala Development Company for $1.35 billion. Dartmouth grad earned M.B.A. at U. of Chicago. Took job at First National Bank of Chicago, became chief financial officer at MCI. Runs Carlyle's investment committee.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With William Conway Jr. and David Rubenstein (see both) founded Carlyle Group 1987; used politically connected advisers--including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major--to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's 2004 movie, Fahrenheit 9/11, for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Cut ties with lightning-rod advisers; brought on ex-IBM chief Louis Gerstner, former Time Inc. editor in chief Norman Pearlstine. Diversified portfolio. Today firm manages $76 billion across 55 buyout, leveraged finance, real estate, venture capital funds. Last year firm sold 7.5% stake to Abu Dhabi government's investment group Mubadala Development Company for $1.35 billion. D'Aniello grew up in Butler, Pa., bagged groceries; mom was an insurance claims agent. Studied economics at Syracuse, then Harvard M.B.A. Early career included posts at Trans World Airlines, Pepsi. Became executive at Marriott. Runs Carlyle's day-to-day operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Balance owner hung up sneakers last year after 35 years; ceded control to new chief executive, Robert DeMartini, citing desire for a younger, more progressive operation. Remains chairman; wife, Anne, is executive vice president. New Balance Arch Co. founded in 1906 to correct orthopedic foot problems. Davis foresaw rise of athletic shoe popularity, bought company on day of Boston Marathon 1972. Built brand shunning fashion trends; focused on selling comfort, support. Company holds No. 2 spot in U.S. sneaker market.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded NCB stockbrokers in Dublin in 1981. Sold the company in 1994 for $39 million and started his own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. In 2006 sold his best-known asset, the London City Airport, to a consortium of investors including Credit Suisse, GE and AIG. Still owns stakes in a variety of entities, from Scotland’s Celtic Football Club to Latvia’s Rietumu Banka; also a piece of Barbados’ swank Sandy Lane Hotel. Passionate golfer. Nicknamed “The Kaiser” due to his bushy mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable pioneer founded network that became Home Box Office; traded channel with the old Time Inc. for a cable company with 1,500 Long Island customers 1973. Bet became Cablevision. Public 1986. Today serves 3 million customers; sales nearly $6 billion. Failed to take company private last year. Other assets include Radio City Music Hall, Madison Square Garden, pro basketball's New York Knicks, hockey's New York Rangers.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Jerry Yang (see) as Stanford grad student, veered off Ph.D. path to form new portal; took Yahoo public 1996. Brought in "professional management" (Tim Koogle in 1995, then Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel in 2001). Semel quit under fire in 2007. Yang became chief executive for first time last June. Tough job. Turned down Micrsoft's offer to buy Yahoo for $45 billion in early February. Yang born in Taiwan. Filo expanding into China: bought 40% stake in Alibaba.com for $1 billion in 2005; public offering of Chinese business-to-business Web site likely. Yang aims to create a "stronger culture of winning" (or at least get a higher price out of Steve Ballmer). Filo runs tech.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William, heads Li & Fung, global outsourcing firm that supplies clothes and accessories to retailers such as Disney, Coca-Cola, Kohl's. Sales: $7.2 billion. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started distribution outfit Li & Fung a century ago in Guangzhou, China; sold porcelain, handicrafts. Victor earned engineering degrees from MIT; Ph.D. in economics from Harvard. William studied engineering at Princeton, then Harvard M.B.A. Duo returned to Hong Kong 1970s. Victor now chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited family watch-parts business at 15 after father passed away; expanded into shopping malls, sports teams. Best assets: pro football's Tampa Bay Buccaneers, soccer behemoth Manchester United, 7 million square feet of retail space. Sons manage family assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Laurence Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has 18 stores worldwide. Average transaction: $400,000. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei and Donald Trump, who paid a reported $1 million for wife Melania’s 12-carat diamond engagement ring. A self-made tycoon, Graff grew up in London’s gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler’s apprentice. Aside from his jewelry company, Graff Diamonds International, Graff owns a polished diamond trading company in Antwerp, a real estate company in Luxembourg and a majority stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. He also owns a vineyard and winery in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and a modern and contemporary art collection valued at $250 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sudanese-born "Mo" founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 15 African countries. Sold it in 2005 for $3.4 billion; pocketed $1.4 billion. The London resident now spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. Created Mo Ibrahim Foundation to award monetary prize to former African heads of state who have shown exemplary leadership in such areas as promoting political freedom; awarded first $5 million prize in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Dubai's Landmark Group, a retailer with over 600 stores and 10 original brands of apparel, home furnishings and electronics. Drove a taxi in London before moving to Bahrain and starting baby products shop in 1973. Since expanded beyond Gulf to India, Pakistan, China and Spain. Founded charity in India  promoting children's education. Also sponsors orphanage and old age home in city of Chennai. Wife Renuka oversees "Splash," company's fashion line.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after earning his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky Fraser, an asset manager that today manages $50 billion on behalf of institutional clients and high-net-worth individuals. Outspoken critic of excessive executive pay. Has advocated for a common currency among Nafta members. In addition to eclectic art collection that includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline. Inducted into the Canadian Business Hall of Fame.

name: Billionaires
bio: Borrowed $300 from wife, founded real estate developer Lerner Enterprises in 1952. Made fortune building massive shopping malls in the suburbs of Washington, D.C.: Tysons Corner Center, Tysons II, Wheaton Plaza, Landover Mall, Dulles Town Center, White Flint. Today owns millions of square feet of commercial and retail property, thousands of apartments. Focused on new developments near area's Dulles airport and Tysons II. Going green: buying wind power tax credits for new projects. Owns pro baseball's Washington Nationals; runs franchise with son and 2 sons-in-law.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as "Mr. Shanghai" for his promotion of China's international business hub, Lo is branching out. His Shui On Land took a stake in an industrial park last year, a software outsourcing hub in Dalian; plans project in Yunnan Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of cable investor John Elroy McCaw. Craig, at age 19, found father dead of a heart attack, watched as dad's partners tried to grab family business. Vowed to work with only those he truly trusts; takes over with brothers Bruce, Keith and John Jr. and transforms company into early cell phone giant McCaw Cellular. Sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Reinvested profits in Nextel satellite network--then it all collapsed in telecom crash of 2000. Now chief of wireless Clearwire. Went public last March, stock has been volatile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financial genius joined what became Drexel Burnham Lambert 1969. Developed market for high-yield junk bonds, fueled 1980s leveraged buyout mania. Helped fund cash kings of The Forbes 400: Ted Turner, Carl Icahn, Ronald Perelman, Henry Kravis. Earned $550 million in salary and bonus in 1986. Ratted out by fellow arbitrager Ivan Boesky; plead guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud 1990. Paid $900 million settlement; sentenced to 10 years in prison, released after 22 months. Still actively trades. Investor in education outfit Knowledge Universe; company sold stake last year to diversify ownership. Spends majority of time on philanthropy. Charity started early: rode bicycle through San Fernando Valley streets collecting dimes and quarters for American Cancer Society as a kid. Donates to doctors looking for cures for prostate and breast cancers, melanoma, Alzheimer's, diabetes, leukemia, AIDS.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime architect led investor buyout of previously state-owned oil company, Rompetrol, in 1998; took over as chief executive in 2001. Via acquisitions built the company into a $3.2 billion (2007 sales) multinational refiner. Last year sold 75% of the group to Kazakhstan's state-owned energy operator, KazMunaiGaz. At the time, Patriciu was quoted as saying the deal offers Europe "an energy bridge that does not depend on Russia." Former parliamentarian is member of the Romanian Liberal Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Robert Sr., founded Rich Products after WWII with invention of world's first frozen soy whipped topping. Diversified into nondairy coffee creamer, frozen breads, cookies, cakes. Robert Jr. studied at Williams College, M.B.A. from U. of Rochester. Became president of company 1978; now chairman. Inherited 60% of privately held company when dad died 2006. Spent much of past few years buying up competitors; now investing internally. Built new facilities in Mexico, England, Brazil, South Africa this year. Sales: $2.6 billion. Sports fanatic tried out for 1964 U.S. Olympic hockey team; owns Triple-A Buffalo Bisons. Penned 2 books on fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With William Conway Jr. and Daniel D'Aniello (see both) founded Carlyle Group 1987; used politically connected advisers--including former President George H.W. Bush and former British prime minister John Major--to buy defense-oriented companies, turn them around, sell for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's 2004 movie, Fahrenheit 9/11, for investing Bin Laden family money; rehabbing image since. Cut ties with lightning-rod advisers; brought on ex-IBM chief Louis Gerstner, former Time Inc. editor in chief Norman Pearlstine. Diversified portfolio. Today firm manages $76 billion across 55 buyout, leveraged finance, real estate, venture capital funds. Last year firm sold 7.5% stake to Abu Dhabi government's investment group Mubadala Development Company for $1.35 billion. Baltimore native sold magazines in high school. Studied political science at Duke, then law at U. of Chicago. Became a lawyer; then deputy assistant to President Carter for domestic policy 1977. Road warrior: rumored to spend two-thirds of the year traveling raising funds. Vice chairman of New York's Lincoln Center.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker Schroder continues as a director of his family's financial services company, Schroders. Shares wealth with sister Charmaine, whose husband George Mallinckrodt is the company's president. Speculation last year about whether Schroder would unload his stake in the 200-year-old bank to private equity groups. In spare time, flies planes and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Charles Schusterman (d. 2000), who started in oil and gas business 1961. Founded Samson Resources a decade later; built into one of world's largest privately held energy companies. Today Samson Investment ruled by daughter Stacy; spent $1.3 billion last year on drilling and development. Operates more than 4,000 oil and gas wells; owns interests in another 12,000. Majority of sales come from natural gas. Dedicated to philanthropy: Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation contributes to worldwide Jewish causes, enhancing quality of life for Oklahoma; more than $100 million in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment geek uses complex algorithms to capitalize on tiny anomalies in the stock market. Became a professor of computer science at Columbia U., worked at Morgan Stanley before launching hedge fund D.E. Shaw & Co. from an office above a bookstore. Recruits heavily, hires selectively; only one in 500 applicants makes the cut. Company sold 20% stake to Lehman Brothers last March. Delegated day-to-day operations to others to focus on medical research; D.E. Shaw Research hires scientists in hopes of making groundbreaking discoveries while reaping financial rewards.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'D. E. Shaw & Co., L.P.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers, both Duke University grads, control generic drug maker Ranbaxy Laboratories, founded by their grandfather. Malvinder is chief executive of Ranbaxy, which recently settled lawsuit with GlaxoSmithkline over marketing rights to generic version of herpes drug Valtrex. In February 2008 Ranbaxy's board approved spinoff of research arm into Ranbaxy Life Science Research. Shivinder runs Indian hospital chain Fortis Healthcare, which went public in 2007. Brothers also recently listed financial services arm, Religare Enterprises.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Kingston Technology 1987; now nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit. Today its USB flash drives and flash cards grace digital cameras, MP3 players. Its DataTraveler Mini-Migo holds 2 gigabytes on a data key less than 1 inch long. Partner John Tu (see): family fled China for Taiwan 1949, later moved to Germany where he studied electrical engineering. Came to U.S. 1972. David Sun: moved to U.S. from Taiwan 1977, worked as chief engineer at Alpha Micro. Pair started first memory-chip shop Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million, then formed Kingston. Nifty turnabout: sold 80% stake to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, then bought it back for only $450 million 3 years later.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Belle International, one of China's biggest shoe retailers. Claims to be nation's largest retailer of Nike, Adidas brands. Its 2007 listing attracted such international investors as luxury goods purveyor LVMH. Hong Kong native chairs the Federation of Hong Kong Footwear. Shares fortune with 37-year-old daughter, Tang Ming Wai, group's executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of a trio of Brazilian billionaire beer barons. With former investment banking partners, Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira (both billionaires), Telles built Brazilian brewer AmBev. In 2004 merged with Interbrew of Belgium to form InBev, world's largest brewer by volume. The trio also controls Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Telles is reportedly a keen spearfisher and likes to spend time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: A longtime associate of Vladimir Putin and studied judo with the same trainer as him. In the late 1980s ran Kinex, a state-owned oil exporter. Became one of its main shareholders when it was later privatized. In the 1990s sold Russian oil. Business apparently improved after Putin came to power. Today is one of the co-owners of the Gunvor Group, through which state-controlled Rosneft and Gazpromneft oil firms export their products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brooklyn-born investor duo Laurence Tisch. "Larry" with brother Preston bought New Jersey hotel in 1946, leased hotels in once posh Atlantic City. Later managed NYC's Drake, Belmont Plaza, Regency. Took control of Loews Theatres 1959; varied interests now include watches (Bulova), tobacco (Lorillard), oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk). Contrarian investor Larry known for his bearish pessimism. Wilma transferred large chunks of stock to sons soon after his death in 2003. Company remains under family control. Family contributions to NYU exceed $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Kingston Technology 1987; now nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit. Today its USB flash drives and flash cards grace digital cameras, MP3 players. Its DataTraveler Mini-Migo holds 2 gigabytes on a data key less than 1 inch long. John Tu: family fled China for Taiwan 1949, later moved to Germany where he studied electrical engineering. Came to U.S. 1972. Partner David Sun (see): moved to U.S. from Taiwan 1977, worked as chief engineer at Alpha Micro. Pair started first memory-chip shop Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million, then formed Kingston. Nifty turnabout: sold 80% stake to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, then bought it back for only $450 million 3 years later.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned textile company into a real estate empire, Peel Holdings, which includes the 1.4-million-square-foot shopping mall the Trafford Center. Took company private in 2004. A year later led the group's $1.3 billion takeover of Mersey Docks & Harbour Co. in a bid to revitalize the Liverpool waterfront. In 2006 Deutsche Bank's property arm paid $600 million for 49% stake. Group's other holdings include investment properties, airports and ports. Added a stake in the James Bond's film studio, Pinewood Shepperton. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio: The queen of daytime television continues to expand her empire. Announced plans to create OWN: The Oprah Winfrey Network. Launched XM Radio channel Oprah and Friends September 2006. Born in rural Mississippi, became TV newscaster in Nashville, Baltimore. Joined Chicago TV station, turned 3rd-rated morning show into nation's No. 1 talk show. The Oprah Winfrey Show launched nationally 1986; currently airs in 135 countries, drawing 46 million viewers a week in the U.S. Also launched showboating shrink Dr. Phil; a producer of the musical version of The Color Purple on Broadway. Donated $40 million to create the Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa. Previous net worth estimates failed to account for value of Oprah's powerful brand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, Edgar Sr., inherited Seagram spirits empire that was built up by their father, Sam, and sold to Vivendi in 2000. Charles is focusing on Jewish charities. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Through his foundation underwrites New York Jewish Music & Heritage Festival. Started the Andy Prize in memory of his late wife, Andrea, who was killed by a taxi while walking their dog near their Manhattan apartment in January 2006. The prize is awarded annually to an Israeli decorative artist for excellence in ceramics, jewelry, textile or glass. The Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies annually give $15 million to a host of causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grocer's son developed first shopping center in Cedar Rapids, Iowa 1954 with his 2 brothers. Took General Management public in 1970; real estate investment trust liquidated 15 years later for 100% profit. Relocated to Chicago after brother Martin died 1995, renamed company General Growth Properties. Remains chairman; son, John, took reins 1999. Today nation's second-largest REIT owns 200 million square feet across more than 200 malls and planned communities in 44 states. Company recently gave health insurance, higher wages to shopping center janitors.

name: Billionaires
bio: After selling TV-production giant Endemol in 2000, the brain behind global hit Big Brother returned in full creative force. In 2005 launched a new television channel, Talpa TV, to stunning success in the Netherlands, largely off the back of programming like Dutch soccer and popular reality fare. Talpa TV, now called Tien, was taken over by RTL Group in 2007. De Mol has a 25% stake in RTL’s Netherlands subsidiary. Also bought a 5% stake in Endemol 2007, sparking rumors that he wanted it all back.

name: Billionaires
bio: With siblings inherited Getty Oil from father, J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976). Spent 4 years in business; sold to Texaco in 1986 for $10 billion. Started Forward Management in 1998, investment firm manages $1.5 billion today; Getty the majority shareholder. San Francisco socialite composes operas; latest, PlumpJack, was inspired by Falstaff, the spirited knight in Shakespeare’s Henry IV plays. Loves the vino: founded Napa Valley winery, also dubbed PlumpJack, in 1992.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Used papers to champion Spanish-American War; infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle, Houston Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire), cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV, radio stations. Company relocated to $700 million, 46-story "green" tower last year. William III a partner at VC firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, invests in companies focused on Web video, fiber optics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in Illinois and Florida; father a residential housing contractor. Skipped college to join Army. Bought used garbage truck in 1962; discovered the power of repeat customers. Turned small trash-hauling operation into waste-management titan WMX. Quit 1984. Bought stake in 19-store video rental chain Blockbuster 1987; expanded, sold to Viacom 7 years later for $8.4 billion. Invested some of the proceeds in resorts; sold stake in Extended Stay America to Stephen Schwarzman's (see) Blackstone Group 2004 for $185 million. Owner of pro football's lowly Miami Dolphins hired famed coach Bill Parcels as head of football operations to hopefully return the team to glory.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, and his brother Sam ran handful of small 5-and-10 stores in Arkansas and Missouri. Brothers built first Wal-Mart 1962. Nancy inherited large stake after Bud's death 1995. Sold pro hockey's St. Louis Blues 2006. Recently purchased a Missouri bank. Founder of New York City's Cedar Lake Ensemble ballet troupe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Lars founded L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB in 1944 as a construction company. Fredrik took over in 1981. Today the $ 3.4 billion (sales) diversified holding company concentrates on property management and investments; owns over 150 properties and projects in Sweden. Enjoys hunting and curling; in fact, was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johannesburg mining magnate Patrice Motsepe is South Africa's first black billiionaire. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, Motsepe became the first black partner at Johannesburg's Bowman Gilfillan law firm, before starting a low-level conracting business doing mine scutt work. Bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994, turned them profitable using lean, mean management style. Since then, built $875 million (sales) mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM), with interests in a wide swath of minerals: precious metals (platinum and its cousins), nickel, chrome, iron, manganese and coal. Benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. Also holds a 5.5% stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett's (see) indispensable consigliere. Son of a lawyer grew up in Omaha reading medical journals, Ben Franklin aphorisms. Bred hamsters, traded them to other children. Studied math, physics at U. of Michigan, dropped out to join Army Air Corps. Then Harvard Law. Met Buffett at a dinner party 1959; duo soon began investing together. Became vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway; owns shares worth $2.2 billion. Obsessed with due diligence, patience; disdains excessive executive pay. Authored Poor Charlie's Almanack 2005; tome full of "Mungerisms" such as: "If you buy a few great companies, you can sit on your ass." Nickname: "The Abominable No-Man." Says Buffett: "If we ask Charlie something and he says "no," then we put all of our money in it. If he says "that's the stupidest thing I've ever heard," then we make a more modest investment."

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Sole heir to once deeply troubled estate left by late father. Battled for 14
years to win control of his assets from her stepmother. Legal hurdles
cleared in 2003 in time to catch boom in iron ore demand. Has potential to
become much richer. In late 2007, after decades of promise, Rinehart's
family company, Hancock Prospecting, shipped its first ton of iron ore as
part of a joint venture with mining giant Rio Tinto; royalties from Rio
Tinto expected to jump in the next year. Rinehart is now working on multiple
mine developments on her vast expanse of undeveloped land to feed Chinese
demand.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3.5 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. Now owns over 51% of company, which publishes more than 170 papers in 33 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest daily tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia. She remains the majority holder of Axel Springer after a German court rejected a claim to more shares made by her dead husband's grandson, Axel Sven Springer. He is apparently appealing.  Active in various philanthropic organizations; has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With brother and fellow billionaire Dmitry started out importing computers
to Russia. Brothers then set up a bank and recently have been active in real
estate and mass media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general
strategy. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed
executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are
very religious. Alexei uses free time to assist clergymen at Moscow1s Church
of the Trinity.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Brought into the business by older brother Alexei, also a billionaire; they
are now equal partners. Started out importing computers to Russia, then set
up a bank, and recently have been active in real estate and mass media.
Despite their wealth, the brothers felt a lack of education and completed
executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Alexei is in charge
of the brothers' IT business and the general strategy; Dmitry was recently
appointed to a seat on the Federation Council of the gas-rich Arctic region
of Yamal and is more involved in their bank, Promsvyazbank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ankara-born philanthropist shares Koc Group fortune with brother Rahmi Koc and sister Suna Kirac (see both) . Holds board seat at conglomerate but does not manage any business unit. Because of parasite in her blood spent years fighting illness in hospitals around the world; the experience moved her to build nursing education and research center in Turkey and to marry a doctor. Fluent in English and German.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surfer studied at U. of Southern California, then University of San Diego Law School. Started as an international finance attorney, moved on to invest with Robert Bass (see). Founded Colony Capital 1991, bought up bad real estate loans from fledgling S&Ls. Now owns casinos in Atlantic City, Gulf states and Europe, plus luxury hotels and apartment buildings. With billionaire brothers Frank and Lorenzo Fertitta, took gambling outfit Station Casinos private for $9 billion. Also owns the $3,000-a-night Costa Smeralda resort in Sardinia. Enjoys polo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation grocer's Central Market stores shun big brands like Coca-Cola and General Mills in favor of organic foods, wine and cheese, in-store cafes. Exporting gourmet sensibilities to Mexico's burgeoning middle class. Grocery chain founded 1905 by grandmother to support ailing husband, 3 children out of small house in Kerrville, Tex. Today more than 300 stores in Texas and Mexico. Sales exceed $13 billion. Donates 5% of pretax earnings to charitable causes. Bulking up nongrocery unit to compete with Wal-Mart Supercenters; in October 2006 introduced program allowing customers to purchase any of 500 generic drugs for $5. Sister, Eleanor, involved with children's charities. Two nephews now in charge: Howard III runs Mexico operations, Stephen leads Central Market. Brother Howard runs family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former auto repair shop owner and Michelin engineer entered cell phone business in 1987. Sold just 26 phones in his first eight months from his store in hardscrabble Stoke-on-Trent. Caudwell Group sales reached $3.6 billion in 2005, the last year he headed the mobile phone giant. Sold his 85% stake in the group for $2.3 billion in Sept. 2006. Avid sportsman used to bike 14 miles to work; now climbing Mount Everest and planning to sail the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rice trader turned media baron; his Essel Group includes cable networks, packaging, amusement parks. Has bet $200 million on Veria, a health-and-wellness channel launched in the U.S. Has stake in Daily News & Analysis, a newspaper that competes with market leader Times of India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $4.1 billion (sales) Videocon Group, world's third-largest producer of low-tech color TV picture tubes. Plans to buy Daewoo Electronics went nowhere. Started Videocon Aviation to get into airport development. In January won hotly contested bid for national telecom license to launch mobile phone operations. Partnering with Verizon in another new telecom venture for fixed-line services. Bought Planet M music stores from billionaire Indu Jain's Bennett, Coleman. A regular reader of the Bhagavad Gita, the sacred Hindu text.

name: Billionaires
bio: A count who has a lock on his wealth. Holds stakes in Assa Abloy, worlds largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of the largest publicly traded security companies; Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures; and Attendo Senior Care, a private company that provides alarms and care communication systems for senior citizens. Received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1964.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his staffing company, French Ecco, with Klaus Jacobs' Swiss Adia in 1996 to create Adecco. Now one of the world's largest employment agencies with $30 billion in sales. Per Swiss law, stepped down as cochairman of Adecco in 2005 at age 70 and is now honorary president. Foriel-Destezet remains busy on the boards of holding company Akila Finance and security systems provider Securitas. Lives as a tax-exile in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, who left behind a $16.7 billion estate in 2006. Now based in Riyadh, helps watch over family construction and investment company Saudi Oger for older brother Saad Hariri (see), the Lebanese parliamentary majority leader. Plus has hands in U.S. government contracting: cofounded and chairs identity management software firm Epok, based outside Washington, D.C., which sells to federal and state customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest brother of Saad Hariri (see), the Lebanese parliamentary majority leader; older brothers Bahaa and Aymin and mother, Nazek, are all also billionaires. Owns a stake in family businesses including construction, banking and media holdings. He serves on board of Beirut's Future Television Network, a terrestrial and satellite TV network. Also runs a fledgling design studio for furniture and other wares in Paris, where sister Hind and mother also live.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of hotel magnate Conrad Hilton (d. 1979) initially resisted family business after father offered him management job paying $160 a month. Stint in Navy as photographer WWII; came home to work for dad. Rose from elevator operator to president; became chairman 1979. Tenacious heir: father left bulk of estate to a charitable foundation; Barron waged lengthy legal battle for his cut of fortune, won 1989. Reaped $840 million from The Blackstone Group's buyout of Hilton Hotels last year. Airman flies gliders at his 750,000-acre Nevada ranch. Recently pledged 97% of fortune to father's Conrad N. Hilton Foundation upon death.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vassar grad named chairman of Ingram Industries after death of husband Bronson Ingram in 1995. Bronson inherited his father's oil-and-barge business 1963. Today company is one of the nation's largest media distribution conglomerates: books, magazines, print on demand. Books operations run by son John. Son David manages spinoff Ingram Entertainment: CDs, DVDs. Original barge business led by son Orrin; president, chief executive of Ingram Industries. Martha remains chairman. Performing-arts buff prominent in Nashville social circles. Chairman of the Board of Trust of Vanderbilt U.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school age 14, delivered milk for family's dairy store during Depression; workday began at 4 a.m. Siphoned milk to open ice cream shop with 2 brothers and $1,200 in 1940, grew into United Dairy Farmers chain. Left to pursue own investments; today company run by brother Robert, operates nearly 200 stores in Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana. Acquired S&Ls 1959; expanded into insurance 1971. With sons owns 33% stake in American Financial Group. Now betting on alternative energy; owns Indiana ethanol producer New Energy Corp. Minority owner of pro baseball's Cincinnati Reds spends spare time taking long, brisk walks for exercise.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear engineer turned his family's ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem, second-largest drug wholesaler in Europe. The group was bought by U.K. pharmacy chain Boots in 2006 for $12 billion. In 2007 Pessina teamed up with buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. in a $22 billion deal to take Alliance Boots private; he remains chair of the board. Known to own a yacht and collect art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hong Leong Group Malaysia, conglomerate involved in banking, semiconductor manufacturing, ceramic tile manufacturing, motorcycle distribution. Increased stake in U.K. online gaming company Rank Group fueling speculation that he may be considering a bid for it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Marine commands real estate empire via Majestic Realty: owns more than 73 million square feet of commercial property from Los Angeles to Atlanta. Owns stake in Staples Center arena with Philip Anschutz (see); also stakes in pro basketball's L.A. Lakers, hockey's L.A. Kings. Donated $23 million to alma mater USC in 2006 to fund fine arts school; serves on board of National Geographic Society. Owns 20% stake in Promerica Bank; Los Angeles bank focused on serving Latino entrepreneurs.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Buoyed by beer. With investing partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles (both billionaires), turned around AmBev, a lagging Brazilian beermaker, and in 2004 merged it with Interbrew of Belgium to form InBev, now the world's largest brewer by volume. The Brazilian trio is one of InBev's controlling shareholders. The 3 men also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas--a kind of Wal-Mart without groceries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-granddaughter of Franz Stroher, wigmaker who founded Wella AG, one of world's biggest professional hair care groups. Pocketed $1 billion in March 2003 sale of Wella to Procter & Gamble. Sylvia and her husband, a former male nurse, are known for their collection of contemporary German art which includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The patriarch of cable news is no longer in the media business. Stepped down as Time Warner vice chairman in 2003, retired from the board in 2006; no longer owns Time Warner stock. "Mouth of the South" getting richer with real estate, food. Largest individual landholder in the U.S. owns 2 million acres in 12 states, plus some ground in Argentina. Owns 50,000 bison; restaurant chain, Ted's Montana Grill, serves bison burgers at 51 locations. Has given more than $1.5 billion to charity, including gifts to the United Nations Foundation, Nuclear Threat Initiative, the Turner Foundation. Outdoorsman committed to fighting global climate change.

name: Billionaires
bio: Seventh child of Kentucky dairy farmers opened hamburger stand to fund flying lessons after hearing radio broadcast of Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight. Dropped out of U. of Kentucky to follow passion; flew Pan Am planes for 10 years. Founded pilot training academy FlightSafety International 1951. Took public 1968; sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway 1996. Nanogenarian still drives himself to work each morning. Chairs Orbis International: nonprofit group fights blindness in developing countries, uses DC-10 plane as mobile ophthalmological teaching and surgery lab. Shuns traveling like a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest billionaire in the world for years, slips to third place. Prince Albert von Thurn und Taxis appeared briefly in Forbes ranks at age 8 but officially inherited fortune on his 18th birthday in June 2001. Went to high school in Rome; studied economics and theology in Scotland. But hardly needs to work. Assets include real estate, art and a tech company. His 30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany is considered one of the largest forest holdings in Europe. Lives in a family castle, Schloss Emmeram, with his mother, Gloria, and older sisters Maria Theresia and Elisabeth. Racecar driver, tours with an Italian auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner David Filo (see) as Stanford grad student, veered off Ph.D. path to form new portal; took Yahoo public 1996. Brought in "professional management" (Tim Koogle in 1995, then Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel in 2001). Semel quit under fire in 2007. Yang became chief executive for first time last June. Tough job. Turned down Micrsoft's offer to buy Yahoo for $45 billion in early February. Yang born in Taiwan. Filo expanding into China: bought 40% stake in Alibaba.com for $1 billion in 2005; public offering of Chinese business-to-business Web site likely. Yang aims to create a "stronger culture of winning" (or at least get a higher price out of Steve Ballmer). Filo runs tech.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moved from China to Singapore in 1988. Began building luxury residences back in his native China five years later. Yanlord Land Group, which has properties or land, in Shanghai, Chengdu, Nanjing, Zhuhai, Suzhou and Tianjin, is now listed in Singapore. Zhong also has businesses in trading, manufacturing, retail and financial services in China, Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morphed a bed-linen manufacturer into Turkey's largest exporter. His Zorlu holding company encompasses 65 businesses in consumer electronics, financial services and energy. Once bankrupt, his private-label TV maker and distributor Vestel today commands 26% of the European market. Last year went 1-for-2 bidding against international real estate investment and development arm of Dubai Holding for precious plots of land in Istanbul. Now planning bid to build and operate a major state-owned power plant in Turkey. High school dropout shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter. Also owns Vestel Manisaspor soccer club, which plays in Turkey's Premier Super League.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Montreal tobacco and candy wholesaler studied at Harvard, then Wharton M.B.A. Cofounded Boston Properties with Edward Linde 1970, took public 1997. Today portfolio includes 135 commercial buildings: offices, hotels, retail. Sold 5 Times Square office tower for $1.3 billion in 2006. Also media: owns U.S. News & World Report, New York's Daily News. "I've been a news junkie since I was 13 years old." Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan opened a new research center funded with $100 million endowment from Zuckerman last February. Frequent panelist on Sunday morning chatfest The McLaughlin Group.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a barber earned childhood cash selling popcorn in Minnesota. Played hockey for UCLA, started out earning $14 a week working nights at an aircraft factory. Then earned Harvard M.B.A., Loyola law degree. Became a naval officer during World War II; studied for CPA exam in spare time. Founded Ace Beverage 1956 with exclusive rights to distribute Budweiser in parts of Los Angeles. Today distributes beer in L.A., Hawaii (5 islands) and the Caribbean. Added insurance, auto dealerships and real estate. Big supporter of YMCA, Boy Scouts of America. Emphasizes saving: "There are 7 wonders of the world, but the eighth wonder is compounded interest." Turned 90 last year, attributes longevity to 5-mile walks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexho as catering and river-cruise company in 1966. Today the $18.7 billion (2006 sales) company also supplies food to U.S. Marine Corps, handles security for the Alaska natural gas pipeline, manages gold mines in Chile, operates prisons and has a majority stake in the Lido, a topless Parisian cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists. A joint venture with Magic Johnson provides dining, catering and grounds keeping to school and corporate cafeterias. Bellon stepped down as chief executive in 2005 but remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied French literature at U. of Pennsylvania. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis (see), created new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986. Founded Ivax the following year; sold drug giant to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005. Today serves on boards of Teva, American Stock Exchange, Smithsonian. Recently donated millions of dollars to fund a new building for the Frost Art Museum at Florida International University; also gave $30 million to the Frost School of Music at University of Miami.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Marilyn Carlson Nelson, inherited hospitality, marketing, food, travel empire from father, Curtis Carlson. Dad founded Gold Bond Stamp company 1938; produced trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Today Carlson Cos. own hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's). Marilyn runs company; Barbara administers family foundation. Marilyn's son Curtis appointed chief operating officer in 2003, resigned last year; sued mom and aunt, claiming he was cheated out of chief executive position and his cut of profits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents emigrated from Israel, settled in Flint, Mich. Studied real estate finance at Michigan State; spent 20s learning buyout business alongside older brother Alec at Gores Technology Group. Tom split in 1995 to form Platinum Equity; rebuilds distressed companies, flips for profit. Last July agreed to buy Chicago steel outfit Ryerson for $2 billion. Delusions of Tinseltown grandeur: invests in film firms Crescent Drive Pictures, 360 Pictures; executive producer of starlet Lindsay Lohan's flick, I Know Who Killed Me.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew Seven & I Holdings into a retail giant and remains the honorary chairman. Last year the company launched a prepaid debit card that can be used in its 12,000 7-Eleven stores and 160 Denny’s restaurants in Japan. Has expanded 7-Eleven to China. Group also owns other Japanese chains such as baby superstore Akachan Honpo. Expecting record sales this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied law at UC, Berkeley. Bought 80-acre pear and walnut orchard in California, converted into first vineyard. Built Kendall-Jackson into populist wine concern. Today Jackson Family Wines produces 5.2 million cases on 14,000 planted acres. Has spent $250 million building Thoroughbred breeding operation; owns 3 Kentucky farms. Also 30% stake in Preakness winner Curlin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam took helm 1966; business expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), bug spray (Off, Raid). Estimated sales: $7 billion. Environmentalist Sam sent kids to alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. Fisk: S.C. Johnson chairman has Ph.D. in physics, M.B.A.; working in Kenya, India to establish sustainable, community-based businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam took helm 1966; business expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), bug spray (Off, Raid). Estimated sales: $7 billion. Environmentalist Sam sent kids to alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam took helm 1966; business expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), bug spray (Off, Raid). Estimated sales: $7 billion. Environmentalist Sam sent kids to alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. Curt: runs industrial cleaning supplies outfit JohnsonDiversey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam took helm 1966; business expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), bug spray (Off, Raid). Estimated sales: $7 billion. Environmentalist Sam sent kids to alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. Helen: heads camping and military provisions manufacturer Johnson Outdoors, Johnson Financial Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam took helm 1966; business expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), bug spray (Off, Raid). Estimated sales: $7 billion. Environmentalist Sam sent kids to alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. Winnie: leads family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime cable baron abhors taxes, loves dealmaking. Partner to TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996) sold nation's largest cable company to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion. Today publicly held holding company, Liberty Media, owns stakes in cable (QVC, Encore, Starz), cell phones (Motorola), online retailing (InterActiveCorp). Ended tense standoff with Rupert Murdoch (see) last April; gave up $11 billion in News Corp. shares for 39% stake in DirecTV and $550 million in cash. Plans to spin off DirecTV with public offering of Liberty Entertainment. Last May Liberty swapped 68.5 million shares it held in Time Warner in exchange for that company's Atlanta Braves, craft magazines and $960 million cash. Now fighting with Barry Diller over the future of IAC/InterActiveCorp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed on Campbell Soup business to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company; all on board but not involved in day-to-day management. Recently company agreed to sell healthier foods to schools; now offers low-calorie, low-sodium soups. Also pledged to stop advertising to children products that do not meet nutritional standards.

name: Billionaires
bio: Feisty entrepreneur grew up poor in Portland, Ore.; sold magazines, lemonade through Depression. Studied physics at UCLA. Founded, sold aerospace companies Spectrolab, Heliotek 1960s. Funded some of world's most innovative biomed firms: Pacesetter Systems (rechargeable pacemakers), MiniMed (insulin pumps), Advanced Bionics (cochlear implants). Sold parts to Medtronic for an estimated $4.2 billion in 2001. Won back his Advanced Bionics from Boston Scientific in August after the device giant tried to fire him from running the subsidiary. Tinkering with inhaled insulin via MannKind; invested hundreds of millions so far, product approval years away. Gave $100 million to Purdue in 2006 to build a technology-conversion institute. Searching for more universities that will do the same; several have turned him down because of his strict rules as to how funds should be used.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Barbara Carlson Gage, inherited hospitality, marketing, food, travel empire from father, Curtis Carlson. Dad founded Gold Bond Stamp company 1938; produced trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Today Carlson Cos. own hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's). Marilyn runs company; Barbara administers family foundation. Marilyn's son Curtis appointed chief operating officer in 2003, resigned last year; sued mom and aunt, claiming he was cheated out of chief executive position and his cut of profits.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Peripatetic horse pill salesman turned cell phone magnate. His upstart Digicel stealing customers from big carriers in a dozen Caribbean and Latin American countries. Hopes to repeat success in South Pacific. Made first fortune selling an Irish mobile outfit to BT Group at height of telco boom in 2001. Last year, sold enough Digicel junk bonds to buy out minority owners and put $800 million in his pocket. Building stake in Tony O&#39Reilly’s  newspaper company, Independent News & Media, in effort to push the fellow billionaire out. Bought Aer Lingus shares to stop a rival from buying national carrier. Interests in 42 European radio stations, online recruiting sites in China, plane lessor in Ireland and Portuguese resort Quinta do Lago. Son of human rights activist, started nonprofit Front Line to fly activists in danger out of hot spots.

name: Billionaires
bio: Slim-fast kingpin raised in Long Beach, N.Y. Joined Army at 18; fought in Italy, France and Germany during World War II. Lesson: "War should be outlawed." Introduced Slim-Fast nutritional supplements 1976. Made fat fortune helping others get thin; sold to Unilever in 2000 for $2.3 billion. Recently embroiled in real estate, banking scandals involving friend Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert; denies any wrongdoing. Involved in Middle East diplomacy since 1988. "Democracy is a hell of a lot more than elections." Donates heavily to Democrats, Mayo Clinic, Jewish causes.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born developer fled Europe during WWII for then Palestine. Studied architecture, then went to Canada, where he established his real estate business. Now owns major properties in Canada, the U.S., Europe and Israel, including the Azrieli Center, three major high-rise developments in downtown Tel Aviv. Through the Azrieli Foundation, which he established in 1991, he is supporting architecture, education and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded commercial real estate investment firm JMB Realty with U. of Illinois roommate 1970. Rebuilt fortune after 1990s real estate collapse via private equity firm Walton Street Capital. Today portfolio includes Chicago's Four Seasons Hotel, MGM Tower in Los Angeles. Feeling lucky: lost out on bid for stake in Las Vegas' Riviera casino December 2006, won license to build riverfront casino in Philadelphia 4 days later. Prodigious collector of contemporary art also buying up industrial properties near West Coast ports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker became head of Banco Santander 1986. Built the 150 year old bank into Santander Central Hispano, one of Spain's leading financial institutions with more than 129,000 employees in 40 countries. Its retail branch, Banesto, is now run by daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botin. Emilio Botin's great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879. Enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of lighthouse operator emigrated from Greece as an infant; family settled in upper Manhattan. Studied engineering at NYU; dropped out to help friend save family's fledgling supermarket business. Opened first grocery store on 87th and Broadway 1969. Owned 10 stores by age 24; made $25 million a year in revenue. Plowed $5 million into Manhattan real estate 1977; property worth $100 million 5 years later. "A total accident. I just needed a place to put all the money I was making." Today his Red Apple Group owns $500 million worth of property; New York's Gristedes grocery chain. Obsessed with planes: midlife crisis led to flying lessons, then created airline to haul gamblers from New England to Atlantic City. Bought Capitol Airlines 1983; outfit quickly bankrupt. Stumbled upon Chapter 11 proceedings of United Refining Company while trying to salvage Capitol. Purchased oil refiner's stock for $7.5 million. Today firm owns 372 gas stations, Pennsylvania refinery. Running for mayor of New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Used papers to champion Spanish-American War; infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle, Houston Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire), cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV, radio stations. Company relocated to $700 million, 46-story "green" tower in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime ally of fellow billionaire Silvio Berlusconi, cofounded financial services group Mediolanum SpA with Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Still runs the group, whose companies provide investment advice, online banking, life insurance and real estate loans. Son Massimo, 40, is slowly being brought up Mediolanum's executive ladder. Company stock fell 30% in 2007. Doris vows it has no exposure to the subprime mortgage market. Also has a stake in Caffaro Biofuel. Enjoys bicycling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed on Campbell Soup business to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company; all on board but not involved in day-to-day management. Campbell recently agreed to sell healthier foods to schools; now offers low-calorie, low-sodium soups. Also pledged to stop advertising to children products that do not meet nutritional standards.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started working at age 7 to help support family. Helped father, Curly, operate a small lumber mill 1940s. Took Sierra Pacific public 1969; private again 5 years later. Borrowed $460 million to buy 522,000 acres in 1988. Today company is nation's third-largest private landowner with more than 1.8 million acres of timberland, mostly in California. Planning to turn some of his ground into residential developments. Bought 147,000-acre Hamilton Tree Farm in Washington State out of bankruptcy 2006. Wears blue jeans, drives Chevy pick-up. Son Mark runs company's finances.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William's father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who "won" failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation's largest newspaper chain via sensational "yellow" journalism. Used papers to champion Spanish-American War; infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle, Houston Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire), cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV, radio stations. Company relocated to $700 million, 46-story "green" tower in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William’s father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who “won” failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation’s largest newspaper chain via sensational “yellow” journalism. Used papers to champion Spanish-American War; infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle, Houston Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire), cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV, radio stations. Company relocated to $700 million, 46-story "green" tower in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst. William’s father, George, was a prospector, land baron, U.S. senator who “won” failing San Francisco Examiner newspaper as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951), assumed control in 1887, built nation’s largest newspaper chain via sensational “yellow” journalism. Used papers to champion Spanish-American War; infamously portrayed by actor Orson Welles in Citizen Kane. Today Hearst Corp. controls newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle, Houston Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire), cable networks (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV, radio stations. Company relocated to $700 million, 46-story "green" tower in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Horn founded Cyrela Brazil Realty 1978; built it into largest developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Later expanded by inking development deals with partners in various regions of Brazil. Fortune continues to grow as many Brazilians, flush with cash, buy swank apartments. Horn also owns slice of agricultural investor BrasilAgro. A low-profile man known for giving 20% of his earnings to charity.
