name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,925 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. The Edmonton, Alta.-based Katz Group is also one of Canada's largest private companies. Starting in the 1990s, Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable execs to turn the chains around. Katz is now using the Rexall name to rebrand his stores. In early 2008 he clinched a deal to buy hockey's Edmonton Oilers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Senior statesman of Turkish industrialists ran Koc Group until 2003. Manages to find common ground with Greek, Israeli, Arab and American investors in his 65,000-employee conglomerate. Credited as driving force behind the expansion of Turkish economic interests in eastern Europe. Avid sailor spends months calling on ports around the world with his luxury yacht. Worked with Alexander Onassis Foundation to restore wall paintings in historic Antalya, Turkey church. Sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac share in family fortune (see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Mike Sr., immigrated to America 1914, settled in Colorado. Spun homemade mozzarella and ricotta for local customers 1950s. Son Jim joined family business at 18, transformed mom-and-pop outfit into world's largest producer of mozzarella. Today Leprino Foods can churn through 30 million pounds of milk each day across 11 plants in the U.S., Europe. Estimated sales: $2.3 billion. Biggest customers include Domino's Pizza, Papa John's, Pizza Hut. Also sells to Nestle for Hot Pockets, Stouffer's microwave pizzas. Loves the leftovers: market for company's excess whey and lactose swelling in Asia; by-products key ingredients in infant formula, soup mixes.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: After making early fortune in construction, got one of first Macau gaming licenses when market opened in 2002. British buyout firm Permina paid $835 million in October for 20% in his Galaxy Entertainment, which plans to open megaresort on Cotai strip in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell soup accountant took general manager post at 5-employee pet food firm Iams 1970. Became president, chief executive a decade later; bought company 1982. Expanded market share with premium puppy chow; focused on nutrition, high-end breeders. Sold out to Proctor & Gamble in 1999 for $2.3 billion. Wife runs Mathile Family Foundation. Also supports entrepreneurship through Dayton business center Aileron, single mothers through Dayton-area program The Glen. Donated $10 million to Ohio Northern University 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: The pachinko and slot-gambling company he founded, Aruze, is recovering from a slump. After four years of decreasing sales, the manufacturer expects to double its sales this year. Aruze has found success with new slot-machine models, and a new focus on overseas business in locales such as Macau. Owns part of Steve Wynn’s Macau business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built energy conglomerate Perez Companc and sold it to Brazilian energy giant Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. Now works to wring energy out of vegetables. Food and farming concern Molinos Rio de la Plata, of which he owns a controlling stake, operates massive soybean-crushing plant in the northeastern province of Santa Fe. Argentina’s answer to Kraft also deals in pasta, flour and frozen foods. Plus churns ice cream for wife Maria Carmen’s ice cream parlor chain, Munchi’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to split empire 11 ways, drawing lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Settled for $1 billion. Dynastic carve-up has begun. Sold minority stake in Hyatt to private equity firm Madrone Capital (owned by the Walton heirs) and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion last August. Then sold 60% stake in Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in December; Berkshire will buy the remainder of the company over the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile tycoon, transformed family's real estate outfit mainly through acquisitions, joint ventures with companies like Dutch ING Group. The Rajan Raheja Group has holding in Exide Industries, maker of automotive, industrial batteries; also owns Outlook Publishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to flip burgers. Saved money, invested in oil, real estate. Bought New Frontier Hotel and Casino, 41 acres of land on Las Vegas Strip for $165 million in 1998. Sold 34 acres for $1.2 billion to Elad Group (owners of Manhattan's Plaza Hotel) last June; deal the most expensive land sale in Sin City history. Kept 7 acres for condos. Partnered with Donald Trump (see) to build 64-story Trump International Hotel & Tower; duo split $500 million. Plans to build a second tower. Last August voters rejected a Kansas bill that would have allowed him to install slot machines at his Wichita Greyhound Park. Winner of The Forbes 400 poker game last summer; donated $125,000 pot to American Diabetes Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Turkey's Dogus Holding conglomerate. Lobbies hard for Turkey's inclusion in European Union. Dick Grasso look-alike lords over Garanti Bank and media properties capturing more than 10% of country's advertising market. Partner with General Electric and Volkswagen says he's worried that the U.S. economic crisis will depress the European economy, a key export market. Harvard Business School case study documents challenges in taking over his father's traditionally managed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Austrian national moved to Hong Kong 37 years ago. Married eldest daughter of late shipping magnate Y.K. Pao. Now steers shipping operations: his BW Group has one of world's largest fleets of oil tankers, gas carriers. Another Pao son-in-law, Peter Woo, a fellow billionaire, inherited Pao's Wheelock business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Became one of the leading marketers of replacement joints. Public 1979. Aging, active baby boomers boosting bottom line: net profits soared 21% to $778 million in 2006. Third generation controls 30% of company's shares. Jon gave $50 million to charity in 2006, active in liberal politics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded YTL Corp., one of Malaysia's largest conglomerates, with interests in construction, utilities, hotels, property development and technology. Its power unit has entered power transmission business in southern Australia. Son Francis runs YTL's daily operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother to mall magnate Majid Al Futtaim, Abdulla split from brother in 2000 and has since built up own conglomerate centered around autos and retail. Is United Arab Emirates' exclusive distributor for heavyweight brands such as IBM, Ikea and Toyota. Now expanding rapidly into real estate:  has lead role in construction of Dubai Festival City a 1,300-acre lifestyle resort due to be finished in 2015 at an estimated cost of $15 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former rice trader controls Malaysia Mining Corp. (MMC); has stakes in Malaysia's Johor Port; country's largest independent power producer Malakoff; natural gas distributor Gas Malaysia. Inking projects in Saudi Arabia, Jordan and on Malay-Thai border. Donates to Islamic schools, mosques, arts. The Albukhary Foundation offers full scholarships to students from poor countries to pursue tertiary education in Malaysia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Uncle Charles (d. 1994) founded investment boutique Allen & Co. in 1922; father, Herb Sr. (d. 1997) joined 5 years later. Herb came aboard 1962. Helped take Google public 2004. Host of famous annual media retreat in Sun Valley, Idaho. Secretive; believed to be giving portions of fortune to children. Family's fortune highly difficult to calculate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built riches on a marketing surprise. Met partner Min Kao at AlliedSignal, left and founded Garmin in 1989 to make navigation devices for aviation, boating, using newfangled Global Positioning System. Original office: 2 folding chairs and a card table. But U.S. Army servicemen loved GPS during Gulf war (though Garmin never had a military contract), and now in Iraq. In 1998 duo realized GPS could sell to directions-starved drivers on U.S. highways, too. Spouses stop bickering. Building third plant in Taiwan. Burrell retired as cochairman 2004, now chairman emeritus.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied accounting at U. of Southern California, practiced bean counting before moving to real estate 1975 with $1,000 savings. Built fortune on high-density inner-city apartment buildings in Los Angeles. Sold bulk of portfolio to Aimco in 2002 for $1 billion in cash, stock, assumed debt. Today owns gobs of office space, high-end apartments in L.A.; partnering with Aimco and Cerberus Real Estate in other L.A.-area projects. Donates money to alma mater, Jewish causes; now building an "American-style" condo tower in Tel Aviv, Israel. Personnel issues: a Casden exec pleaded guilty to taking a bribe, filing false tax return in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Main source of wealth is Zijin Mining, one of China's largest private sector mining outfits. Overseas investments include gold project in Tajikistan and copper and molybdenum mine in Peru.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter. Founded Sonae GSPS, maker of decorative laminates, in 1959. Later diversified into supermarkets, eventually becoming Portugal's biggest retailer through his Modelo Continente superstores and supermarket. Holds 53% stake in the now $7.3 billion (sales) company, which today has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper and a maker of wood panels. Has announced he is stepping down from active involvement in the company in favor of his son, Paulo, who will be the new CEO. Belmiro will be Chairman. Other son Nuno and daughter Claudia also work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974; built a stable of trade titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004. Launched celebrity magazine OK! in Britain in 1993. Bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. Planning to list his adult television channels this year. His $100 million launch of OK! in 2005 in the U.S. is paying off: made headlines with exclusive interview with Britney Spears' pregnant sister in December. In March launched OK! in Spain in rival Hello's territory; this follows a German edition earlier this year. For fun and charity, plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include folks from The Who and Led Zeppelin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fitness buff Diniz chairs $6.5 billion (sales) Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao, Brazil's largest retailer, which sells everything from food and clothing to TVs and appliances. His stake in the retailer increased in 2006 when his father, Valentim Diniz--who founded the company in 1948--divided his shares among his children. Abilio Diniz controls company with French food retailer Groupe Casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rupert Murdoch-like media kingpin of Turkey commands the largest share of country's advertising market. Target of large demonstrations in Istanbul protesting his ties to ruling Islamic political party, AKP. Also owns a large gasoline company, Petrol Ofisi. Charitable foundation supports literacy programs, but when it comes to speaking English, Dogan relies on help from his four daughters, two of whom have master's degrees from Columbia Business School and are expected to take over the family business. Avid walker and swimmer in his spare time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chess-playing Harvard grad got start as dealmaker for Goldman Sachs; named partner 1988. Founded J.C. Flowers & Co. buyout shop decade later. With Ripplewood Investments chief Timothy Collins, bought Long Term Credit Bank of Japan in 2000. Renamed Shinsei Bank, cut jobs, fixed balance sheet. Partners reaped $2.3 billion in 2004 public offering. Last year agreed to pay $25 billion for student loans firm Sallie Mae; deal later fell apart. Other investments: NIBC (Netherlands bank), Enstar Group (financial services).
title: Founder and Managing Director
employment: {'name': 'J.C. Flowers & Co. LLC', 'title': 'Founder and Managing Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
Owns 50% of Chadstone mall in Melbourne, the biggest in the southern
hemisphere; also owns 50% of Northland mall and a 20% stake in the property
trust that owns the other half of both malls. Started in retail in the 1950s
managing his Polish-immigrant parents1 Sussan women1s clothing chain. Sold
Sussan to his brother-in-law, soon after buying Chadstone in 1983. With his
wife collects Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Gerling Konzern, one of the world's largest reinsurers, from his father. The company, in which he had 94% stake, was sold to Germany's Talanx Group in November 2005 for estimated $1.6 billion. Now focuses on his Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Randstad Holding in 1960, now one the world's largest temporary employment agencies. Took company public in 1990. Owns 44% of the $12 billion (sales) company, which has branches in a dozen European and North American countries. Although retired, he remains vice chairman of the supervisory board. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his main holding company, Fosun International, public in August; at the time said it was 6th-most-oversubscribed offering in Hong Kong stock exchange history; reportedly attracted such investors as legendary Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing. Chairman and chief executive cofounded Fosun in 1992 with fellow Fudan University grads; soon moved into pharmaceuticals, real estate. Other interests now include iron, steel, retail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partner in Leon Black's (see) private equity company Apollo Management. Studied at U. of Pennsylvania; moved on to Harvard Business School. With Marc Rowan (see) took job in M&A department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, joined Black to create Apollo 1990. Claimed average annual return: 40%. Harris serves on Council of Foreign Affairs, American Israel Public Affairs Committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started privately held kretekmaker Djarum in 1950s. With brother Budi, turned it into one of the largest in Indonesia and the bestselling clove  cigarette brand in the U.S. Brothers also have stakes in Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest private bank. Property holdings include Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex under construction in the center of Jakarta. Rumored to be expanding family company into coal mining.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started privately held kretekmaker Djarum in 1950s. With brother Michael, turned it into one of the largest in Indonesia and the best-selling clove cigarette brand in the U.S. Brothers also have stakes in Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest private bank. Property holdings include Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex under construction in the center of Jakarta. Rumored to be expanding family company into coal mining.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained mathematician; former IBM software engineer. Cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues. Successfully built up the North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. Holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation supports cancer and AIDS research, art and historical preservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her five children, Gunter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from her late husband, coffee magnate Max Herz. Personally owns 15% of Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, the German consumer goods group her husband ran. Sons Michael, Wolfgang and Joachim own the rest. Daughter Daniela and son Gunter cashed out in 2003 after a nasty family feud.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Golden Resources Group is one of ChinaOs most successful property developers. Also operates a successful chain of hotels under his Empark brand and claims to own the largest shopping mall in the world. Considered to be a generous philanthropist. Published a book of his calligraphy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shades maven first hawked motorcycle grips from car trunk 1975. Moved to eyewear 1983. Shrewd marketer built brand enticing hotshot athletes to sport his trendy Oakley sunglasses. Emphasized style, cutting-edge lens technology; Oakley glasses are made of polycarbonate material that can withstand a shotgun blast. Now competing with Nike, expanding into sportswear, shoes. Company's headquarters dubbed the "design bunker" for its 600,000-square-foot reinforced blast walls. Agreed to sell company to Italian rival Luxottica for $2.1 billion last June. Deal will close this year; Jannard will stay on as "chief mad scientist."

name: Billionaires
bio:
After studying construction and finance in Moscow secondary schools, got a
job at the privately held BIN Bank. Then went to the Slavneft, an oil
company, then led by fellow billionaire Mikhail Gutseriev. Between 2001 and
2003, Khachaturov and his partners spent $60 million buying the insolvent
insurance giant Rosgosstrakh from the government. Managed to transform the
Soviet-era company into one of the highest-volume Russian insurers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ankara-born philanthropist shares Koc Group fortune with brother Rahmi Koc and sister Suna Kirac (see both) . Holds board seat at conglomerate but does not manage any business unit. Because of parasite in her blood spent years fighting illness in hospitals around the world; the experience moved her to build nursing education and research center in Turkey and to marry a doctor. Fluent in English and German.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of 4 sons of Fred Koch, MIT grad who invented method of refining gasoline from heavy oil. Expanded oil industry in U.S.S.R. 1930s; returned home before World War II. Founded Koch Industries, passed on to sons after death in 1967. Bill attended MIT. With brother Frederick, sold stake to brothers Charles and David (see both) for $1.3 billion 1983. Later had buyer's remorse; sued duo for larger sum, eventually settled. Reinvested via Oxbow holding company: petroleum coke, coal, natural gas. Art collector owns works by Picasso, Matisse and Renoir.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has run $158 billion (sales) Samsung Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, for two decades. Credited with turning sleepy conglomerate into one of the world's most recognized, high-quality electronics brands. Last year particularly tumultous for Lee: In November 2007, a former Samsung employee accused Samsung of using a reported $215 million in company money to create a slush fund intended to bribe politcians and prosecutors. In January 2008, Korean agents raided the Chairman's Seoul office, looking for evidence of such claims. Lee's wife, Hong Ra-hee, director-general of the Leeum art museum in Seoul, has also been accused of using some of the money to buy expensive paintings. Samsung denies all claims. Further blow occurred in late January when a Seoul court ordered Samsung Group to pay a reported $2.4 billion to creditors of the conglomerate's failed auto unit, in Korea's largest civil court action. Samsung is considering an appeal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korea's richest woman is Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee's younger sister. Chairs retailing group Shinsegae, which operates department and discount stores throughout the country. Caught up in the unfolding scandal involving Samsung: Lee, along with other Samsung-affiliated people, has been accused of illicitly buying millions of dollars' worth of artworks, using Samsung Group money.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable buyout maven putting the money men of The Forbes 400 to work. Founded Blue Star hedge fund of funds in 1999. Today outfit believed to be one of the world's best-performing fund of funds; said to have returned 43% net of fees in year ending last July 31. Harvard grad built fortune on inheritance. Bought Snapple for $135 million in 1992, sold 2 years later for $1.7 billion to Quaker Oats. Now does deals through Lee Equity Partners; owns stakes in Dunkin' Donuts, Warner Music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born the son of a farmer in Chinas Zhejiang. Started out with a small bicycle-repair shop. Today his Wanxiang Group has 40,000 employees worldwide and annual sales of more than $4 billion. Main businesses are auto parts, agriculture, real estate, metals, finance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Hendrik, emigrated from the Netherlands 1907; settled in Michigan. Worked as a barber until Depression reduced clientele. Opened Meijer Grocery 1934 with son Frederik; kept prices low. Duo launched Meijer Thrifty Acres in 1962. Store believed to be one of first to offer "one-stop shopping"; sold food, general merchandise under same roof. Wal-Mart opened same year. Penny-pinching Frederik took helm following father's death in 1963. Today Meijer operates 181 stores across 5 states. Son Doug is cochairman; son Hendrik Jr. is chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio:
South African-born Neilson made his name as an investment guru by
sidestepping the 1987 global equities market crash at bt Australia, the
Australian arm of Bankers Trust where he worked as a fund manager. He left
bt in 1993 to start his own boutique funds management group, Platinum Asset
Management, with George Soros as a client and founding shareholder. Listed
25% of Platinum on the stock market in May. He and his wife are opening up
an art gallery in Sydney to showcase Chinese contemporary art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began career as a textiles trader in Hong Kong. Expanded to Macau to obtain export quotas and branched into property investments. With wife and son now runs Kowloon Development. Last year bought land in northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang; announced plans to partner on project in Tianjin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known to her friends as Lottie, she is the second-largest shareholder of Hennes & Mauritz, the successful Swedish clothing retail chain founded by her father, Erling, in 1947 and now run by her brother Stefan (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: With Stephen Schwarzman and Hamilton James, took investment house Blackstone public in June; shares down 50% since. Company sold just under 10% stake to Chinese government weeks before the offering. Wall Street giant manages nearly $100 billion across private equity, real estate, corporate debt, hedge fund operations. Schwarzman and Peterson cofounded Blackstone Group 1985 with $400,000. Net profits in 2006: $2.3 billion. Paid $39 billion for Sam Zell's Equity Office Properties last February, then agreed to buy Hilton Hotels for $26 billion last July. Peterson studied at Northwestern, then M.B.A. from U. of Chicago. Commerce Secretary under Nixon, became chairman of Lehman Brothers 1973. Forced out a decade later. Headed the Federal Reserve Bank of New York 2000 to 2004. Plans to officially retire from Blackstone by the end of the year. Giving it away: recently unveiled Peter G. Peterson Foundation, plans to give perhaps $1 billion of his own money to fight rising healthcare costs, trade and budget deficits, unsustainable energy consumption, education woes. Named U.S. Comptroller General David Walker to serve as president and CEO of the Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale economics student wrote senior thesis on what would become Federal Express. Tome focused on improving overnight delivery services using integrated network of planes and trucks. Marine in Vietnam, then worked as crop-dusting pilot. Bought small stake in Arkansas aviation firm. With venture capital and family money launched Federal Express 1973.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn-born son of a bricklayer made big bet on 9 West 57th Street, today one of New York City's best commercial addresses; building is home to several high profile hedge funds, commands rents of more than $200 a foot. Also owns luxury apartments on Upper East Side. Still waiting on approval to redevelop a parcel on Manhattan's East River into 4 million square feet of residential, commercial and retail space. Avid art collector recently donated 2 floors of a New York City townhouse to Institute of Fine Arts of New York University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father fled Nazi Germany. Jerry studied German literature at Columbia, later joined father-in-law Robert Tishman's realty firm. Divorced the daughter, but Speyer and Tishman continued to work together; created Tishman Speyer in 1978. Company now a global real estate powerhouse: owns New York's Chrysler Building and Rockefeller Center, purchased Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartment and retail complex for $5.4 billion from MetLife in 2006. Family business: wife, Katherine, runs company's emerging markets division; recently announced it will build a $2 billion town in India. One of the first American developers to enter German market. Son and daughter also work for firm. Art collector elected chairman of the Museum of Modern Art in May. Also chairs Federal Reserve Bank of New York's board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in Pittsburgh; "Never got an A in high school." Earned M.B.A. from Carnegie Mellon. Ran junk bond desk at Goldman Sachs, failed to become a partner. Left to start hedge fund Appaloosa Management in 1992. Fund up 150% in 2003; believed to have averaged 30% returns net of fees since inception.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Viessmann Werke GmbH, $2 billion (sales) maker of boilers and heating equipment. Grandfather founded group over 90 years ago. Company set up Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula One racing. Viessmann is president of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University. Holds professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Sun Microsystems; an inventor of Cisco Systems's switching business. Co-founded and ran Kealia, a computer design system, sold to Sun in 2004. Now back at Sun Microsystems as senior vice president and chief architect. Early backer of Google: his initial $100,000 investment is now worth $1.7 billion. Also has stake in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation. Reportedly lives alone in a small Palo Alto, Calif. apartment.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Great grandfather (d. 1932) moved from Philadelphia to Chicago to sell soap; offered baking powder as incentive. Began offering chewing gum instead of baking powder. Founded Wrigley Company 1891; introduced first spearmint chewables 
2 years later. Sent stick of gum to every person in U.S. phone book 1915. Fourth-generation Wrigley now runs the operation.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and largest shareholder of RMK, Russia's third-largest copper producer, which is thriving as copper prices have hit new highs in recent years. This entrepreneur from Ekaterinburg reportedly had the cash to buy a London mansion from Madonna and her husband, Guy Ritchie, several years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of a Guangdong Province army officer and eldest of eight children. A finance job at a foreign paper-products trading company gave her the idea to start her own business. In 1985 she moved to Hong Kong and, with $4,000 in savings, set up a company importing waste paper. Five years later she and her husband, a Taiwan-born Brazilian national, trained as a dentist, traveled to California to open a paper recycler that would ship its output to China. In 1995 she returned to China and, with her husband and brother, started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons (whose name implies ?highest fortune?), of which she is chairman. It went public in March 2006; now all three are billionaires. Hopes the business will stay in the family for ?100 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Huabao International, which makes fragrances and flavorings for use in cigarettes, detergents, beverages, dairy products and cosmetics. Founded the company a decade ago and took it public through a backdoor listing. Sold 9% earlier this year; still owns two-thirds of shares. Holds several leadership positions in local industry groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ashmore Group, a London fund manager specializing in emerging market debt with $32 billion under management. Took company public 2006, raising $2 billion. Started career at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group and rose through the ranks of the emerging-market division. Launched what is now Ashmore in 1992 with other ANZ Group alumni; officially became independent in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: HCA founder took nation's largest hospital operator private with Bain Capital, KKR and Merrill Lynch in 2006. At the time the $33 billion leveraged buyout was largest in history; eclipsed by $45 billion purchase of power giant TXU 4 months later. Nashville native served as an Air Force flight surgeon. With father founded Hospital Corp. of America 1968; took public 1969. Merged with Richard Rainwater's (see) Columbia Hospital Corp., stepped down 1994. Came out of retirement to revive HCA during fraud investigation. Still plays large role in strategy. Thrilled to be private: "Thank goodness I'm not in the market now."

name: Billionaires
bio:
Opened a wholesale business that sold perfume and beauty supplies in 1994 in
his southern hometown of Krasnodar. An admirer of Wal-Mart, in 1998
established Magnit, a chain of grocery stores with the slogan "Always Low
Prices." Took the company public in April 2006; he owns 58%. To Magnit's
nearly 2,000 stores Galitsky is adding several hypermarkets around the
country. Loves Ferraris and extremely expensive watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil tycoon has braved war and corruption to build an empire on the cheap. Starting as an oil trader in the 1970s, Gandur made friends with West African potentates like Nigeria's Sani Abacha and later moved crude for Saddam Hussein. Today his 25%-owned Addax Petroleum produces 100,000 bbl per day from fields offshore from Nigeria and Sao Tome. His Oryx brand stores petroleum products and sells cooking gas across Africa. Shortly after Saddam's fall Gandur cut deals to explore oil fields in the Kurdistan region of Iraq; a series of gushers at the Taq Taq field have followed. His collection of Egyptian antiquities is among the best in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Joyce C. Hall (d. 1982) turned fuzzy feelings into hard cash. Started selling greeting cards while living at Kansas City YMCA at age 18; founded postcard manufacturer Hallmark in 1910. Donald took over 1966, expanded into crayons (Crayola), TV (Hallmark Channel), real estate (Crown Center Shopping Complex). Now world’s largest greeting card company. With sisters owns 65% of company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has been making air conditioners for 22 years through his Midea Group; also makes refrigerators, washing machines. Thriving thanks to more home ownership, rising middle-class incomes. Goldman Sachs tried to buy 11% of Guangdong Midea Electric, part of Midea Group, but was stymied by government. He and family also have stakes in three other groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean war vet became sales rep for Miles Laboratories; earned law degree at night from DePaul U. Partnered with Phillip Frost 1972, acquired Key Pharmaceuticals. Increased sales from $2 million to $200 million with top asthma drug and cardiovascular patch; sold to Schering-Plough for $836 million in 1986. Launched Kos Pharmaceuticals 2 years later, invested $200 million to develop and commercialize cholesterol drugs. Public 1997; dominated market with Niaspan, which raises good cholesterol. Sold to Abbott Labs for $4.2 billion in 2006; added $700 million to fortune. Now oversees private equity firm Vatera Capital; focused on life sciences investments. Greek culture enthusiast supports medical and nutrition research at Tufts U.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In the 1990s was good friends with Vladimir Putin when the future president
was vice mayor of St. Petersburg. Their country houses were both in the
Ozerki dacha cooperative, and when Putin became president many of Ozerki's
members saw their careers improve. Now the largest shareholder of Rossiya
bank, which controls insurance company Sogas,one of the largest in Russia;
its main client is gas behemoth Gazprom. Also has 40% of Gazprombank, the
third-largest bank in the country in terms of capital; Gazprom is also its
main client. Plus has several media holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Taiwan; got a degree in dental surgery from the University of Santa Amaro in Brazil in 1983.  Met his wife Yan Cheung in Hong Kong. Moved with her to the U.S. in 1990 where they set up a paper recycling business. Later returned to China and started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons with his wife and brother-in-law. Company went public March 2006. All three are now billionaires. Flags from China, the United States and Brazil hang outside their corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: With three brothers, Liu started Hope Group 1982 with about $120; eventually became China's second-largest animal feed maker. In 1999 restructured into four entities, each owned by a brother. Liu relocated from Sichuan to Shanghai; renamed his part East Hope Group. Still makes more than 100 types of animal feed; operates two aluminum smelters. Liu also spending time managing interests in China Minsheng Banking, Bright Dairy etc.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded investment research firm Morningstar with $80,000 in 1984; cultivated quarterly publication into analysis giant famous for its 5-star ratings. Took public in 2005. Company bought InvestorForce's institutional hedge fund and separate account database division for $10 million in 2006; then added Standard & Poor's mutual fund database for $55 million last March. U. of Chicago grad personally purchased Fast Company and Inc. magazines from Gruner & Jahr for $35 million a few years ago. Works in cubicle alongside employees.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Brewmaster of Turkey created one of the country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. Reprised Donald Trump's role on the Turkish version of The Apprentice TV show. He and fellow billionaire Yazici control 38-year-old Anadolu Group conglomerate. Second-generation partnership with Yazici family continues as the group rapidly expands into Russia and former Soviet republics. Also a car guy: makes Isuzus in Turkish plants and imports to Turkey Lada and Kia cars made in Russia and Korea to then be distributed in Ukraine and central Asian countries. Ex-basketball player never misses Efes Pilsen basketball club's games. He has a 3,000-piece pen collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: After World War II he and brother, Paul, set about rebuilding family's candy company. Brothers still run the now $2.2 billion (estimated sales) confectioner Haribo. Hans is often the one to concoct new products and is credited with inventing more than 200 confections including Goldbaren, Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Apparently gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. A bachelor with no children, at 85 Hans has yet to name a replacement after reportedly falling-out with heir apparent, nephew Hans-Jurgen Riegel, who has left the company

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Nicholas (see) while working in chip design at TRW. Duo formed Broadcom 1991 using Nicholas' spare bedroom to design high-speed telecom chips. Went public 1998. Nicholas unexpectedly quit as CEO in 2003; now company blames him for stock-options backdating. Restated earnings, cutting 2006 profits $2.2 billion, to $3.7 billion, for 7 years of shenanigans.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-Ho serves as vice chairman of the $33 billion (sales) Lotte Korea, a web of dozens of companies spanning such industries as retail, food, petrochemicals, construction, and theme parks. Born in Japan; moved to Korea in the 1990s. Seen as father’s eventual successor. Relatively unassuming among sons of fortune; shuns flashy stuff. One of his favorite wines is affordable Australian Yellow Tail. Brother and fellow billionaire Shin Dong Joo is vice president of much smaller Lotte Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former salesman for Oracle left 1990 after chief Larry Ellison (see) ditched plans to bring Siebel&#39s sales-tracking software to market. Founded Siebel Systems 1993, took public 1996. Struggled through tech downturn, then grudge match vs. Ellison ended badly: Siebel quits, his creation gets sold to Oracle in 2006 for $5.9 billion. Siebel&#39s salve: his stake brings $500 million in cash. Funds computer science grad students; also supports Salvation Army and an intentionally scary ad campaign on the horrors of methamphetamine addictionÑin Montana (where half of the 2,100 kids in foster care were there because of parents&#39 meth habit). Last June donated $100 million to alma mater University of Illinois to create fund focused on alternative energy, bioengineering, stem-cell research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began trading shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil. With Kuok Khoon Hong, the nephew of longtime Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok, bought a plantation in Sumatra that became basis of publicly traded palm oil company Wilmar International. Merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007, turning Wilmar into one of the world's largest palm oil producers. Deal boosted stock and turned Sitorus and his cofounder into billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Newspaper entrepreneur bought shares in chemical company Dwory; funded expansion with debt, taking advantage of low interest rates. Diversified into ceramic tiles, wood floors and real estate. Gave up any management roles two years ago but is still an active investor on Warsaw Stock Exchange. Stakes in ceramic maker Cersanit, developer Echo Investment, flooring company Barlinek and chemical company Synthos are down this year. Avid race car driver, races 20 days a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Became one of the leading marketers of replacement joints. Public 1979. Aging, active baby boomers boosting bottom line: net profits soared 21% to $778 million in 2006. Third generation controls 30% of company's shares. Pat founded Bohemian Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford M.B.A. took the reins of Enka Construction from his father, Sarik Tara (see), at age 26. Under contract to build a nuclear power plant in Turkish capital of Ankara. Took initiative to use family foundation funds to start Enka Schools, a private school in Istanbul that accommodates 2,000 from pre-kindergarten to grade 12. Known for his modest character, his office has bare white walls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sultan of sound formed firm 43 years ago, yet today it thrives on the latest in iPod speaker docks, home theater systems, noise-killing headphones. Sales: $2 billion. He started repairing radios in high school to help family after WWII hurt his father's import business. Earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT, stayed on faculty. Began research in hi-fi sound. Founded Bose Corp. 1964; first contracts with NASA, U.S. military, to improve radio communications. Built brand on groundbreaking loudspeaker design. Owns 60% stake; wears name tag to office so employees know who he is. Enjoys badminton. Will leave fortune to independent research institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father served in the pacific during WWII; founded logistics outfit William E. Connor & Associates in Tokyo 1949. "Chip" took reins 1980s, moved operations to Hong Kong. Manages entire supply chain, from factory production to selling floor or distribution center; helps merchants eliminate trading companies, brokers, other middlemen. Primarily focused on apparel and home products. Customers include Nordstrom, Williams-Sonoma, Saks, Neiman Marcus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Philip (d. 2004), ran investment firm, built reputation with buy-and-hold philosophy, early tech investments. Ken went to Humboldt State U. to study forestry, graduated with degree in economics. Worked for dad after college; struck out on own 1973. Father of the price/sales ratio. Author (Super Stocks; The Only Three Questions That Count), long-running FORBES columnist runs Fisher Investments. History buff; supports studies on coastal redwood trees. Owns $100 million in California real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still runs the consumer finance company, Aiful, that he began more than 40 years ago when he was just a teenager. His business acumen has lately been put to the test as a government crackdown on lending, sparked by allegations of heavy-handed debt collection, has halved maximum interest rates to 20%. In 2007 profits at Fukuda’s company and other consumer finance lenders were further crimped by a court ruling that forced them to repay customers they had overcharged.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of poor preacher worked at local 5-and-10 store in high school. Later spent days managing TG&Y discount store, nights making wooden frames in garage with wife. Opened first Hobby Lobby store with $600 loan 1970. Sales now $1.8 billion. Highly religious: keeps stores closed on Sundays, plays contemporary Christian music in background. Donated $11 million electronics plant to the late Jerry Falwell; Liberty U. founder converted building into new law school and church. Has delivered more than 300 million copies of gospel to children in 100 countries through the Book of Hope ministry.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad made plastic egg cartons during 1960s before buying a styrene plant 1970. Turned Huntsman Corp. from fast-food container supplier into nation's largest private chemical company via acquisitions. Rising oil prices squeezed profits; forced to give up 49% of firm to settle debts with creditors. Took public 2004; personally netted $275 million. Devout Mormon used proceeds to buy land in Idaho, Utah; donated rest to cancer research. Sold company to Leon Black's (see) private equity group Apollo Management last July for $10.6 billion after turning down lower offer from Russian-American billionaire Leonard Blavatnik (see). Son Peter expanding Huntsman into Asia; son Jon Jr. governor of Utah.

name: Billionaires
bio: MIT engineer turned father's small forgingsmaker into world's second largest. His Bharat Forge has factories in India, Europe, U.S., China. Customers include Ford, Toyota, BMW. Also has interests in steel, wind energy. Recently survived helicopter crash. Owns two Harley-Davidson motorcycles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Money man emigrated from Moscow with his parents to U.S. 1976; became U.S. citizen. Returned to Russia mid-1990s to head Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. Became chief of Alfa Bank. Today invests via Pamplona Capital Management. Lives in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of the Magnitogorsk Iron and Metals Institute, worked for 35 years at the Silvinit fertilizer factory and in 1990 became head of the company; his stake in the company comprises the bulk of his fortune. Today the factory, located in the city of Solikamsk in Russia’s Perm region (in the Urals), is the second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manhattan-born Wharton grad joined father's cosmetics and hair care products company 1958. Eventually took over, developed new contact lens design before selling out to Cooper Labs for $60 million in 1971. Created Vision Cable; acquired New Jersey cable licenses, built 230,000 subscriber base in 6 states. Sold operation to Newhouse brothers (see) for $220 million 1982. Later built cell phone outfit Metro Mobile, sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion 1991. Now lords over natural gas transporter Southern Union; with family, owns stake worth $525 million. Current investment strategy: "I give my money to Ron Baron (see) and blindly trust it will go up 15% a year. It usually does."

name: Billionaires
bio: A former amateur boxer, founded ABC-Mart two decades ago and turned it into one of Japan’s biggest footwear wholesalers and retailers with more than 367 stores. Stepped down as chairman in August 2007. Formerly the second-largest shareholder in Tokyo Broadcasting System (TBS) through his real estate firm EM Planning, cut his stake down from almost 10% to 3.35% last year. May have sold off to avoid getting further embroiled in proxy fight between TBS and fellow billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Samueli (see) while working in chip design at TRW. Formed Broadcom 1991, using Nicholas' spare bedroom to design high-speed telecom chips. Went public 1998. Nicholas unexpectedly quit as CEO in 2003. Now company blames him for stock-options backdating. Restated earnings, cut 2006 profits $2.2 billion, to $3.7 billion, for 7 years of shenanigans.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Holds 11% of Spain's largest construction company, $20 billion (2006 sales) A.C.S. (Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A.), which he has headed since 1993. Well known as onetime president of popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane; ran the club from 2000 to 2006. Resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats, despite initial successes and once-stellar players

name: Billionaires
bio:
Raised in gold-mining town in central Australia. Quit school at 14 to sell
hand-carved handkerchief boxes. Dabbled in plumbing, construction, a small
airline and ice-skating ventures. His best cash business came as a
going-away gift in 1962 when he stepped down from his job as a manager for
an earthmoving outfit. The company chairman gave Perron Toyota franchise
rights, allowing Perron to set up dealerships in western Australia. Perron
says he tried to give it away, but "nobody wanted it." I Still selling Toyota
vehicles decades later; also owns Australian shopping malls. Pops into the
office for a few hours each week but leaves most of the day-to-day decisions
to a small band of loyal staff.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Joseph, ran pharmacy in Brooklyn. Stewart took over after dropping out of law school 1975, moved to Queens. Today Kinray's highly automated operation supplies more than 3,000 independent pharmacies in 8 northeastern states. Sales: $4.4 billion. Rumored to be shopping company to rivals. In 2005 purchased 25-room Hamptons mansion, Burnt Point, for $45 million; uses spread to entertain celebrity friends with lavish summer barbecues. Donated $1 million to New York chapter of Make-A-Wish Foundation last June.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fashionista sister of Ferit Sahenk and heir to Dogus Holding fortune built by father, Ayhan. Has handled retail partnerships with luxury brands Tods and Armani. Advocate of women's leadership and one of Turkey's top 100 taxpayers. Also holds title of president at family's active charitable foundation, the sponsor of well-known three-day annual international mountain bike festival in Turkey's Cappadocia region. Active in the International Myeloma Foundation. Also has a huge antique collection.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Graduate of Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of
Russia's tycoons attended. Worked as an economist in the Central Research
Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 started a joint venture in
scrap-metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank, one of
Russia's largest banks. Then started buying up shares in pipe producer
Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant (VMP), a factory in the Urals region that was
founded in 1757; by 1999 Sedykh and his partners were controlling
shareholders. Later established the United Metallurgical Company, Russia's
second-largest pipe producer and its largest maker of railway wheels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Shin Kyuk-Ho is vice president of $4.2 billion (sales) Lotte Japan and lives in Tokyo. Sits on boards of Lotte Chilsung Beverage, Lotte Hotel and Lotte Aluminum. Reportedly will take over Lotte Japan when father retires. Younger brother Shin Dong Bin is vice chairman of much larger Lotte Korea.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian-born financier created shop bot Junglee; sold to Amazon in 1998. Worked for Netscape, Amazon before creating venture firm Sherpalo in 2000. Early investor, board member of Google has sold more than 3 million shares since 2004 public offering. Today backs Indian, U.S. tech outfits: 24/7 Customer, Frontline Wireless, Zazzle.com. Sold online classifieds site StumbleUpon.com to Ebay in 2007; owns similar Indian site Naukri.com.
title: Managing Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 71.5% of $3.8 billion (sales) Hunter Douglas Group, a Netherlands company that manufactures and markets window coverings and architectural products. Father, Henry Sonnenberg, founded the group in 1919 as a machine-tool manufacturing and distribution company, eventually developing new technology for the production of lightweight aluminum slats for Venetian blinds. Ralph Sonnenberg has been CEO since 1971. Heirs apparent, sons Marko and David, work alongside their father in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Kazakhstan's largest bank, Kazkommertsbank, which went public in 2006. Via his stake in Central Asian Investment Company, has interests in oil and gas, energy, telecommunications, transportation and media companies in Kazakhstan. Attended Moscow State University with fellow billionaire Timur Kulibaev, with whom he maintains important political ties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Daito Trust Construction, a property developer specializing in rental apartments. Groupfs net income doubled over the past five years to $396 million as demand for rental units in Japan has burgeoned. May soon exit the business though as rival investors, including Aetos Capital, a consortium that includes Japanfs richest man Akira Morifs company, make offers to acquire his third of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Workaholic sign seller dropped out of U. of Nebraska to join Merchant Marine Academy. Served in South Pacific during WWII. Took over family's Whiteco Industries 1946. Expanded 5-person operation into vast billboard and real estate empire. Sold billboard division to Chancellor Media Corp. for $960 million 1998. With partners sold off 100 hotels to billionaire media mogul Robert Johnson for $1.7 billion in 2006. Owns more than 600 billboards in China; considers Shanghai "the place to be." Also owns apartment communities from Denver to Danbury, Conn. Airplane junkie recently purchased a Falcon 7X jet.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a boy worked at his father's little grocery store in Istanbul and learned how to trade. Founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks, and holder of a 40% stake in all seven of Coca-Cola's Turkish bottling and distribution companies. Longtime business partner of fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan (see). Got to watch his Efes Pilsen basketball club win the European championship in 1996 and 2000. Has helped open thousands of summer sports camps throughout Turkey to generate interest in basketball.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime pharmacist sold family pharmaceutical business 1985; invested proceeds in several industries, from banking to textiles. Accumulated 10% stake of construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, of which he is a vice president. Often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. Known for his valuable art collection which includes works by Edgar Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Salvador Dali and Van Gogh, among others. Enthusiastic hunter; enjoys bullfights, soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sidney, ran family's shoemaking operation, invested in Florida real estate. Ed preferred the limelight. With dad, bought Miami TV station in 1962 for $3.4 million. Took over 1971. Dropped NBC affiliation in 1989, revamped as tabloid news station; heavy emphasis on crime, consumer stories. Later added 2 competing Boston stations. Today son Andrew manages real estate investments: 4.5 million square feet of commercial property, mostly in Broward County, Fla. Has no plans to diversify: "I don't plan to cash out. That's for my heirs to worry about."
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Second-generation Greek-American born in Detroit, raised in Pasadena, Calif. Studied business and economics at Michigan State. Graduated to real estate 1962. Sold land at busy intersections to oil companies to set up gas stations. Today privately held Arnel & Affiliates owns, manages 5,200 apartments and 2.5 million square feet of commercial space. Founded private equity firm Westar Capital 1987; invests in pet products (Doskocil), coolers (Igloo), auto technology (Amerigon). Former U.S. ambassador to Spain raising money for John McCain's presidential run; enjoys sailing, skiing, hunting.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund guru grew up in Raleigh, N.C.; father worked in real estate. Studied literature at Middlebury College. Hired as fishing-boat captain by former NYSE board member Walter Frank; Wall Street veteran encouraged him to go to Columbia business school. Founded Moore Capital in 1989; returned 86% in first year on savvy bet that Gulf war would drive up oil prices. Hunter stalks game on 453-acre Robins Island in Long Island's Peconic Bay; bought Forbes family's 250-square-mile Trinchera Ranch in Colorado for a reported $175 million last year. Tied the knot last February with longtime girlfriend, art consultant Gabrielle de Heinrich Sacconaghi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former banker has managed to largely keep out of the news since he sold Banco Bozano Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano in 2000. In 2006 reportedly sold stakes in coffee plantation and Rio de Janeiro shopping center to new Brazilian investment fund. Has a 9% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer. Said to love racing horses and live in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amicably split with older brother, Richard in late 2006 after running investment portfolio Sovereign Global together for 20 years; each took half the assets. His new investment company, Legatum, has invested heavily in India's beverage and financial services industries. Big believer in social investing: in September launched $50 million venture with MIT to support aspiring entrepreneurs from developing countries. Raised on New Zealand farm, mother was Croatian, father once worked as a beekeeper before founding a department store.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amicably split with younger brother Christopher in late 2006 after running investment portfolio Sovereign Global together for 20 years; each took half the assets. His new venture, Orient Global, has largely picked up where Sovereign left off; focusing on long-term value investments in financial and social businesses. Recently made donation to late explorer Sir Edmund Hillary's charitable foundation to support schools in Nepal. Hillary was old family friend of Chandler brothers' father, a beekeeper turned department store owner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall mogul father bought Notre Dame grad pro football's San Francisco 49ers in 1977; team won 4 Super Bowls between 1982 and 1990. Eddie Jr. forced to exchange team with sister Denise DeBartolo York for large stake in Simon Property Group following federal bribery conviction in 2000. Today owns 15.5 million SPG shares. Back in the game: new sports agency represents Heisman Trophy winning quarterback Troy Smith. Ohio native still focused on real estate; developing $1.4 billion worth of apartments, shopping centers across the U.S. Other holdings: pizza, water pumps.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alpha dog at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers funded famed tech pups in 1990s: Intuit, Amazon, Netscape. But Google made him truly rich. Studied electrical engineering at Rice U., then Harvard M.B.A. Invested $1.4 million in a few nerds from Stanford 1980s: Sun Microsystems. Next big idea: green tech. Also fights poverty, AIDS in Africa. Helped recruit new KPCB partner Al Gore.
title: Partner
employment: {'name': 'Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers', 'title': 'Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied geology at an oil-and-gas university in Moscow. Sensing deep demand in post-Soviet Russia's deteriorating oil sector, set up an oil-services firm, PetroAlliance, in 1995. In 2003 sold PetroAlliance to oil-services giant Schlumberger. A year later, with Russian oil companies consolidating and shedding assets, teamed up with partners including former Halliburton managers to buy Lukoil's well-drilling business. The firm, Eurasia Drilling Co., is the largest independent oil-services outfit in Russia and listed in London last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native Minnesotan grew up playing hockey with eight siblings. Continued skating at Harvard, then went pro in Europe. Leg injury cut career short. Returned to US, started at Kidder, Peabody & Co. junk bond desk 1985. Spent time in junk bonds departments at Wachovia, Barclay. Founded Harbinger Capital Partners in 2001 with $25 million. Firm now manages two funds totalling $18 billion. Made fortune betting against sub-prime last year; his two funds boasted 114% and 176% returns in 2007. Also big gains in mining markets. Prefers hiring former athletes. Pet pot-bellied pig named "Pickles" has own room in his Manhattan townhouse. Minority owner of hockey's Minnesota Wild.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Started his company Linfox by driving its only truck in 1956. Today Linfox,
which he owns entirely, is one of the largest logistics companies in the
country, with more than $1.8 billion in sales and 20,000 employees. (His
business card is shaped like a truck.) Also owns a wide variety of
businesses, including airports, property development operations, car
dealerships and a security business. Has an extensive car collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean immigrant runs Maruhan, Japan’s biggest operator of pachinko gambling parlors with more than 220 locations and sales of $17 billion. As tighter restrictions squeeze the gaming industry, Han has diversified. In October 2007, the group spent $100 million to buy stakes in Macau Success and its subsidiary World of Fortune, gaming companies that also operate cruise ships and a travel business in Macau. Also has Mister Donut and Seattle coffee chain, Zoka, franchises. Classical music fan and art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father and uncle were both geologists; duo ran small oil and gas firm until late 1970s. Headington played tennis at U. of Oklahoma; took over operation following father's death 1977. Today Headington Oil produces more than 7 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalent each year. Pushing into new territory; drilling Bakken formation in North Dakota and Elm Coulee field in Montana. Supporter of Dallas art scene spending $500,000 to rescue historic mosaics from Mercantile Building. Also building stylish Joule Hotel. Going Hollywood: financing The Young Victoria, flick based on life of British queen set to open late 2008. Academy Award-winning director Martin Scorsese is one of film's executive producers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Banamex bank made almost $2 billion in 2001, when he sold the bank to Citigroup. Today, owns more than 14 million Citigroup shares, which suffered in 2007. Citigroup is still taking care of Hernandez, a director. Last year the bank gave him $2,867,000 worth of security services as well as usage of an office, secretary, airplane and helicopter. Owns luxury resorts on the Yucatan Peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built enterprise started by his father, the Far Eastern Group, into a conglomerate with 180 affiliated companies in ten industries, including textiles, cement, retailing. Indicted for forgery and breach of trust in 2006, denies any wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Over two decades transformed small commercial real estate construction firm in St. Petersburg, Russia into the 61st international contracting company in the world. His Renaissance Construction employs 15,000 and has lucrative contracts for 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia. Earned graduate degree from University of Minnesota-University of Vienna joint program and went on to collect a Ph.D. from International School of Management in France. Self-described family man spends free time reading books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emigrated from Korea to U.S. 1955, started Amkor Electronics 1968 as U.S. sales and design partner of father H.S. Kim’s Anam, Korean semiconductor maker. Took public 30 years later; family still holds 45% of stock. Sales up 30% last year to $2.7 billion. Restated 7 years of finances last summer for backdating of stock options. Former Amkor general counsel awaits trial on insider trading charges. Made second fortune in videogames. With wife, Agnes, started Electronics Boutique retail chain 1977; first mall kiosk sold calculators, digital watches. Sold in 2005 to GameStop for $1.4 billion; couple got $375 million. Donates to educational, cultural institutions.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Born in then Soviet Republic of Estonia and graduated from the Moscow Power
Engineering Institute; served as commercial director at a small firm founded
with the institute's help. In 1992 was hired by Alfa Group to oversee
establishment of a privatization-investment fund; months later became chief
executive of Alfa Capital, the group's fund-management company. After
expanding Alfa Capital became responsible for all of the bank's investment
units. Also board chairman of Alfa's Altimo telecom-holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of auto dealer quit job to sell used computers after placing $3 ad in Chicago Tribune to sell old PC. Reaped $300 profit on 2nd sale. Saw potential in discount computer sales, founded Computer Discount Warehouse 1984. Skilled negotiator brought used-car sales tactics to computer industry by offering salespeople high incentives. Retired 2001; today CDW Corp. sells $7 billion of computer gear. Company sold to private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in October. Last June Kransy donated more than $350 million in CDW shares to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Bought out majority partner in 2000; today owns 95% of company. Hit jackpot when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991. Today group has five permanent shows in Sin City, including Beatles-themed "Love," which opened in June 2006; show replaced Siegfried & Roy at the Mirage. Hoping to bring a permanent show to New York City. Throws lavish parties, dreams of one day traveling into space.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee (see). Promoted to chief customer officer of Samsung Electronics in January 2007; works as an internal advocate for customers while building strategic alliances with partner companies. There is an ongoing investigation involving his acquisition of a 25% stake in amusement park Samsung Everland from his father at allegedly below-market rates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started root beer stand Hot Shoppe 1927; expanded into catering, restaurants. Opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. "Bill" and brother Richard (see) parted ways in 1993 amid bondholder protest; Richard controls hotel ownership operation Host Hotels & Resorts, Bill heads franchise and property management outfit Marriott International. Created joint venture with chic hotelier Ian Schrager to develop line of hip boutique Marriotts; planning kid-friendly hotels with Nickelodeon. Pecks out weekly blog with thoughts on leadership, BBQ sauce recipes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started root beer stand Hot Shoppe 1927; expanded into catering, restaurants. Opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Richard and brother J. Willard Marriott Jr. (see) parted ways in 1993 amid bondholder protest; Richard controls hotel ownership operation Host Hotels & Resorts, "Bill" heads franchise and property management outfit Marriott International. Created joint venture with chic hotelier Ian Schrager to develop line of hip boutique Marriotts; planning kid-friendly hotels with Nickelodeon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Cogen Technologies, then the nation's largest privately held power company, to Enron for $1.5 billion in cash and stock in 1999; sold all of his shares before energy giant's bankruptcy in 2001. Owns pro football's Houston Texans, majority stake in Stonerside Stables, home of the Kentucky Derby. Sold 106-acre spread in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. for $19 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control in 1998 of Oberoi Constructions, property developer started by his father, Ranvir. Got noticed when firm made big land purchases from Novartis and GlaxoSmithkline. Morgan Stanley paid $152 million last year for stake in firm. Has built 26 million square feet of offices and luxury apartments in Mumbai. Current projects include a shopping mall and a five-star hotel to be managed by Westin Hotels. Enjoys bungee jumping and skydiving.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built an empire of car dealerships from scratch. A former air force pilot instructor during the Soviet Union era, founded Rolf in 1991 with $15,000 he had earned as the manager of a car-rental company. Got Mitsubishi to agree to give him a line of credit in the form of 40 cars. Sold them, paid back his debt and became a dealer and later exclusive importer of Mitsubishi cars in Russia. Now the largest retailer of foreign-made cars in the country. In 2007 became member of lower house of parliament.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brusque money manager sold Heine Securities to Franklin Resources for $670 million and 5-year employment contract in 1996. Now runs private MFP Investors; assets under management exceed $1 billion, much of it his own money.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale grad dreamed of being a writer. Lawyer's son parked cars at racetrack in Monmouth, N.J. Summer job on Wall Street. Landed job at Rothschild 1976; cleaned up messes left by Drexel Burnham junk bond financings as a bankruptcy specialist. Founded W.L. Ross & Co. in 2000. Made fortune investing in troubled steel and coal companies. Sold stake in one of his buyout firms to Amvescap for $375 million in 2006. Now buying up auto parts companies. Collects contemporary Chinese and Vietnamese art acquired during visits to offshore factories.

name: Billionaires
bio: After 10 years as Minister for Science & Innovation, Lord Sainsbury resigned in November 2006. The former politician owes his wealth to his stake in his family's iconic Sainsbury's grocery business. His fortune, which had been held in a blind trust while he was in government, was just released. The company has lately been the subject of increased takeover speculation from buyout groups as investors and rivals hope Sainsbury may now cash out his remaining holdings. The most recent bid comes from Qatar-backed investment group Delta Two.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 40% of $8.5 billion (sales) Helm A.G., which has interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Became chairman of executive board in 1984 when father, Hermann, the company's founder, retired. Dad still owns other 60%.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State U. turned down proposal for his adult education program, John, humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix 1976. Took public as Apollo Group 1994; today one of nation's largest private university systems. More than 300,000 students working to complete over 100 programs for associate's, bachelor's, master's degrees in classroom or online. Son, Peter (see), serves as senior vice president. John closed pet-cloning business: "Not commercially viable."

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State U. turned down proposal for his adult education program, father John (see), humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix 1976. Took public as Apollo Group 1994; today one of nation's largest private university systems. More than 300,000 students working to complete over 100 programs for associate's, bachelor's, master's degrees in classroom or online. Peter serves as senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Sotheby's chairman spent 9 months in jail on price-fixing charges in 2004. Tell-all account of prison experience, Threshold Resistance, was released last April. Sold off controlling stake in art auctioneer 2005. U. of Michigan dropout made first fortune in shopping malls. Public 1992. Today Taubman Centers real estate investment trust owns 23 malls in 11 states. Son, Robert, now in charge. Active philanthropist interested in funding research on cures for diabetes and Lou Gehrig's Disease.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns large stake in Al Rajhi Bank, Saudi's Islamic banking behemoth. His three brothers also own significant shares. Heads up one of the country's largest steel manufacturing companies. The secretive family issued a rare public statement after a Wall Street Journal article was published in July 2007 about bank's alleged role in supporting Islamic extremism. Brothers denied the allegations and stated they "unequivocally" condemn terrorism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control of Grupo Televisa when his father died in 1997. Company operates radio, satellite, Internet and publishing businesses, and in recent years has diversified into off-track betting and a discount airline. Had a major legal upset last year, when the Suprema Corte de Justicia de la Nacion struck down provisions in a 2006 radio and television law designed to protect Televisa from new competition. In response, group is shoring up its efforts outside Mexico, exporting telenovelas to additional countries. In May 2007, signed a deal with the Chinese government to make a Chinese version of these sudsy shows. Later bought long-distance provider Bestel for $325 million to add telephone services to its Internet and cable TV package. Launched a free video-sharing site on its Web portal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former scientist Buck fronted family friend Fred DeLuca (see) $1,000 to open Pete's Super Submarines 1965. Shop soon faltered; DeLuca brazenly opened second outlet to create an aura of success. Today there are 28,893 Subway shops in 86 countries; much of company's success can be attributed to infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen formed athletic apparel supplier China Dongxiang of Beijing after holding senior positions executive at Li Ning Sporting Goods, the category leader in China. Took company public in 2007. Benefited from international investor interest in the Beijing Olympics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor introduced students Sergey Brin and Larry Page (now billionaires) to venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Rewarded with a chunk of Google stock. Founded networking-equipment company Granite Systems with fellow billionaire Andreas von Bechtolsheim, and sold to Cisco Systems in 1996. Donated $21 million in Google stock to Canadian alma mater, the University of Waterloo, in 2005. This frugal billionaire prefers jeans to designer clothes, reuses tea bags and cuts his own hair to save time otherwise spent going to a barber

name: Billionaires
bio: Former scientist Peter Buck fronted family friend DeLuca $1,000 to open Pete's Super Submarines 1965. Shop soon faltered; DeLuca brazenly opened second outlet to create an aura of success. Today there are 28,893 Subway shops in 86 countries; much of company's success can be attributed to infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Reportedly building "Destiny": the biosustainable city in South Florida will have a sustainable energy source and room for 150,000 people.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-starter, established 1&1 AG in 1988 with a borrowed desk and DM 500,000 in seed capital to service software and telecommunication companies too small to reach clients on their own. Took company public in March 1998 on the now defunct Neuer Markt, Germany's exchange for high-tech companies. Presently owns 35% of the company, renamed United Internet AG, which posted $3.5 billion in revenues in 2006 and is one of Germany's largest DSL providers. Avid sailor owns his own yacht. His company sponsored the United Internet Team Germany in the 2007 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mastermind behind the superfashionable Dyson vacuum. Went to art school to study design and engineering. Ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force  an upright vacuum that uses spinning technology to maintain constant suction. Introduced his vacuum in U.K. in 1993 and it was an immediate hit. Announced plans to open the Dyson School of Design & Innovation to offer 14- to 18-year-olds programs in engineering, design and enterprise.  Expanded into hand dryers this past year with the AirBlade.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969; opened 6 new stores in first year. Public 1976. Parents handed control of company--and nearly half of their stock--to John and brothers William and Robert 2004. Today company boasts 3,131 stores across 5 brands (Gap, Old Navy, Banana Republic, Piperlime, Forth & Towne). Sales: $15.9 billion. John owns pro baseball's Oakland A's; donates to schools for underprivileged.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Pilot for father's Pacific Southwest Airlines 1960s. Then moved into cars; bought Toyota distributor 1968. Today Gulf States Toyota is main engine behind supersecret Friedkin Cos.; delivers vehicles, parts to dealers in Texas and 4 other Gulf states. Sales believed to exceed $4 billion. Former Hollywood stunt pilot hunts big game on his Tanzanian reserve; supports antipoaching and community development efforts through his Friedkin Conservation Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio:
High school dropout joined Marines in WWII; trained as television repairman on GI Bill. Launched cable biz with $1,500 in 1956: built 5-channel system in Liberty, N.Y. Rapidly consolidated cable franchises. Sold to Time Warner for $2.8 billion 
in 1996. Now invests via Granite Associates: hedge funds, real estate, private equity, Time Warner stock. Spent millions of dollars building performance hall on site of original Woodstock concert. Funds environmental, educational, medical causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Payroll rep found niche supplying financial services to small businesses. Created Paychex 1971 with $3,000 and a credit card; expanded via franchising, joint ventures. Took public 1983. Left day-to-day operations 2004; remains chairman. Cofounder of the Independence Party of New York; spent $90 million of his own cash on 3 failed gubernatorial campaigns; claims he no longer has political aspirations. Recently moved into a new mansion on his 38-acre estate in Mendon, N.Y. Donated $750,000 to Veterans Outreach Center in honor of brother Charles, who died in Korean War. Owner of pro hockey’s Buffalo Sabres; divorced third wife, Heather, earlier this year. “Yes, I’m single.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), turned $6,000 winnings from craps table into a large construction empire: airports, power plants, Mideast water supply systems, South American pipelines. WWII vet bought coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee late 1960s; traded for stock in Amoco during energy crisis a decade later. Marguerite met John in elementary school; duo spent most of their lives traveling the world, playing golf, hunting quail. Son Raymond manages family fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime head of Banamex made a fortune when company was sold to Citigroup in 2001. Today, an active philanthropist who's serving as president of two Banamex-affiliated foundations. A baseball fanatic, Harp also owns the Red Devils, a minor league team in Mexico City. Cousin of Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erstwhile hippie opened first store in 1970 near U. of Pennsylvania with $4,000; sold trendy clothes to cash-strapped college kids. Expanded. Eschews advertising: lures customers with ever changing displays, vivid color schemes, inviting floor plan. Today Urban Outfitters operates under 3 brand lines (including Free People, Anthropologie). Employees travel around the world to spot new trends, buy merchandise.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable-hating digital dish lovers swear allegiance to Hubbard. His father, Stanley Eugene (d. 1992), created one of first commercial airlines in U.S.; it went bankrupt. Dad moved on to build radio station 1923. Added TV 1948. Son "Stub" took over 1981, built direct-satellite TV biz with U.S. Satellite Broadcasting.
