Public 1996; sold 3 years later to Hughes/DirecTV for $1.3 billion. Latest project: ReelzChannel, movie info and trivia channel. Debuted in 30 million homes. Says TV still beats the Net: "If you want to reach a mass audience, there's no other way to do it."
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Played shortstop for pro baseball’s Detroit Tigers farm team. Opened first Little Caesars pizza joint in 1959 after injury ended career; 40 stores by 1967. Based franchise on Ray Kroc’s McDonald’s: cheap ingredients, fast service, drive-up windows. Business lagged early 1990s; ditched frozen cheese, refurbished stores. Today sales exceed $1.5 billion. Bought Tigers franchise in 1992; team played in World Series last fall. Also owns pro hockey’s Detroit Red Wings. Wife, Marian, owns Detroit’s MotorCity casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former MIT professor got rich on wireless patents. Now they get him in trouble. Founded Qualcomm 1985 for CDMA scheme in cell networks. Patent fees are now 84% of profits. Last June Broadcom won federal lawsuit alleging Qualcomm abuses power at international standards body; in August appeals court sided with Broadcom right to sue. Remains chairman. Son Paul runs company. Benefactor to San Diego causes: symphony, art museum, university.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmers’ son founded Commonwealth Brands 1990, manufactured discount cigarettes USA Gold, Bull Durham, Malibu. Outperformed Big Tobacco keeping advertising costs low. Sold out for $1 billion cash in 2001. Reinvested proceeds in real estate: owns 1.7 million acres in New Mexico, Florida, Texas. Also holds small stake in Churchill Downs, home of the Kentucky Derby. Wildlife conservationist works with national zoos to breed “hoof-stock” and aids in repatriation efforts for desert antelopes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a drill sergeant grew up on Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. First job: sold greeting cards door-to-door. Studied business at Radford U. Tried to launch local TV station while attending law school at U. of Virginia; lost $250,000 of investor's money. Started pharmaceutical distribution firm General Injectables & Vaccines 1984; later sold stake for $70 million. Launched New River Pharmaceutical in 1996; focused on less addictive, more stable drugs for pain, thyroid ailments, ADHD. Sold to Shire for $2.6 billion last February; personally netted at least $1.2 billion. Now invests via private equity outfit Third Security; genetic testing, gene therapy. Avid falconer also owns an eagle, owl and hawks. Writes music in personal recording studio.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The Urals and its metals industry are in his blood. Grew up in the town of
Verkhnaya Pyshma in the Urals region and studied at a  metallurgy institute.
In 1979 went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now the main factory
at the Ural Mining and Metallurgy Co. Served as general director from 1995
to 2002; accumulated a 15% stake. Now fellow billionaire Iskander
Makhmudov's closest partner, helping him build up holdings in Urals mining
and metallurgy companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: An orphan, got start exporting handbags from mainland. Set up Lee & Man Paper in 1994 to tap China's need for packaging paper. Chairman, runs business with son Raymond Lee, who's the group's chief executive, and son Lee Wan Bun. Expanded operations in Vietnam.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded home improvement emporium Home Depot with Arthur Blank (see) in 1978 after being fired from now-defunct Handy Dan. Took public 3 years later. New concept in home improvement appealed to pro contractors, do-it-yourselfers alike. Active philanthropist hung up his toolbelt 2002; donated $250 million in 2001 to fund world’s largest aquarium, in Atlanta.
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Wisconsin native started at Honeywell; became chief executive of Cisco 1988. Took company public 2 years later, stepped down 1995; remains Cisco chairman emeritus. Stock soared from 1995; briefly world's largest company by market cap 2000. Plummeted in tech bust but way up from $11 low in 2001. With wife, Tashia, gave $50 million to alma mater U. of Wisconsin to fund bioscience research. Outdoorsman chairs the Nature Conservancy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over William Morrison Supermarkets, which is named for his father, in 1952; became chairman in 1956. Since then has built the chain into one of the largest grocers in Britain, with sales of $24 billion in 2006. In 2004, after a protracted six-way bidding war, emerged victorious in takeover bid for rival Safeway supermarkets, paying $5 billion in stock and cash. Now selling shares, propelling rumors he may be trying to unload his 10% stake in Morrisons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family escaped Soviet Union after revolution, settled in Iran. Immigrated to U.S. at age 15 with $800. USC grad worked as a Motown Records exec before turning to real estate 1973. Today Olen Properties owns 6.4 million square feet of commercial space and 11,800 residential units in L.A., Las Vegas and Florida. Pled guilty in December to federal tax charges, paid $52 million in back federal taxes, interest and civil fraud penalties to settle charges that he lied for years about his ownership of accounts in the Bahamas, Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Britain. Agreed to move all his offshore money back to the U.S. Son, Andrei, died 2005 in car crash; daughter, Natalia, donating to Russian orphanages in foundation bearing Andrei's name.

name: Billionaires
bio: With John Arrillaga (see) became Silicon Valley's biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Credited with building up the cities of Sunnyvale and Mountain View, where tenants today include Google and Cisco. Have sold off half their portfolio since 2005; sold 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D facilities for $1.1 billion last year. Lifelong partners shun debt, media. Peery's father was an executive for Bank of America, devout Mormon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Chevy Chase Bank in 1969 from a trailer. Now Washington, D.C. area's largest commercial bank. Rising operating expenses slashing net income; profits down 27% to $78 million since 2005. Founded first real estate investment trust 1964, second REIT 1969. Today Saul Centers manages 7.9 million square feet of property in 6 states. Trustee of Johns Hopkins Medical Board, National Gallery of Art.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish businessman, chairman and 85% owner of investment firm Melker Schorling AB. Founded MSAB in 1999 and took it public in 2006, attracting such investors as fellow billionaire Stefan Persson (see), who sits on the board of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vied with Warren Buffett (see) over girls in high school; 2 became lifelong friends. Studied civil engineering at Colorado State; went to work for father's employer, Kiewit Construction (now Peter Kiewit Sons'). Became chief executive 1979. Pushed company into telecom, fiber optics, power plants. Retired 1998, still chairman Level 3 Communications. On Buffett board at Berkshire Hathaway. Owns 25% of Omaha Royals minor league baseball team. Patron of Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha: "People like warm, fuzzy things."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen has quietly built Shagang Group of China's booming Jiangsu Province into one of the country's largest steelmakers. Shen is vice chairman of the China Iron and Steel Association and a member of the 17th National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made fortune in rice crackers and other junk food sold throughout Taiwan and China. His company, Want Want, traces its roots back to Taiwan, where it was founded by his father in 1962 as I Lan Foods Industrial Co., an exporter of canned agricultural products. Company later signed an agreement with Japan's Iwatsuka Confectionery. Co. to use its equipment, which allowed it to enter the rice cracker market in Taiwan. Formally entered the China market in 1992. Companys shares trade on Singapores exchange. The family also operates a hotel in downtown Taipei.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985. Sold 80% of company to a British investor group in 2002 for $800 million. Sold rest to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004 for some $360 million. Retired, lives in Weide, Bavaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Considered the brains behind Turkcell. His idea for a mobile phone company was eventually funded by billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet. Sat on Turkcell board from 1993 until May 2005. Still owns a big stake in the NYSE-listed telecom stock. Started Turkish search engine Hakia 2006. Now partnering with another firm in new wind power plant set to open by end of 2008. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in the low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the Golden Eagle Retail Group, operator and developer of 8 high-end retail stores in China. Also owns real estate. Studied at Chinese Culture U. in Taiwan in 1969, immigrated to U.S. 1971. M.B.A. from Southeastern Louisiana U. two years later. First job: manager of a Thrifty Drug Store in Los Angeles. Took Golden Eagle public last year. Philanthropist has donated money to relief efforts for the catastrophic flooding in China in 1998; more recently Nanjing Blind School, child welfare causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Harvard graduate and cofounder of Royal Caribbean, Wilhelmsen's cruise empire remains the tent pole of the family business. Though shares of Royal Caribbean were flat in 2007, the family has expanded its maritime operations through oil driller Awilco Offshore. Arne chairs the family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and shopping centers in the Baltic States. Also owns private Norwegian real estate outfit Linstow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Graduate of the People's Police School of Sichuan and former customs officer became a coke trader in 2000, later moved into coal production. Listed his Hidili Industry in September 2007 in Hong Kong. Minority investor Baring reportedly cashed out just four weeks later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother of appliance billionaire Zhang Jindong, making own mark in real estate. His Suning Universal (not to be confused with brother's Suning Appliance) paid record price for land near Shanghai's Bund this year; announced plans for private placement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dallas native was raised by lawyer dad, accountant mom. Studied at Vanderbilt U., graduated in 3 years. Became oil trader for Enron 1995; said to have earned $750 million for company in 2001. Energy outfit famously collapsed a year later; went into business for himself. Today runs hedge fund Centaurus Energy, said to boast of 240% annualized returns since 2002. Big score buying up hedge fund Amaranth Advisors' losing positions in natural gas.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: With billionaire Richard Peery, became Silicon Valley's biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Credited with building up the cities of Sunnyvale and Mountain View, where tenants today include Google and Cisco. Have sold off half their portfolio since 2005; sold 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D facilities for $1.1 billion in 2006. Lifelong partners shun debt, media. Son of Basque immigrants donated $100 million to alma mater Stanford's endowment fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Army engineer's son grew up outside Asbury Park, N.J. Studied chemistry at Bucknell U., worked as patent examiner while attending George Washington University Law School at night. Left one semester short of graduating to pursue Wall Street career. Borrowed $1,600 to invest in nursing home operator Manor Care 1969; still owns stock. High interest rates, late fees on loan nearly wiped out early investment profits. Bought stake in Handy Dan hardware stores mid-1970s; sold stake, lost chance to buy Home Depot shares early 1980s. Lesson: always invest for the long term. Founded Baron Capital 1982; today manages $21 billion. Invests in companies expected to double in size every 5 years. Both Baron Growth Fund and Baron Partners Fund have returned 18% a year since 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: First job fixing used television sets; sold to low-income families. Bought New Jersey rental home at age 19. Founded what's now Beal Financial in 1988 to buy distressed assets from defunct S&Ls. Opened Beal Bank Nevada 2004. Founded Beal Aerospace to develop commercial rockets late 1990s; spent $250 million, folded operation citing excessive government competition. Passion for poker: has gone head to head with pro players Doyle Brunson and Phil Ivey in some of the highest-stakes private games ever played. Matches chronicled in 2005 book The Professor, the Banker and the Suicide King.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Armed with a degree in radio electronics, in the 1990s had first stores in
Moscow with bar code readers. Diversified company later traded food and
electronics, imported bananas, managed banks and an airline; group
eventually collapsed. Now focuses on the gambling business and is opening
slots parlors and casinos in Russia, the Baltics, Ukraine, Kazakhstan,
Italy, Germany, the U.S. and Latin America. Injured in an accident at a
friend's home in Monte Carlo ten years ago; appears frequently at Moscow
parties in a wheelchair. Heads the Russian Committee for the Development of
the Paralympics Movement. The new focus on international expansion will help
Boyko since Vladimir Putin pushed through strict laws limiting gambling to
just four regions in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tennessee farm boy spent childhood growing corn, raising pigs and dairy cows. Left to study chemical engineering at Auburn U. Worked as processing engineer at aluminum company. Took job at Bristol-Myers Squibb, spent time in product management, personnel; ran manufacturing section and surgical instruments division. Took over Stryker Corp. after Lee Stryker died in a plane crash 1976. Turned small medical-instruments company known for selling hospital beds and cast cutters into dominant manufacturer of artificial hips, knees. Hobbies: reading newspapers, donating to educational causes. Staunch Democrat credits his politics to modest upbringing: “I still have fond memories of what FDR did for us.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth generation of Bruchs to run $6 billion (revenues) Globus & Co. KG. Under his watch the 180-year-old company has matured into one of Germany's largest food retailers. With the sixth generation (Bruch has three sons) waiting in the wings, continued family stewardship seems inevitable.

name: Billionaires
bio: Textile entrepreneur owns one of the world's top ten denim producers; sells products to Diesel, Levi Strauss, Armani, Gap and other Western brands. Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan's 26-year-old son-in-law Berat Albayrak became Calik Group's general manager in 2007. Late Turkmenistan president Saparmurad Niyazov assigned Calik official gatekeeper role to foreigners exploring sale of Turkmen natural gas, oil and electricity to Turkish market. Seeking to exploit congestion in Turkish straits by acquiring license to build $1.5 billion Samsun-Ceyhan pipeline carrying crude oil primarily from Caspian area countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former government bureaucrat got into real estate development in 1992. Listed his Hopson Development on Hong Kong stock exchange in 1998. Hopson is now a property conglomerate with interests in residential, commercial, hotel properties as well as tourist and vacation businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accountant's son born in Kenya, moved to India at age 11. Studied engineering at Indian Institute of Technology, took programming job in U.S. at Tata Consultancy Services 1976. Earned M.B.A. from U. of Michigan; founded info-tech outsourcing firm Syntel with wife, Neerja Sethi, while in school. "I'm genetically not wired to be an employee." Went public 1997. Card player represented India in bridge world championship 1995; enjoys running, yoga.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Brash Brooklyn-raised hedge fund star dropped out of NYU's M.B.A. program to work full-time on Wall Street. Met first partner, Ivan Boesky disciple John Mulheren, on floor of American Stock Exchange. Founded investment outfit Jamie Securities 1980s; firm collapsed just before Mulheren was accused of stock manipulation. Created Millennium Partners 1990. Recently paid $180 million settlement to SEC amid allegations of illegal trading techniques; employees created 100 legal shell companies in order to market time mutual funds. "Izzy" personally paid $30 million. In June ended dispute with James Simons'(see) Renaissance Technologies; Simons claimed 2 former employees took secret trading models to Millennium. Firm paid an estimated $20 million to settle.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first hotel, the Altair Hotel, over 50 years ago at the age of 21 in Palma de Majorca. His Sol Melia group now has $1.8 billion in sales and some 350 hotels and resorts in 30 countries. They are one of the world's largest hotel chains and the largest in Spain. Escarrer still runs the show with help from his two sons. Has received numerous awards in his career such as Tourism Personality of the Century and Corporate Hotelier of the World and is a major figure in the development of the Spanish hotel industry. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied political science at Trinity U. Married Linda Pace, daughter of Pace salsa founder David Pace, son of jellymaker from Louisiana who invented own hot and spicy salsa--"Syrup of the Southwest"--after WWII. "Kit" started out cutting vegetables in production line, found calling in sales department. Became president 1977; with wife bought company from family. Purchased her half for $95 million after she sued for divorce 1991. Sold entire outfit to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion 1996. Now runs private equity firm Silver Ventures.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli immigrant raised in Flint, Mich. First job at GM. Founded Gores Technology Group buyout firm 1987 after selling computers out of his father's basement. Prefers to buy divisions of technology firms. Opened to outside investors 2003. Today manages 2 private equity funds. Brother Tom runs competing Platinum Equity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Exxon geologist now owns 3rd-largest privately held oil company in America. Founded Hilcorp Energy 1989. Bought out former partner Thomas Hook 2003 for $500 million; loaded up on debt to finance expansion. Pumped an estimated 25 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalents in 2006; has 120 million barrels in reserve. Buys "mature" fields, deploys technology to squeeze out more energy. Gives to Houston Zoo, Contemporary Arts Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Louis, started hawking peanuts and popcorn at sports events 1915; grew into massive sports concessions business. Jeremy took over upon father's death 1968, transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Owns pro hockey's Boston Bruins; became NHL chairman in June. Also stake in lucrative New England Sports Network; regional channel supplies Red Sox games to Boston and beyond. Provides hospitality services to London's Wembley Stadium; venue hosted first NFL game outside North America in 2007. Recently lost bid to operate New York race tracks. Donated $1 million to cancer research in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grocer's son chose the law over family business. Studied English and history at U. of Texas; stayed for law school. Joined Harris County, Tex. prosecutor's office 1954; district attorney was soon impeached for "running a string of whorehouses." Reputation for smarts, sharp tongue brought lucrative offers from private sector. Formed own firm instead, made name trying personal injury cases. Nervous corporations paid him vast sums to switch sides. Hit gold mine representing Pennzoil against Texaco 1987; the $11 billion judgment for Pennzoil netted him an estimated $345 million fee. Faithful alum says he has donated $100 million to UT, sponsored 3,500 scholarships. Spends evenings reading Twain, eating shrimp. "I'm still drinking."

name: Billionaires
bio: After giving up control of Promise, Japan’s third-largest consumer lender six years ago, Jinnai began growing mangoes, bananas and other tropical fruit in greenhouses on Japan’s northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters and heavy snowfalls. Promise, which he founded and is now run by his son, Hiroki Jinnai, has been squeezed by the industry’s tighter lending rules that limit interest rades. In response, it has eliminated jobs for more than 1,000 workers, acquired smaller rival Sanyo Shinpan in a bid to shore up its customer base and is bolstering ties with Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan’s third-largest bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Green's the thing now, says this renowned venture capitalist and vegetarian. John Doerr's doppelganger at Kleiner Perkins studied engineering at Indian Institute of Technology, earned biomedical masters at Carnegie Mellon, M.B.A. at Stanford. Cofounded electronic design automation company Daisy Systems early 1980s, then joined Andy von Bechtolsheim, Scott McNealy, Bill Joy to form Sun Microsystems. Chief executive for short stint, became full-time investor 1986. Later joined fellow Sun-backer Doerr. Profited on Juniper Networks, Cerent, Corvis. In 2004 formed Khosla Ventures to fund "science experiments."
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio:
A businessman with a murky past. Born in a small town near Moscow and a
graduate of the State Institute of Physical Culture. The Russian tabloid
Versia once linked Kvetnoi with the feared Solntsevo crime group, one of the
biggest and richest of the last decade. No clear evidence was presented. In
1995 joined Alisher Usmanov's (also a billionaire) metals group, for a time
serving as chief executive of an Usmanov company. In April 2006 sold out to
Usmanov when his patron created a metals conglomerate that included a
Kvetnoi company. In 2007 used some of the capital to buy National Standard
Bank, which had been affiliated with an Usmanov company, and NovorossCement,
Russia's third-largest cement producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morocco native studied at Clark U., then NYU law school; clerked for a bankruptcy judge in New York. Left law to lead bankruptcy operations for Cowen & Co., manage money for Robert Bass (see). With sister Sonia Gardner, founded distressed debt brokerage Amroc Investments 1989. Expanded into distressed equities via Avenue Capital hedge fund 6 years later. Sold 15% stake of company to Morgan Stanley for $275 million in 2006. Appalled by hedge fund salaries: "What we make is absolutely obscene." Chess, basketball player.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made billions in credit cards via MBNA, brought professional football back to Cleveland. Sold to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family's shares of BofA now worth $2.2 billion. Brother Randolph (see) active Cleveland Browns owner bought Birmingham, England soccer club Aston Villa for $120 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made billions in credit cards via MBNA, brought professional football back to Cleveland. Sold to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family's shares of BofA now worth $2.2 billion. Son Randolph (see) active Cleveland Browns owner bought Birmingham, England soccer club Aston Villa for $120 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made billions in credit cards via MBNA, brought professional football back to Cleveland. Sold to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family's shares of BofA now worth $2.2 billion. "Randy" active Cleveland Browns owner bought Birmingham, England soccer club Aston Villa for $120 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Auto mechanic's son dropped out of law school to sell cars in 1950, owned 1st dealership by age 25. Built string of car lots across native Texas before founding radio station giant Clear Channel with Lowry Mays 1972. Onetime owner of Minnesota Vikings cashed out in 2005, selling team for $600 million and netting $350 million profit. Money now reinvested in oil, real estate, more car dealerships.

name: Billionaires
bio: Temple U. grad studied medicine at Hahnemann (now part of Drexel U.). Made first fortune as a surgeon inventing spinal implants. Settled nasty intellectual property lawsuit with medical device maker Medtronic in 2005. Payoff: $1.4 billion. "I don't think I've spent one penny of that money." Set up 2 foundations: one supports scientific research, the other strives to save unloved pets. Says philanthropy funded by investment gains. Has planted 3.5 million teak trees in Costa Rica since 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Witnessed wildcatter dad's discovery of 6-billion-barrel East Texas megafield at age 10; gushing plume of oil inspired "Tex" to join family business. Studied petroleum engineering at U. of Texas. Served in Navy during WWII. Became partners with dad, ran company's day-to-day operations. Acquired one-third of massive Madden Deep natural gas field in Wyoming 1972; field grosses at least $2 million a day. Owns ranches on 20,000 acres on Fort Worth's Barnett Shale. In no hurry to expand; says drilling rigs too expensive right now.

name: Billionaires
bio: Argentinean-born son of Cuban parents started out as urban planner; moved into low-income housing development. Met partner, Stephen Ross (see); cofounded Related Group of Florida 1979. Built affordable housing 1980s, later switched to high-end condo construction. Has constructed 55,000 apartments in Florida since 1982. Recently smacked by stagnating Miami market. Expanding into Atlanta, Tampa, Orlando. Also Latin America: developing $3 billion worth of properties across 15 projects in Argentina, Colombia, Mexico. Democratic donor supporting Hillary Clinton's presidential bid.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former engineer turned Ineos into the world's third-largest chemicals company, with $39 billion sales, largely through a series of acquisitions. The biggest: the $8.7 billion deal to buy BP Group's Innovene business in 2005. In December Ineos offices were raided by European Commission competition authorities over its planned buyout of Norway's Norsk Hydro, which the commission suspected was going through without its approval.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dartmouth grad earned law degree from Southern Methodist U. 1978. Practiced bankruptcy law in Dallas, left to invest in oil and gas 1984. Started Chief Oil & Gas decade later. Bet early on Fort Worth's Barnett Shale natural gas field; sold out to Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy for $2.6 billion cash 2006. Now runs oil drilling outfit Chief Operating.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Born in Tula, near Moscow; graduated from the Institute of Hydrometeorology
in St. Petersburg. In early 1990s worked on the production of
ecological-control instruments, participated in the creation of an
electronic bourse and traded in imported food products. In 1999 opened his
first Pyatyorochka discount grocery store, which apparently met a market
need: Listed on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. The following year it was
bought by Alfa Group's Perekryostok grocery store chain; the new entity is
called X5. Rogachev is now opening hypermarkets across Russia under the name
Carousel and building trading centers as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partner in Leon Black's (see) private equity company Apollo Management. Studied at U. of Pennsylvania; stayed at Wharton for M.B.A. With Joshua Harris (see) took job in M&A department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, joined Black to create Apollo 1990. Claimed average annual return: 40%. Active with National Jewish Outreach Program, Youth Renewal Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada&#39s cheese mogul started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents, Giuseppe and Maria. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza’s growing popularity boosted demand for his products. Still serves as chairman; son Lino Jr. is chief. Through his private investment company Jolina Capital, took Canadian lumber company Arbec Forest Products private and also owns a stake in Tembec, another forest products company. Owns 80% of 47-story Place Victoria, home of Montreal Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger brother of billionaire Sergei Sarkisov, graduated from the State University of Management and started his own company in 1990 after quitting his job at a Soviet company that exported commodities. Traded metals and imported construction equipment. Later joined his brother's successful insurance company, RESO-Garantiya, getting oversight of the firm's largest clients. Now manages the RESO group's construction projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start at the Soviet state insurance firm Ingosstrakh. Founded his own insurer, RESO-Garantiya, in 1991; today serves as chairman of the board. Sold a 37% stake to French insurance giant AXA in 2007 for $1.2 billion, a record sum for a Russian insurer. He and his brother Nikolai, also a billionaire, are still its largest investors. Fond of auto racing.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Considered a major player in the Australian media industry through his
majority stake in the Seven Network, Stokes neverthless has a much more
valuable asset in the selling and servicing of Caterpillar earthmoving and
mining equipment. Already the biggest Cat dealer in Australia through his
WesTrac. Stokes is busy building a replica business in China. Given the
potential size of the Chinese market versus the relatively small size of
Australia, it might not be long before the bulk of Stokes's fortune is
Chinese based.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former engineer from Fujian Province in China started out mopping floors to put himself through school. Wealth now held in aviation, real estate, mining, liquor and tobacco companies. His Philippine Airlines just emerged from receivership in 2007, but a safety downgrade from the U.S. FAA may limit plans to expand international routes. Also owns a portfolio of real estate in Hong Kong. Hobbies include flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Persuaded the board of Campbell Soup Co. to sell its Godiva Chocolatier unit to his family's Yildiz Holding for $850 million in late 2007. Cut teeth working at his father's Ulker Food Co. and at Continental Baking Co. in the U.S. Owns candy and sweets factories in Uzbekistan, Ukraine and Saudi Arabia. Enjoys sailing, hunting and travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bored lawyer changed careers, created early Internet video outfit Broadcast.com with partner Mark Cuban (see). Sold to Yahoo in 1999 for $5.7 billion; company isn't visible today. Went Hollywood. With Cuban, owns stakes in 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, HDNet, Lion's Gate. Sold domestic rights for indie flick We Own the Night to Sony for record $11.5 million in May; manly mob drama stars Joaquin Phoenix, Mark Wahlberg. Believes a few eco-entrepreneurs will become billionaires: "Someone who will figure out how to capitalize on these environmentally friendly trends in the coming decade."

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang has benefited from his minority stake in Shanghai-listed Poly Real Estate Group. Zhang's Huamei International Investment Group owns several language-training institutions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech's newest golden boy founded addictive social networking site Facebook in February 2004 from his Harvard dorm room. Left school for Silicon Valley later that year; scored initial $500,000 investment from PayPal cofounder Peter Thiel (see). Venture firms soon swooned, among them Accel Partners and Greylock Partners. Today Facebook boasts 66 million active users. Estimated annual sales: $150 million. Expanding beyond being a college-only message system and photo album; now courting users to 55,000 different high school, business and city networks. Problems with privacy: installed "News Feed" in 2006; program automatically alerted users' friends to changes they made to their profiles. Outcry over privacy concerns led company to backpedal; Zuckerberg issued apology. Similar controversy ensued after release of Facebook Beacon late last year; program automatically alerted friends of activities on selected outside sites, including eBay and Fandango. Microsoft bought 1.6% stake for $240 million last October; deal led many to suggest the company is worth $15 billion. Some analysts--and even a few Facebook investors--suggest the company's value is far lower.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of 25-year-old Agaoglu Group, a builder of hotels, resorts, ski lodges and McMansions in Turkey. Justifiably calls construction sector the iron horse of Turkish economy with growth rate of 16.5%. Started working right after high school. Divorcee's so-called playboy antics with bikini-clad younger women closely tracked by local media. Hops around in his $4.5 million Bell 430 helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio:
A schoolboy when his father, the director of a plant in Baku, Azerbaijan,
was sentenced to death for state-property embezzlement. Fled to Moscow,
studied to be a mechanic; spent several years in the navy; graduated from
the Moscow Veterinary Academy's Commodity Research & Animal Commodities
department as specialist in fur. Eventually began selling machinery to oil
and gas companies and later moved into production himself. Starting in 1993
built up shares in gas company Nortgas, which has a field in the Arctic
Circle, from 5% to nearly 100% by 2001, largely by diluting partner
Gazprom1s stake. In 2005 was threatened with the loss of his license; agreed
to give Gazprom its Nortgas shares back. Today he owns half the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paid college tuition repairing vending machines, working hotel night shift; became a loan processor. Purchased Mission West real estate investment trust in 1997. Today manages 7.8 million square feet across 110 properties. Silicon Valley office space houses Apple, Microsoft. Investing in technology that removes carbon dioxide from coal-burning plants, cancer research. Considers funding only ideas that can make him at least $250 million. “Otherwise you get into these small companies that eat up all your time and don’t go anywhere.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate raider known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies. Got start as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. Has targeted advertising companies: built up a stake in French agency Havas, demanded board seats, gutted management and made himself chairman; also bought shares in Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. Eclectic portfolio includes plastics, African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, newspapers and a television channel. Close friends of French President Sarkozy. Hosted the president on his yacht for a post election holiday off Malta early last year. Avid comics aficionado has a collection of 1,000 comic books by the likes of Pieds Nickles and Spirou.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got his start teaching at Stanford, became a high-tech hitmaker and startup addict: Silicon Graphics 1982; Netscape 1994; Healtheon (now WebMD) 1996. Took each public. Cashed out before all of them tumbled in bubble-burst. Reinvested in Neoteris (computer security), MyCFO.com (wealth management), Hyperion Development Group (Miami real estate). Owns 40% stake in photo-sharing site Shutterfly; went public 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group is one of North America&#39s largest pharmacy chains. Bought into the Eckerd brand in 2004 when it purchased the chain&#39s stores in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states for $2.4 billion. Just two years later announced it was selling its U.S. operations, including the Eckerd and Brooks brands, to Rite Aid, in a deal worth $3.4 billion in stock and cash. Jean Coutu Group is Rite Aid&#39s top shareholder. Coutu&#39s son Michel is nonexecutive cochairman of the board at Rite Aid, while other son François is president and chief executive at the Coutu Group. Jean continues in the role of chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up middle class in Worcester, Mass.; studied economics at U. of Pennsylvania, graduated summa cum laude. Took job at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette; worked 100-hour weeks. Harvard M.B.A. Then merger arbitrage at Kellner, DiLeo & Co.; lost entire life savings on "Black Monday" in 1987, reduced to tears. Launched York Capital hedge fund operation in 1991 with $3.6 million, mostly from former DLJ colleagues. Scored big betting on Sears, Roebuck & Co. 1993. Has returned 17% a year after fees. Tries to stay humble despite fortune: "I pretend it's not real money so I don't forget I'm just a kid from Worcester, Mass."
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwards has been battling the Alberta government's effort to raise royalties on oil and gas companies. The reason: He has more at stake in the Canadian oil sands than possibly any other individual. His company, Canadian Natural Resources, has sketched out plans to spend $25 billion to turn the gucky mud found in northern Alberta into barrels of crude oil. This media-shy lawyer-turned- financier also owns big stakes in Ensign Energy, Canada's second-biggest oil services company, and Penn West, one of Canada's biggest energy trusts. Also owns Lake Louise, Canada's famous ski resort, and a chunk of the Calgary Flames hockey team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969; opened 6 new stores in first year. Public 1976. Parents handed control of company--and nearly half of their stock--to Robert and brothers William and John 2004. Today company boasts 3,131 stores across 5 brands (Gap, Old Navy, Banana Republic, Piperlime, Forth & Towne). Sales: $15.9 billion. Robert became interim chief executive last year following the resignation of Paul Pressler; former exec failed to revive fledgling Gap brand.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969; opened 6 new stores in first year. Public 1976. Parents handed control of company--and nearly half of their stock--to William and brothers Robert and John 2004. Today company boasts 3,131 stores across 5 brands (Gap, Old Navy, Banana Republic, Piperlime, Forth & Towne). Sales: $15.9 billion. William ran company's international stores until 1998.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's biggest mining promoter has had a busy year. Developing a gold mine in Kazakhstan, other metals ventures in Africa. But the big prize is in Mongolia, where his Ivanhoe Mines continues to work on the Oyu Tolgoi copper and gold project. Chicago native attended Reed College in Oregon; studied Sanskrit, Buddhism in India after graduating. Returned home, discovered abandoned gold mine on a parcel of timberland. Opened gold operations in Colorado in the 1980s and was sued by the EPA over alleged contamination of Alamosa River. Settled case in 2000 for $20.3 million without admitting wrongdoing; government paid his $1.25 million lawyer bill. Found large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay, Nfld.; made first fortune selling nickel-rich property to Inco for $3.2 billion in 1996. Selling his 12,000-square-foot mansion in northern California for $65 million.
title: Founder and Executive Co-Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ivanhoe Energy Inc.', 'title': 'Founder and Executive Co-Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Japanfs largest home schooling group, Benesse, with $2.8 billion in sales. Best known outside Japan for Berlitz language schools. May get boost from collapse last year of rival Nova, Japanfs largest English-conversation school. Other divisions provide elder and child care services, student loans; also has a publishing arm that prints child care books for new moms and lifestyle magazines. In 2007 Benesse branched out into childrenfs furniture.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire runs Brazilian insurer Porto Seguro, the country's largest auto insurer. The company was founded in 1945 and purchased by the Garfinkel family in 1972. When his father died in 1978, Jayme was groomed to take over. Took the company public in 2004. Through Porto Seguro, Garfinkel has supported the creation and maintenance of schools for young children in favelas, or shantytowns, around Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The closest thing to Australia's king of retail, Gerald Harvey is a
consummate salesman having made a fortune several times over under a variety
of trading names. With partner, Ian Norman, he started in electrical goods
with a business called Norman Ross. When that business was taken over, both
men quit, later opening another electronics retailer, Harvey Norman, in
1982. Remains chairman of the now publicly traded group, which has 245
stores, mainly in Australia. Has a passion for horses: owns part of Magic
Millions Thoroughbred auction house and personally owns some 900 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Belize national, Huang has substantial business interests in China. Indeed, he entered the property industry in freewheeling southern Chinese city of Shenzhen in 1992. He later moved into retailing and had planned to take his retail company Maoye International Holdings public in Hong Kong in January but he postponed the listing amid the market's plunge.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The former commercial director of Kuznetsk Coal became president of the
Swiss firm Conares Holding in 1995, overseeing export sales and financing.
The public learned about him for the first time in October 2004, when
Mechel, the largest producer of special steel and alloys, listed on the NYSE
and Iorikh was named general director; he turned out to have the same size
stake as better-known partner Igor Zyuzin, also a billionaire. But between
2005 and 2006 the two became divided over the direction of the company, and
by January 2007 Iorikh had sold his shares to Zyuzin. Established an
offshore fund to buy stakes in mining and machine firms in Turkey, Canada
and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Captained 1964 Cotton Bowl-winning University of Arkansas Razorbacks football team. Earned M.B.A., joined father's insurance firm. Moved to energy: struck gas in first 13 wells drilled 1970s. Bought pro football's Dallas Cowboys in 1989 for $150 million; team worth $1.5 billion today. Cowboys dominated NFC last season, lost to rival New York Giants in the playoffs. Latest obsession: Cowboys Stadium. Air-conditioned, 100,000-seat venue originally slated to be built for $650 million; total cost will now exceed $1 billion. Covered overrun by selling $300 million in real estate. Retractable roof will keep iconic hole design, presumably so God can still watch his favorite team. Also invested in poultry, cattle.
title: President and General Manager
employment: {'name': 'Dallas Cowboys', 'title': 'President and General Manager', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Oaktree Capital Management with Howard Marks (see). Sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange last May; raised $1 billion. Karsh: graduated from U. of Virginia law school 1980. Served as assistant to SunAmerica chairman Eli Broad (see) until 1987. Marks: Wharton grad got start in investments with First National Citibank (which later became Citicorp) 1969; joined TCW 1985. Marks hired Karsh 1987; pair founded Oaktree Capital Management 8 years later.
title: President
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Almost perfect. Kraft's New England Patriots went 18-0 on their march to the Super Bowl, then lost the game in the last minute to the New York Giants. "Bob" studied at Columbia U., then Harvard Business School. Joined packing firm Rand-Whitney after marrying Myra Hiatt, daughter of founder. Bought company 1970s; founded wood and paper trader International Forest Products later in 1972. Today Kraft Group includes investments in real estate, private equity, New England Revolution soccer team. Bought troubled New England Patriots football franchise in 1994 for then record $172 million. Team now worth $1.2 billion. Won Super Bowls in 2002, 2003, 2005. Opening $500 million, 1.3-million-square-foot Patriot Place on land adjacent to Gillette Stadium; shops, hotel, office space.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Hong Kong’s richest man Li Ka-shing has been cashing out. His PCRD sold stake in Pacific Century Insurance for premium in 2007. Landmark Marunouchi Building, in which he had 55% stake, sold, for $1.7 billion, highest price for single piece of Tokyo real estate, also in 2007. Attempts to unload Hong Kong flagship PCCW stake fell apart. In February 2008 PCCW announced plan to take its property development unit, Pacific Century Premium Development, private. Li has taken over newspaper Hong Kong Economic Journal through nonbeneficial trust. Supports universal suffrage in Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder and chief executive of Baidu.com, China's most popular Internet search engine, Li got his start working at search engine pioneer Infoseek in Silicon Valley in the late 1990s. Launched Baidu.com in 2000. Listed shares on Nasdaq in 2005. Li has announced plans to enter the e-commerce market.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three Chinese Internet moguls to debut on the billionaires list this year; others include Baidu.com's Robin Li and Alibaba's Jack Ma. His Tencent Holdings is China's most popular provider of online chat services. It has attracted such advertisers as McDonald's and Nike.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Oaktree Capital Management with Bruce Karsh (see). Sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange last May; raised $1 billion. Karsh: graduated from U. of Virginia law school 1980. Served as assistant to SunAmerica chairman Eli Broad (see) until 1987. Marks: Wharton grad got start in investments with First National Citibank (which later became Citicorp) 1969; joined TCW 1985. Marks hired Karsh 1987; pair founded Oaktree Capital Management 8 years later.
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned M.B.A. from Michigan State. Joined family grocery-distribution business 1959, worked night shift loading trucks. Sold to tennis partner Sam Walton for cash and Wal-Mart stock in 1990. Owns pro baseball's Houston Astros.  Sits on board of Boy Scouts of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Infosys Technologies, software services firm he ran for 21 years. Passed reins 2002; remains chief mentor, nonexecutive chairman. Sits on boards of Unilever, Singapore's DBS Bank. Was recently conferred France's Officer of the Legion of Honor and the Padma Vibhushan, India's second-highest civilian honor. Wife, Sudha, chairs Infosys Foundation, company's philanthropic arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls Nidec, a maker of micromotors used in DVDs, hard drives; camera shutters, robots, game-machine consoles. The recent adoption of hard drives in newer electronic devices such as iPods and DVRs is bolstering demand for its components. In 2003 Nagamori used some of Nidec’s cash reserves to build Kyoto’s tallest office building for his new headquarters. Has sponsored a skating team since 1953; 45 of the skaters have gone to the Olympics, including one who won gold at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano.

name: Billionaires
bio:
A graduate of Simferopol State University, in mid-1990s founded Russian
General Bank with fellow billionaire Alexander Skorobogatko, which served
the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began
buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and
combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial
Sea Port, went public in November 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1
billion for the partners. Bulk of fortune is his stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Conair with parents 1959 using $100 investment and hot-air hair rollers invention after dropping out of college. Experienced rapid growth after perfecting pistol-shaped hair drier. Took company public in 1972; then took private 13 years later. Acquired kitchen appliance manufacturer Cuisinart in 1989. Products include Scunci hair accessories, Interplak electric toothbrushes, Rusk salon products. Opened lavish Cuisinart Resort and Spa in Anguilla in 2001. Pleaded guilty to tax evasion charges in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attended Northwestern U. on football scholarship; sold insurance for 5 years after graduating. Founded Pat Ryan & Associates insurance firm 1964; sold policies directly through car dealerships. Salesmen became well known for clean-cut image. Merged with Combined International in 1982; renamed Aon Corp. 5 years later. Grew via acquisitions; publicly traded company now nation's largest reinsurance broker. Serves as executive chairman, owns stake in pro football's Chicago Bears. Working to bring Summer Olympics to Chicago in 2016.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Staunch conservative with political clout inherited over $200 million from mother in 1965. Great-grandson of Richard Beatty Mellon, heir to T. Mellon & Sons banking fortune; bank itself no longer in family hands. Invested in media: owns Pittsburgh Tribune-Review newspaper, Pennsylvania radio stations. Aids right-wing policy via think tank Heritage Foundation; also supports Center for the Study of Popular Culture.

name: Billionaires
bio:
If your name is your destiny, Skorobogatko got the right one: his means
"rich soon." In 1989 formed a small perfume-production company in the Crimea
with Alexander Ponomarenko, now also a billionaire. Three years later moved
to Moscow, where the pair traded consumer goods; with their earnings
established a bank. Now the partners have a controlling stake in the
Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port, the largest port in Russia and the
fifth-largest in Europe in terms of cargo volume. Since 2002 he hasn't been
involved in the business: five years ago became a representative of the
Kaliningrad region in the upper house of parliament and a year later became
a lower-house deputy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chairman of Straumann Holding, a dental implants company, gave up the family business in 2002, the first time the company was out of the clan’s hands since Straumann&#39s grandfather founded the company in 1954. Led the company through its 1998 float and its expansion into oral tissue regeneration. Also owns luxury hotels in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls the Philippines' largest retailer, SM Group, named for the small shoe mart he opened in Manila 60 years ago. His SM Prime Holdings owns SM Mall of Asia, the country's largest mall, with more than 4 million square feet of space, as well as another 30-plus malls throughout the archipelago and in China. Has plans to open another three this year. Banco de Oro-Epi, run by daughter Teresita Sy-Coson, is the Philippines' second-largest bank. Aging entrepreneur, who is often seen wearing Hawaiian shirts, remains chairman but is largely handing over daily operations to his six kids.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical engineer, chairs $3 billion (sales) Avantha Group. Its Ballarpur Industries is India's largest papermaker. Has other interests in chemicals, infrastructure, engineering. Avid golfer, is president of the Professional Golf Tour of India. Also, founder/director of Osian's, country's first art auction house.

name: Billionaires
bio: His former Dutch TV production company, Endemol, launched reality-show craze with the creation of programs like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Made fortune when he later sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Then focused on theater, a passion he's had since childhood. (At age 6 Van den Ende put on a puppet shows for neighborhood children in his hometown.) Stepped down last September as chairman at Stage Entertainment, a musical theater company and Endemol spinoff that produces blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards. Humble beginnings; started career as party-supply salesman. Last year was awarded the cross of Honor of the House of Orange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banking big shot got start as a runner for Bear Stearns 1955; earned $150 a month. Cash-strapped newlywed lived at mother's Brooklyn home during the week with wife, Joan; finally moved out when Joan was 8 months pregnant. Became president of American Express 1983. Created insurance behemoth Travelers Group through acquisitions, then merged with Citicorp in 1998. Committed $300 million to Cornell U. in June, chairman of Carnegie Hall has managed New York theater's endowment from $2.3 million in 1991 to $300 million today.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad left Wall Street in 1969 for a fresher perspective on markets; moved to Denver, founded mutual fund giant Janus. Enjoyed exceptional returns during bull markets of 1980s, 1990s; became fourth-largest mutual fund company in the country. Losses mounted in 2000; resigned chief exec post 2002. Stepped down as chairman 2 years later amid industry's market-timing scandal; Janus fund managers accused of giving preferential treatment to short-term investors. Company settled with regulators for $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lost $6.4 billion in net worth as shares in his real estate company Astroc Mediterraneo S.A. plummeted over 90% in 2007 amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain. Resigned in July 2007 as chairman of Astroc, which he founded. Still owns 31% but stake dropping to 17% once company's merger with two other companies is finalized later this year. Runs a private foundation, committed to spreading knowledge of Spain's cultural heritage, which celebrated the opening of Astroc's New York office by hosting a paella (Valencia's quintessential dish) feast in Central Park that fed 20,000 people in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maryland native's father died young; raised by football-fanatic mother. Spent high school summers mowing lawns, babysitting, pumping gas. Graduated from Salisbury State. Started Aerotek with $3,500 and furniture purchased from Goodwill; company provided engineers to aerospace industry. Today owns large chunk of Allegis Group, nation's third-largest staffing firm. Places workers in aviation, mining, banking, construction jobs. Estimated sales: $5 billion. Cigar aficionado bought majority stake in pro football's Baltimore Ravens 2004. Media shy: "I wouldn't mind being the least-known owner in the NFL."
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Hero of hardware cofounded Home Depot 1978; do-it-yourself giant fired chief executive Robert Nardelli last year amid concerns over stagnant stock price. Started chain with partner Bernard Marcus (see) after getting fired from now defunct Handy Dan Improvement Center. Handed out dollar bills in the parking lot of first store to lure customers. Took public 3 years later. Retired 2001. Owner of pro football's Atlanta Falcons forced to juggle off-the-field distractions last summer; quarterback Michael Vick pleaded guilty to dogfighting charges in August 2007.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of original chicken sandwich fired up first grill 1946. With brother Ben served Ford factory, airport workers round the clock, 6 days a week. Poultry executives approached Cathy with discounts on leftover chicken breasts too big for Delta meal trays. Oversize chicken sandwiches became trademark. Food-court pioneer opened first Chick-fil-A at Greenbriar Mall in Atlanta 1967. Scarred by Depression, keeps debt to minimum. Devout Baptist keeps stores closed on Sundays, enforces strict Christian corporate code. Advises employees, franchisees to "base your business on biblical principles." Owns a Batmobile from Batman Returns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chearavanont family forbears founded Charoen Pokphand Group 86 years ago as a small seed shop in Bangkok to import seeds from China to Thai farmers. Dhanin, the youngest of four brothers, was just 25 when he took over the business and transformed it into one of the world's largest suppliers of animal feed. Then successfully branched into retail, telecom and other businesses. In 1999, opened Thailand's first 7-11 convenience store in Bangkok. C.P. Group uses a lotus flower as its Buddhist symbol of commitment, effort and accomplishment. In spare time, enjoys breeding Thai chickens; bankrolls a cockfighting arena but only with chickens wearing small gloves to prevent serious injuries. Also purchases and saves the lives of water buffalo otherwise destined for the slaughterhouse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Toymaker thrust into spotlight in summer 2007 when his Early Light Industrial alerted Mattel of cars tainted with lead, sparking recall. Luckily most of his fortune comes from real estate. Recently sold a half-dozen buildings, pocketing $200 million, but still holds two dozen properties. He also has large stakes in Hong Kong companies Town Health International and Regal Hotels International, and sits on the boards. Collects expensive watches, fishing vessels and luxury cars. He has 45 racing cars, including a Ferrari Spider, a Lamborghini Murcielago and a Rolls-Royce Phantom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Procter & Gamble product manager developed Quicken personal finance software to combat wife's checkbook-balancing complaints. Cofounded Intuit with Tom Proulx 1983; public a decade later. Today products include TurboTax, Property Manager, QuickBooks, Medical Expense Manager. Increased competition from Microsoft, H&R Block. Active philanthropist funds business school program at wife's alma mater, U. of Wisconsin; Intuit Tax Freedom Project donates free tax prep to 11 million low-income people annually.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich's much lower-profile right-hand man
worked with him ten years ago at Abramovich's Runicom, an offshore holding.
Was also main oil trader at Abramovich's Sibneft, which was sold in 2005 to
Gazprom. Owns piece of Millhouse LLC, Abramovich's investment vehicle, with
assets in metals, pharmaceuticals, commercial real estate and food.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transformed from Hollywood mogul to Internet maven in past decade. Kept blunt, fearsome style intact. Spent 3 decades in Hollywood then quit News Corp. 1992 to be owner, not employee. Now controls Internet melange IAC/InterActiveCorp: 60 brands including Ask.com, Citysearch, Gifts.com, iNest, Evite, CollegeHumor, RealEstate.com, Ticketmaster, LendingTree.com. Split off travel Web sites operation Expedia in August 2005 (TripAdvisor, Hotels.com, Hotwire). Wealthy developer's son went to Beverly Hills High School, dropped out of UCLA for job in mailroom at William Morris Agency. "I read the entire history of the entertainment business." Later became an executive at ABC (1960s), Paramount (1970s), then--for Rupert Murdoch--created Fox Broadcasting Co. (1985), a then unheard-of 4th major network. Now on the Net, missed MySpace and YouTube revolution. Currently embroiled in a nasty legal dispute with Liberty Media's John Malone over future of IAC/InterActiveCorp.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Henry Swieca (see), leads hedge fund and private equity outfit Highbridge Capital. Grew up together in Washington Heights, N.Y. Both studied at SUNY Stonybrook. Dubin later specialized in merger arbitrage at brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. Swieca took job at Merrill Lynch; became one of the first traders on New York Futures Exchange. Duo founded Dubin & Swieca 1984, renamed Corbin Capital; created Highbridge 8 years later. Sold majority stake to JPMorgan 2004; Dubin and Swieca still run show. Dubin married a former Miss Sweden. Founding board member of New York's poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation with Paul Tudor Jones (see).
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded back-office-software giant PeopleSoft; public 1992. Stepped down from day-to-day operations in 1999, continued as chairman until selling to Oracle's Larry Ellison (see) for $11 billion in 2005. Cornell grad set up $10 million fund for ex-employees unable to find jobs. Early investor in background check firm HireRight. Now hoping to create new fortune with enterprise software startup Workday. Animal-loving philanthropist a trustee of Maddie's Fund (named after his late miniature schnauzer) to help make America a "no-kill zone" for unwanted pets.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Unofficial czar of Turkey's medical and pharmaceutical sector got his last name from the honorary title given to his grandfather, Turkey's head pharmacist, 95 years ago. In 2006 his group of companies increased sales 13% to $2.6 billion. Overseeing expansion of ceramic-tile manufacturing unit into Russia and Ireland. Along with wife, Oya, was a major benefactor of Istanbul's new Modern Art Gallery, a renovated 86,000-square-foot former customs warehouse on the Sea of Marmara. Oya serves as museum's director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares pharmaceuticals fortune with older brother and fellow billionaire, Bulent (see). Worked in family business since 1980 except for a stint in U.S. at American Hospital Supply Co. Still holds title of deputy director general of Eczacibasi Holding. Also a player in the informatics sector in Turkey; serves as Directorate General of the Turkish Informatics Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Frank Fertitta Jr., got start as a dealer for Stardust Casino in Las Vegas. Saw need for casinos aimed at Sin City locals;  opened 5,000-square-foot, 100-slot facility away from Strip simply dubbed The Casino 1976. Expanded to include sports book, restaurant, buffet, bingo hall, more gaming; renamed Bingo Palace. Public 1993; Frank III soon became chairman, chief executive. With brother Lorenzo and Colony Capital's Tom Barrack, took company private for $9 billion in cash and assumed debt last year. Purchased professional mixed martial arts league Ultimate Fighting Championship 2001; spent $40 million to improve operations, image. Mass appeal came in 2004 with reality TV show The Ultimate Fighter. Stages monthly pay-per-view events; each averages $30 million in revenue.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Frank Fertitta Jr., got start as a dealer for Stardust Casino in Las Vegas. Saw need for casinos aimed at Sin City locals; opened 5,000-square-foot, 100-slot facility away from Strip simply dubbed The Casino 1976. Expanded to include sports book, restaurant, buffet, bingo hall, more gaming; renamed Bingo Palace. Public 1993. With brother Frank Fertitta III and Colony Capital's Tom Barrack, took company private for $9 billion in cash and assumed debt last year. Purchased professional mixed martial arts league Ultimate Fighting Championship 2001; spent $40 million to improve operations, image. Mass appeal came in 2004 with reality TV show The Ultimate Fighter. Stages monthly pay-per-view events; each averages $30 million in revenue.

name: Billionaires
bio: Read market reports for fun, bought first stock at 13. Founded Gabelli Asset Management 1977; launched first mutual fund 1986. Public offering 1999. Today company manages $31 billion. Columbia business school grad skips salary, bonuses, stock options; prefers management-fee-based compensation instead. Lucrative tradeoff: earned $55 million in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's biggest bond trader got start gambling. Arranged gambling pools while studying at Duke; spent a summer working the slots at Harrah's in Lake Tahoe. Vegas stint playing blackjack turned $200 into $10,000 in just 4 months. Vietnam vet; earned M.B.A. from UCLA. Took job as a securities analyst at Pacific Life. Discovered key to making money with bonds: trade, don't buy and hold. Given $10 million portfolio to manage in 1973; already earning $20 million bonuses by the 1980s. Bond division spun off to create Pimco; public offering in 1994. Netted personal $400 million in 2000 sale to German insurance goliath Allianz AG for $4.7 billion. Stamp collector sold British stamp hoard for $9.1 million last June to benefit Doctors Without Borders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Azerbaijan native became Turkish citizen last year. Road warrior flies 120 hours a month tending to Palmali Group shipping business. His fleet of 129 ships mainly are used for fuel transport. Military school and Soviet internal intelligence academy grad operates on an average four hours of sleep. Animal lover keeps dogs and monkeys in his botanical-garden-like Istanbul office; has built shelters for homeless animals in Russia and Azerbaijan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former art dealer's primary passion-and source of wealth-is likely the largest private collection of Islamic art, including more than 20,000 objects spanning 1,400 years. Wants to open a London museum for his works in 2009. A dual U.S.-British citizen, Khalili shipped 400 art pieces to Sydney, Australia in summer 2007 and scores of others to Abu Dhabi for his collection's first Middle East showing. Also owns commercial real estate properties in and around London.

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of the Moscow Institute of Chemical Engineering, had a brief flirtation with the world of entertainment as manager of Moscow's Satiricon Theater in the last years of communism. Then quit and began trading cars, metal products and steel pipes. In the mid-1990s, in hometown of Chelyabinsk, teamed up with the manager of the town's pipe-manufacturing plant, who invited him to jointly privatize the enterprise. Now the main shareholder of the ChPTZ group, which includes Chelyabinsk Pipe Rolling, First Urals New Pipe and the Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory. The group controls 22% of the country's steel-pipe market and processes 60% of Russia's zinc. Represents his home region in the parliament's upper house.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer science major and onetime credit officer at the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China moved into real estate in 1994, eventually striking it big in Guangzhou's property industry. Runs KWG Property Holdings with two brothers, Kong Jian Tao and Kong Jian Nan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out as a flour trader working for his uncle, Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok. Struck out on his own, eventually partnering with Martua Sitorus to buy a small palm oil plantation in Sumatra in 1991 that later became publicly traded palm oil company Wilmar International. Merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007, turning Wilmar into one of the world's largest palm oil producers. Deal boosted stock and turned Kuok and his cofounder into billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Shanghai, raised in Hong Kong but prospered in his adopted home of Taiwan. There he dropped out of National Taiwan University and set up Quanta Computer with a fellow classmate, who has since died. Transformed the Taiwan contract manufacturer into the world's no. 1 maker of notebook computers. Reengaged at the company after recovering from a reported illness last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Kerala, in southern India, Menon migrated to Oman in 1976 and started an interior decorating business with a partner. Seeing an opportunity in real estate back home, he started Sobha Developers, named after his wife, in Bangalore in 1995. Went on to build several campuses for Infosys Technologies, cofounded by billionaire N.R. Narayana Murthy. Current projects include a mall with an Olympic-size skating rink in Bangalore. Recently won bid with fellow billionaire Anil Ambani to construct India's tallest building, a 100-story twin tower in Hyderabad. His wife sits on the board. Son Ravi, an engineer from Purdue University, is vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Venture capitalist studied history at Oxford, then got Wharton M.B.A. Became a journalist. Joined Sequoia Capital 1986. First big hits: Yahoo, PayPal. Then Google. Firm's initial $12.5 million investment in search behemoth now worth $11.4 billion. His Google purse: $750 million. Current investments include Plaxo (online address books), Sugar Publishing (women's Web sites), Saba (human resources software). Stepped down from Google board in May 2007.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton dropout had first score with Triangle Industries' acquisition of National Can 1985; sold company for $4.2 billion 1988. Bought Snapple from Quaker Oats for $300 million; sold company 3 years later to Cadbury Schweppes for $1.5 billion. Known for obsession with due diligence, efficiency. Stepped down as chief of buyout firm Triarc Companies last June; received $50 million in compensation, remains director. Outbid for Burger King by Texas Pacific Group in 2002. Owns roast beef sandwich chain Arby's; trying to buy fast food joint Wendy's.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded credit card giant Bancard in native Chile after earning economics doctorate at Harvard. Later amassed 28% stake in Chile’s national airline, LAN. Quit company’s board in 2007 after being fined $680,000 for buying stock ahead of 2006 midyear earnings announcement. Ran as right-leaning candidate in Chile’s 2005 presidential election; lost. Political analysts predict a second try in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: This Winnipeg, Man.-born geologist made it big by finding natural gas in remote and often Artice-like areas. In the 1970s founded Paramount Resources, which developed huge natural gas inventories. Riddell split up the company by spinning out income trusts from Paramount's assets. But Riddell has been facing hurdles ever since Canada's federal government decided to end favorable tax treatment of trusts. A stronger Canadian dollar has driven down the value of exports, and new uncertainty surrounds Riddell's companies because of proposed increases in Alberta's energy royalties.

name: Billionaires
bio: North Carolina native took job as sales trainee at Kidder, Peabody at age 25. Became chief of firm's money management operation 17 years later. Quit to form Tiger Management; firm became world's largest hedge fund 1990s. Fortune crushed after suffering 2 years of losses when tech bubble burst. Returned cash to investors in 2000, fund now manages his money only. His Tiger Foundation has donated $58 million to fight New York City poverty. Owns vineyards in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native New Yorker founded Interstate Partners 1968; today firm has large stake in Vornado Realty Trust, nation's second-largest real estate investment trust. Multifaceted REIT owns millions of square feet of office space, mostly in New York and Washington, D.C. Also supermarkets, shopping centers, cold-storage vaults, stakes in McDonald's and Toys 'R' Us. With Related Companies' Stephen Ross (see), pushing $14 billion reconstruction plan for Madison Square Garden and Penn Station. Lost out to Stephen Schwarzman's (see) Blackstone Group in 2007 bid for Sam Zell's (see) Equity Office Properties. Expanding into California with Donald Trump (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns half of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck. Heads its S. Fischer Verlag unit, which dates back to 1886; were original publishers of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse. Brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck owns the rest. Other brother, Dieter, sold his share to siblings in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother Melvin (see) left native Brooklyn for Midwest, ended up in Army. Sold encyclopedias, spent time as a leasing agent. Herb, made fortune covering the country with shopping malls. Duo runs Simon Property Group; REIT owns or operates nearly 260 million square feet of leasable space at 380 properties in North America, Europe and Asia. Married former Miss Universe Porntip Nakhirunkanok in 2002.
title: Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.
employment: {'name': 'Simon Property Group', 'uri': 'companies/simon-property-group', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dealmaker founded marketing outfit Snyder Communications. Bought Washington Redskins for $800 million 1999. Team now worth $1.5 billion. Rough season: Saftey Sean Taylor was killed at his Florida home; team rallied, made playoffs, lost in first round. Head Coach Joe Gibbs resigned after season despite a year left on contract. Snyder continues dealmaking; purchased Dick Clark Productions last year for $175 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Glenn Dubin (see), leads hedge fund and private equity outfit Highbridge Capital. Grew up together in Washington Heights, N.Y. Both studied at SUNY Stonybrook. Dubin later specialized in merger arbitrage at brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. Swieca took job at Merrill Lynch; became one of the first traders on New York Futures Exchange. Duo founded Dubin & Swieca 1984, renamed Corbin Capital; created Highbridge 8 years later. Sold majority stake to JPMorgan 2004; Dubin and Swieca still run show. Swieca is the more reclusive partner; donates to civic and religious causes.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Bartender's son raised in Illinois housing projects; sold life insurance, worked construction jobs to pay for studies at Southern Illinois U. Founded long-distance and telecom provider Excel Communications 1988, took public 8 years later with $1.4 billion in sales. Sold to Teleglobe for $3.5 billion in 1998 (later sold to VarTec, which went bankrupt in 2004). Reinvested in stocks, bonds, horses; co-owns WinStar Farm in Kentucky. State-of-the-art breeding and training grounds home to Horse of the Year candidate Any Given Saturday. Devout Christian sponsors sons' nationally competitive basketball teams; provides jerseys, equipment, rides on his private jet to tournaments. Coordinated basketball game between son's 5th grade team and jockeys; raised money for an injured jockey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process. Passed Campbell Soup business on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company; cousins Mary Alice Malone, Bennett Dorrance, Charlotte Weber (see all) sit on board but not actively involved in day-to-day operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George who founded it in 1948. Since 2001 has run the $3.3 billion (sales) company, which owns German newspaper Die Zeit and publishing houses, including Henry Holt and Macmillan. In 2006 he and Monika bought out Dieter's one-third share; each now own 50% of the group. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed on Campbell Soup business to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company; all on board but not involved in day-to-day management. Last October Campbell agreed to sell healthier foods to schools; now offers low-calorie, low-sodium soups. Also pledged to stop advertising to children products that do not meet nutritional standards.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. held posts at Hasbro, Keds, Procter & Gamble, FTD, Disney, Bain & Co. before landing Ebay's chief auctioneer post in 1998. "Meg" steered company through Internet boom, then bust, by sticking with loyal trading communities and original goal: "create an environment in which ordinary people could be successful." Moved beyond auctions; today company owns Shopping.com, Web-phone outfit Skype. Exploring online classifieds with Ebay-created "Kijiji." Bought 25% stake in madly popular Craigslist in 2004. Teamed up with Chinese auctioneer Tom Online; two companies set to rule online ads in China. Sold Ebay shares for the first time since 2003 last year. Announced plans to step down from CEO post in January; will stay on as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded paper manufacturer Nine Dragons with older sister Yan Cheung (he spells his name differently in English). Deputy chief executive, he is responsible for much of the day-to-day operations, including marketing, distribution, finance.

name: Billionaires
bio: British-schooled nephew of rags-to-riches Turkish textile billionaire Ahmet Zorlu (see). Now board member at his uncle's Zorlu Group, one of Turkey's largest conglomerates in textiles, electronics and finance. Started working at Zorlu in 1986 in a little textile shop in Trabzon, Turkey. Today mostly interested in Zorlu's textile and energy businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Seen as the unofficial representative of the Azerbaijani diaspora in Russia.
Attended the Baku Polytechnical Institute. In 1988  established Crocus, a
company that organized trade fairs. Then opened the Crocus Inter store, the
first of what would become a retail business that includes malls offering
housewares and the luxurious Crocus City Mall, the "city of boutiques." His
main revenues still come from trade fairs; on the outskirts of Moscow built
the largest trade center in the country. In 2006 his son, Emin, married the
