daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev. Publishes the Baku
magazine, which is edited by his new daughter-in-law, Leyla Aliyeva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alcocer and first cousin Alberto Cortina (see) each married a Koplowitz sister: Alcocer married Esther Koplowitz (see); Cortina married Alicia Koplowitz (see). Dubbed by Spanish press as Los Albertos, jointly ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives had inherited. Later ditched FCC management, divorced their respective Koplowitz spouses and moved into banking together. Alcocer and Cortina became co-presidents of Banco Zaragozano and owned a combined 40% of shares before it was sold to Barclays in 2004. Continue to divide fortune down the middle through their investment arm Alcor Holding.  He reportedly enjoys hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Software titan held posts at Oracle, Apple before launching salesforce.com in 1999. Goal: take traditional customer databases online. "We plan to defeat Oracle, SAP and Microsoft in the business applications market." Active philanthropist gives 1% of company's equity, manpower and profits to various causes. Published tome The Business of Changing the World.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Pizza Hut store manager served the masses online with AOL. Now pushes vacation homes for upper class via Exclusive Resorts. Invested $500 million in health and wellness concerns in 2006. AOL founder made biggest bet in tech boom, merging with staid Time Warner. Ensuing debacle prompted resignation as chairman 2003. Other investments include real estate, pineapple farming in his native Hawaii.

name: Billionaires
bio: Long-time hedge fund manager got start with gigs at Merrill Lynch, Allen & Company, Alliance Capital. Founded equity shop Chilton Investment Company in 1992. Firm has since grown to manage more than $7 billion. Founded Darien Technology Foundation in 1998 with goal of funding tech projects to benefit citizens of Darien, Connecticut. Trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Director of New York City's proverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Chilton Investment Company, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Money man got start as Xerox quality control engineer in 1965. Then ran Goldman Sachs' asset management division. Created hedge fund firm Omega Advisors in 1991. Estimated assets under management: $6 billion. On board of Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation; also on board of overseers at Columbia Business School.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched career in tandem with first cousin Alberto Alcocer (see). Each wed a Koplowitz sister: Cortina to Alicia Koplowitz (see); Alcocer to Esther Koplowitz (see). Nicknamed Los Albertos in Spain, the pair jointly ran predecessor to industrial giant FCC but ceded management to their wives, whom they later divorced. Owned a combined 40% of Banco Zaragozano before it was sold to Barclays in 2004. Wealth now held evenly with cousin in investment arm Alcor Holding. Said to like boating, collecting art and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alternative asset manager became a billionaire alongside Michael Novogratz and Peter Briger Jr. last February with public offering of Fortress Investment Group. Former Lehman Brothers partner founded Fortress in 1998 with Robert Kauffman and Randal Nardone. Novogratz and Briger joined 4 years later. Shares down 60% since offering. Group sold minority interest to Japanese investment firm Nomura for $890 million in 2006; each has also earned more than $100 million in net cash payouts since 2005. Edens studied finance at Oregon State, led private equity division at Black Rock Financial. Then Lehman. Now Fortress chief executive; manages private equity, publicly traded alternative investment businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maritime lover got sea legs as a kid; rebuilt small boat and sailed around Lake Washington. Later crafted sailboats in his Seattle garage before founding Bayliner Marine Corp. 1955. Doubled revenue every 3 years; sold to Brunswick for $425 million 1986. Invested proceeds in stocks, bonds, real estate. Spends days flying helicopters, skiing, cruising in new 164-foot yacht, Evviva. Donated $5.4 million to Arizona State University for student entrepreneurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has worked in the down apparel market for 20 years; was a former factory director. In 1994 he started Bosideng International and turned it into one of world's largest makers of down jackets and vests. Took the company public in Hong Kong in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: India's youngest self-made billionaire. An engineer from India's elite Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, started online brokerage Indiabulls with two college pals in 1999; still heads the company and is its largest shareholder. Early investors included steel tycoon Lakshmi Mittal and hedge fund Farallon Capital. Listed Indiabulls in 2004. Group moved into real estate. Scooped up prized land in Mumbai in public auctions that is being developed into commercial offices and malls. Spun off and listed real estate arm, Indiabulls Real Estate, in 2007. Plans to raise another $1.2 billion in Singapore for a separate property investment trust. Inked joint venture for life insurance with Societe Generale. Expanding into power. Plans include setting up India's fourth commodities exchange that will compete with fellow billionaire Jignesh Shah's MCX.

name: Billionaires
bio: Among largest landowners in northern Cyprus, the part of the island only Turkey recognizes as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. Onetime auto manufacturer founded Near East University in 1978 in a former dumping ground. In addition to the university's valuable land and 44 buildings, he also owns gas station, hotel, bank and publishing businesses. He likes to spend his spare time jogging, riding horses and playing tennis. Also collects stamps and antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of logistics tycoon Johnnie Hunt (d. 2006). Couple met 3 years after high school graduation. Worked as bookkeeper and secretary until cofounding J. B. Hunt Transport Services with husband 1969. Company grew to one of the largest transportation logistics outifits in nation. Sales: $3.5 billion. Johnelle remains involved with company operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Numbers junkie earned Harvard math and physics degrees in 3 years. Piloted B-17 bomber in WWII. First job: statistician at Occidental Life. Earned $225 a month, quit after realizing salesmen made more. Created property and casualty insurance company. Then Mercury General 1962. Targeted customers having trouble getting auto insurance, used snoop unit to flush out suspicious claims. Took public 1985. Believes ZIP codes key statistic to setting insurance rates; now fighting California officials, who say motorists' driving records are more important. Said to relax in the evenings with a lapful of trade magazines and agent reports.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners John Herma and Jay Baker, former store manager took control of Kohl's department store chain in management buyout 1986. Then: localized 40-store Wisconsin chain. Now: 914-store behemoth spanning 47 states. Public 1992. Stepped down from chief executive post 1999, remained chairman until 2002. Company courting new shoppers with chic, low-cost designs from Vera Wang, kitchen accessories from Food Network. Sales: $15.5 billion. Owns $500 million in Kohl's stock; also stake in used car conglomerate Carmax.
title: Director and Member of Executive Committee
employment: {'name': "Kohl's", 'uri': 'companies/kohls', 'title': 'Director and Member of Executive Committee', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of the prestigious Moscow State Institute of Foreign Affairs, ran a division of Absolut-Moscow, a private insurance company, until 1991, when he started his own firm. His Mercury group of companies started out as trader of imported food and cigarettes and became the largest tobacco products distributor in the country. In 2005 began widening its activities, when Mercury acquired a controlling stake in Sibir Energy. Its Mercury Development is now an investor in a large construction project in St. Petersburg. At the end of 2007 bought a controlling stake in Dixy Group, the sixth-largest retail chain in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leal helped fellow Brazilian billionaire Luiz Seabra build Natura Cosmeticos into the biggest Avon-like cosmetics company in Brazil. He co-chairs Natura and has promoted a product line that uses renewable ingredients from the Brazilian rain forest. He is also an active board member of nonprofit groups, including the World Wildlife Fund in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked as a banker in Shenzhen before becoming an entrepreneur and investor. Main source of wealth is a well-timed stake in Ping An Insurance. He became a company supervisor in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Colorful liquor tycoon, his United Breweries acquired Scottish distiller Whyte & Mackay for $1.2 billion in May 2007; now world's second-largest spirits group. Owns Kingfisher Airlines, which competes with fellow billionaire Naresh Goyal's Jet Airways. Acquired low-cost airline Air Deccan. Plans to launch flights to the U.S. in August 2008. Co-owns a Formula One team, Force India, with Dutch businessman Michiel Mol.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gained notoriety during the Bank of New York money-laundering scandal at the end of the 1990s, when the Moscow State University graduate was known as "the Yeltsin family banker." (No charges were filed against him in connection with the case.) Later ran MDM-Bank, founded by billionaire Andrey Melnichenko, and was chairman of the board of Troika-Dialog investment bank. In recent years has preferred the role of portfolio investor, putting money into insurance companies, real estate, retail, construction and oil fields. In 2007 bought the popular American blogging site LiveJournal.com and a number of Russian publishers specializing in intellectual literature.

name: Billionaires
bio: Phoenix native partnered with advertising genius William Levine, who founded Outdoor Systems 1980 with billboards, bus station ads. Vietnam vet Moreno joined 1984. Took public 1996, sold to Infinity Broadcast Corp. 1999 for $8.7 billion in stock. Became Viacom following 2000 merger, still owns stock. Also owns Arizona commercial real estate; stakes in pro baseball's Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim, basketball's Phoenix Suns.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother, Murat Ulker (see), became new owners of Godiva Chocolatier in 2007. Also owns stakes in half-dozen other businesses in banking, logistics and information technology sectors. Planning to sell part of Turkish bank to Saudi investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Board member of Turkey's powerful Sabanci Group serves as face of family empire in Europe. Spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul. Also started another large Turkish conglomerate, Esas Holding, in 2000. Had library named for him at Harran University in Turkey. Past charitable projects include an archeological site in Turkey, first excavated in the 1960s, and a refurbished park in Bodrum, Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billions for beauty. Luiz Seabra founded Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, in 1969. Today its more than half a million "consultants" peddle creams and makeup across Brazil and five other Latin American countries. Went public on Brazilian stock exchange May 2004. Seabra co-chairs the company with fellow billionaire Guilherme Peirao Leal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock car maven attended first auto race at age 8; promoted events on dirt track in Midland, N.C. as a teen. Opened Charlotte Motor Speedway 1960. Founded Speedway Motorsports, took public 1995. Still works out of modest sales office on the showroom floor of one of 175 car dealerships; uses fleet of 4 jets to watch races across the globe. Last March expressed interest in buying National Hot Rod Association; NHRA insisted it wasn't for sale, then sold pro drag racing series to an investment firm 2 months later. Ridiculous compensation: Speedway granted Smith a $1.5 million bonus in part for repaying the millions of dollars in loans he owed the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Found Ed Rajawali Group as a trading company in 1984. Expanded into telecom, consumer goods, retail and hotels. Most valuable holding is stake in cementmaker Semen Gresik. Partners with Sheraton and Novotel in hotels. Now moving into aviation. Bid to buy stake in Indonesia's flagship carrier, Garuda, was thwarted when government postponed sale to 2009. In December announced plans to partner with Cambodia's government to establish new national carrier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Yale soccer player got start as Morgan Stanley analyst. Stanford MBA, then  risk arbitrage at Goldman Sachs. Founded hedge fund firm Farallon Capital Management in 1986; joined private equity outfit Hellman & Friedman that same year. Serves on Board of Advisors to Common Sense Media, non-profit dedicated to improving family-friendly media. Named trustee of Stanford in 2007.
title: Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner
employment: {'name': 'Farallon Capital Management', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chess prodigy was ranked seventh in the U.S. at age 12. Stanford law grad spent time at Credit Suisse before founding Thiel Capital Management 1996. Renamed Clarium Capital Management 2002; firm now manages more than $5 billion in assets. Cofounded PayPal in 1998, sold to eBay in 2002 for $1.5 billion. Launched venture capital Founders Fund in 2005 with $50 million. Facebook's first outside investor initially gave founder Mark Zuckerberg $500,000 in 2004. Sits on board of Palantir, a computer analysis firm for goverment agencies. Enjoys running, hiking, surfing.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Amassed companies in banking, insurance, auto leasing and retail; sold off stakes to Western companies and plowed proceeds into Romanian real estate. Current projects include residential offerings in Bucharest, Timisoara, Brasov and Sibiu, as well as four office complexes in Bucharest. Outstanding athlete, he competed in the 1960 Olympic Games as an ice hockey player. Later switched to tennis, eventually coaching several tennis greats including Boris Becker, Steffi Graf and Goran Ivanisevic. Patron of the Madrid Masters tournament today; goal to turn Madrid into a Gland Slam event like those in London, Paris, New York and Melbourne.

name: Billionaires
bio: Louisiana native's parents ran a local newspaper. Sam cleaned presses, sold ads; then studied at Louisiana Tech. Worked at IBM, Honeywell. Founded supercomputer operator University Computing with $1,000 in 1963; $57 million (sales) by 1968. Added investments in insurance, oil, restaurants. Bought controlling interest in arts-and-crafts chain Michaels Stores 1982; shares bought out by Bain Capital and  Blackstone Group for $6 billion. Sold Sterling Software to Computer Associates in 2000 for $4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Based in southern China's Guangdong Province, Xu's Evergrande Real Estate Group sells apartments mostly to upper and middle-income dwellers. Foreign shareholders include Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank. Was planning to take the company public in early 2008, but those plans are now delayed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over Thermax, maker of energy, environment management systems, in 1996 after death of husband, Rohinton. Then lost son in road accident. Stepped down as chairman 2004, replaced by daughter Meher. Still on board; involved in social causes. Meditates daily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retained billionaire status despite 2007 seizure of his popular newspaper Sabah and other valuable media assets by Turkey's Savings Deposit Insurance Fund. Sold profitable stakes in gasoline- and aviation-services firms to make new investments in print publishing and TV businesses. Also owns electric power plants and copper, aluminum and soda ash mines in Turkey. Finishing building new office towers in desirable Taksim neighborhood of Istanbul. Also owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul. Personally pays for multiple school construction throughout Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Less-than-fairy-tale ending for former Walt Disney chief: resigned from Disney in September 2005 following bitter shareholder revolt led by company's nephew Roy Disney (see). New chief Bob Iger promptly bought Steve Jobs' Pixar animation group, a deal Eisner had opposed. Former Paramount executive took over troubled Disney in 1984, masterminded magnificent turnaround. Increased shareholder value more than ten-fold, but stock lagged late 1990s. Now invests via The Tornante Company.

name: Billionaires
bio: U.K. citizen arrived in Hong Kong in the mid-1960s. Later founded Noble Group, commodities firm that supplies customers with coal, grain, oil, soybeans and more. Ownership is held through several holding companies that lead back to a trust that was set up to benefit his wife and children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Athletic-shoe pioneer shelved sneaker war with rival Nike by merging Reebok with Germany's Adidas in 2005 for $3.8 billion; personally reaped $600 million. Bought U.S. distribution rights for small British shoe company 1979. Added women's sneakers amid 1980s aerobics craze. Nike pulled ahead early 1990s; shareholders demanded Fireman step down 1996. Responded with 2-year deadline to increase sales or step down. Did just that; returned 1999, restored business. Also owns golf courses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process, bought out his uncle's Campbell Preserve Company in 1914. Passed company on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company. Interests include gardening, has six greenhouses on estate covering 6,000 square feet. In November gave $25 million to the University of the Arts in Philadelphia.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Viscount Rothermere, as he is known, assumed leadership of the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) newspaper conglomerate—which includes brands like The Evening Standard, Metro and Euromoney— from his late father in 1998, when he was just 30 years old. A decade later he&#39s proved adept at guiding DMGT in a shrinking U.K. newspaper market. Under his leadership the group launched the free daily Metro newspaper now copied around the world and has been growing its insurance and property arms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. He has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998 and now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. As principal of Aurum Ventures, invests in emerging life-science and clean-tech companies. Lives on Israel's Mediterranean coast and spends a lot of time on his yacht. In the 1970s he cofounded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations from the Bahamas to Australia. His Morris Kahn Group still owns a 50% stake in the company. Son, Benjamin, is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Novosibirsk State University graduate started out in 1993 selling a variety of consumer goods to a hungry public. Later founded the Profit House investment firm and registered it in the remote Russian region of Kalmykia, then a domestic tax haven. In 2003 Profit House bought five Russian generic-drug plants and a drugstore chain from ICN Pharmaceuticals, a U.S. company founded by former Yugoslav prime minister Milan Panic. These assets grew to what is now known as Pharmstandard, the largest domestic drugmaker in Russia. Last spring it went public on the Moscow bourse; Roman Abramovich owns a stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs and runs pharmaceutical firm Wockhardt, which gets 64% of its $670 million   in sales from the U.S. and Europe. Has overseas manufacturing plants in the U.K., U.S., France and Ireland. Expanded global footprint last year by acquiring France's Negma Laboratories for $265 million and Mortin Grove Pharmaceuticals in the U.S. February offering of hospital chain Wockhardt Hospitals was withdrawn owing to choppy market. Still plans to spin off and list research arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Jones Apparel Division in 1970 while working at W.R. Grace. Bought company with a partner 5 years later. Notable lines: Jones New York, Evan-Picone, 9 West; licensing deals with Ralph Lauren. Left Jones in 2002; has sold most of his shares in the publicly traded company. Today owns art, real estate, movie production outfit Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, small stake in pro basketball's Miami Heat. Active philanthropist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of LG Group, an offshoot of the company that produced Korea's first radio in the 1950s. Today has 36 affiliate companies in electronics, home appliances, chemicals and telecom, with a combined $94 billion in sales. Koo is the largest shareholder of holding company LG Corp. Last year, amid troubles at LG.Philips LCD, a joint-venture between LG and Dutch electronics firm Philips, Koo sacked younger brother Koo Bon-Joon as chief executive; move boosted shares. Vice chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, a trade group, Koo is said to be one of the few chaebol leaders who remains scandal-free.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Fimalac, parent of Fitch Ratings, which operates in 50 countries. Founded the company in 1991 after a varied career. Started a teen magazine in 1961 at age 21. Sold it off a few years later. Attended elite Ecole Nationale d' Administration, then moved into banking and finance. Eventually landed at L'Oreal, where he spent 15 years, rising up to group executive vice president of finance. Now a board member at L'Oreal and Renault. A theater buff, he has helped fund renovations for the Theatre du Rond Point in Paris. Is also on the board of the American Friends of the Louvre.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad joined father's auto insurance firm 1955; targeted high-risk drivers. Took Progressive public 1971. Today country's third-largest auto insurer, caters to all drivers; sets rates using device installed in cars to monitor driving habits. Art enthusiast houses more than 6,000 pieces of contemporary art in Progressive offices nationwide. Donated $100 million to Princeton arts program. Spent millions against Bush in 2004; now giving to Democratic youth groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li's main company, China Infrastructure Machinery Holdings, sells forklifts, road rollers and wheel loaders; its sales network extends into Africa and Russia. Li is active in industrial and political organizations in Fujian Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former English teacher, Ma once offered tours to English-speaking tourists of Hangzhou's famed West Lake. He founded Internet company Alibaba in 1998 with $60,000 in capital, mostly to offer a way for companies outside China to find manufacturers and suppliers inside China. Took his business to business portal Alibaba.com, in which U.S. company Yahoo has a big stake, public in 2007. Alibaba Group also operates Taobao.com, a consumer e-commerce portal similar to Ebay; AliPay, an online payment system; and AliSoft, which makes business management software. Serves on the board of Tokyo-listed Softbank, run by Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable television giant TCI. Inherited hundreds of millions of dollars in stock, thanks to $54 billion TCI-AT&T merger 1999. Forced to pry fortune from stepmother, Sharon, and former TCI honcho John Malone (see); settled differences years ago. Selling off what is now Liberty Media stock; invests in oil, gas, Colorado real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded software firm Infosys, which he ran as chief executive and managing director until June 2007. Now cochairman. Sits on Reuters' board. Wife Rohini big donor to Arghyam, a nonprofit that works to improve access to water and sanitation for the poor.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the mid-1990s gas giant Gazprom created the Panrusgaz joint venture with Hungary's oil & gas giant, MOL. Rahimkulov became its chief executive and 10% owner. To process payments from its local customers, Gazprom bought the Hungarian bank Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB). Rahimkulov headed this as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold AEB and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, the largest bank in Hungary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sits on board of publicly traded family conglomerate Haci Omer Sabanci Holding ($7.7 billion market cap). Ankara-born heiress also worked for Temsa bus manufacturing division. A niece of fellow billionaire Sevket; a cousin of Yalcin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lured to Microsoft in 1981 after work at Xerox's famed PARC lab, became chief architect of revolutionary Word, Excel applications. Left 2002. Now works for small tech outfit Intentional Software. Budapest native came to U.S. at age 18, earned bachelor's at UC, Berkeley, computer science Ph.D at Stanford. Flew in space on Russian rocket to the International Space Station. Charitable Charles Simonyi Fund for Arts & Sciences funds Institute for Advanced Study, Seattle Symphony.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime baker broke ground on properties in the 1960s. Today A.G. Spanos Cos. is one of the country's largest apartment developers. Claims to be containing market downturn because not as nationally exposed as other builders. Owns pro football's San Diego Chargers; sons manage team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oxford physics major became a stockbroker at Simon and Coates in 1976. Today heads ICAP, the world's largest interdealer broker. Through his Intercapital Private Group, also heads investment bank Numis and spread-better City Index. Currently holds Tory purse strings as the conservative party's treasurer.

name: Billionaires
bio: His timber flagship, Rimbunan Hijau, is considering merging its various palm oil estates and forest assets around the world under one entity and listing it in Hong Kong. Merging his three Chinese-language publishing firms in Malaysia (Nanyang Press Holdings and Sin Chew Media Corp.) and Hong Kong (Ming Pao Enterprises). Also planning to launch a new English-language daily paper.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dreamed of becoming an astronaut; didn't make the cut because of poor eyesight. Studied aerospace engineering at Georgia Institute of Technology, applied know-how to bank transactions. Founded Simulated Environments as a grad student at Wharton 1968. Developed early model for automating back-office operations for banks and financial institutions; also computer simulator that trained bank loan officers in credit lending practices. Expanded into asset management, private equity. Quail, dove hunter.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband, Gary (see). Mary: moved to Omaha from Florida as a teenager. Graduated high school, became secretary at Falstaff Brewing. Gary: raised in Iowa; set up pins at parents' bowling alley. Studied at Dana College, then Vietnam. Returned home, spent 7 years as an administrative assistant at a Nebraska hospital. Couple married 1968. Founded WATS Telemarketing 1978; sold to First Data Resources 2 years later. Started West Telemarketing 1986. Switched to computer answering services when government placed restrictions on cold-calling. Also scored with teleconferencing, over-the-phone debt collection. West Corp. public 1996. Sales in 2005: $1.5 billion. Went private with Thomas H. Lee Partners and Quadrangle Group in May 2006. Duo received $1.6 billion, 20% of new company. Horse-racing fans have fallen short 4 times at the Kentucky Derby.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 2002 prospectus for its listing on the New York Stock Exchange the milk and juice company Wimm-Bill-Dann disclosed that Yushvaev, one of its largest shareholders, had served nine years in a Soviet prison camp: In 1980 he had been found guilty of a "violent crime." Investors weren't scared off; its ADRs have  risen sixfold since listing in February 2002. Yushvaev is still the largest private shareholder of the company. Also holds large plots of expensive real estate along Moscow's Rublyovo-Uspensky highway, the Russian equivalent of the Hamptons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of Jianlong Steel, one of China's largest private-sector steel manufacturers. Business partners in China include fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads 82-year-old Bajaj Group; also member of parliament. Bajaj Auto, nation's second-largest motorcycle maker, run by son Rajiv, spinning off financial arm into two companies, to be run by younger son Sanjiv. Company is developing a $3,000 small car with Renault-Nissan. Longstanding dispute with younger brother Shishir, over division of empire, still unresolved.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ding was China's richest man briefly in 2003. The Internet company he founded, Netease, has held its own amid tough competition in the online gaming market that has become its main business. The company's games include Westward Journey Online III and Fantasy Westward Journey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather started rag-cleaning business 1929. Richard joined 1957 after college; CEO 11 years later. Expanded into uniform rental, cleaning. Took Cintas public 1983. Still nation's largest uniform-rental firm: more than 5 million people wear company's gear. Branching out into first-aid products, cleaning supplies. Retired 2003; son Scott runs outfit. Recently lost legal battle with ex-employees over back pay in California; other labor lawsuits pending. Generous supporter of education, veterans' causes, Republican Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy financier forced into the limelight last May when his Cerberus Capital Management bought 80% of car giant Chrysler for $7.4 billion. Princeton grad named All-Ivy League in doubles tennis. Got start trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Gruntal & Co. Cofounded hedge fund-private equity hybrid Cerberus in 1992; name derived from mythological three-headed dog guarding the gates of Hades. Firm now manages $28 billion. Former Vice President Dan Quayle and former Treasury Secretary John Snow serve as advisors. Pulled into court in December to defend Cerberus' pullout from planned takeover of United Rentals; courts ultimately ruled in Cerberus' favor. Said to enjoy big-game hunting.
title: Co-founder and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Cerberus Capital Management', 'title': 'Co-founder and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale grad and bachelor bought talent agency IMG from family of founder Mark McCormack (d. 2003) in 2004 for $750 million; clients include tennis heartthrob Maria Sharapova, baseball's Derek Jeter, model Heidi Klum. Also in 2004: charged with investing Connecticut's money in bad faith in failed XO Communications and McLeodUSA. Didn't have to pay damages; jury said state complained only after deals went sour. Started private equity firm Forstmann Little 1978, early success with Gulfstream Aerospace, General Instrument; estimated $7.5 billion investment gains in last 27 years. Republican fundraiser once linked to late Princess Diana, actress Elizabeth Hurley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ambitious youth spent childhood finding ways to make money: manned firework stands, bagged groceries, sold homemade candles. Spent teenage summers in New Mexico oilfields welding pipes, digging ditches, cleaning tanks: "The single biggest motivation to get an education." Studied at Baylor U., became CPA; ran finances at oil refineries across Southwest. Hired to manage refinery in El Paso 1993 following bankruptcy. Founded Western Refining 1997, bought El Paso refinery 2000. Took public 2006; shares down 55% since last August. Donated $3 million to alma mater to create Paul L. Foster Success Center 2006.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs property developer RiseSun Real Estate based in northeastern China. Holds degrees from North China Institute of Aerospace Engineering and Tianjin University in China, as well as the Nanyang Business School in Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started small mortgage company in 1985 with $5,000 made delivering pizzas in college. Sold to Intuit for $532 million in 1999; bought it back 3 years later for $64 million. Early Internet embracer turned Quicken Loans into nation's largest online mortgage company. Closed $18 billion in loans in 2006. Sports fanatic: purchased NBA's Cleveland Cavaliers for $375 million; resigned star LeBron James to 3-year, $60 million contract. Plays pickup basketball, attempting to break Michigan's steroid-free bench-press weightlifting record. Recently bought $32 million stake in Eprize.com, which runs online promotions for clients like Coca-Cola and Disney.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of software firm Infosys was president and chief operating officer until last June when he succeeded fellow billionaire Nandan Nilekani as chief executive and managing director. Graduate of elite Indian Institute of Technology, Madras to which he is a donor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Often referred to as India's Warren Buffett. Son of an income tax officer, he started dabbling in stocks while in college. Rather than take a job, plunged into investing, starting with $100 in 1985 when the Bombay Stock Exchange Index was at 150; it is now over 17,000. His privately owned stock trading firm Rare Enterprises, derives name from first two initials of his name and wife Rekha's name. Fond of cigars and whiskey, which he consumes every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of fishmonger became successful stockbroker for wealthy Indonesian clients; nicknamed King of the Remisiers (Singapore term for stockbroker). Stopped managing other people1s money in 1996 to become full-time investor. Bet $10 million on palm oil producer Wilmar; his stake in that company was worth more than three-quarters of a billion dollars in February 2008 when we calculated Lim1s net worth. Also second-largest investor in distributor FJ Benjamin.

name: Billionaires
bio: From his Chengdu headquarters in western China's Sichuan province Liu runs one of China's largest fish feed producers, Tongwei, which is publicly traded. Also owns a pet-food manufacturer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father got start making watering cans in summer and hot water bottles in winter. Eventually founded Loh KG 1961. Friedhelm, his second-born son, took over 13 years later. Company, now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group, makes switch boxes that protect electrical circuits, postboxes, intercom systems and steel sheeting; has $2.9 billion in sales, over 10,000 employees. Known for his religious beliefs, has established the Christian Media Foundation, group of publishers of Christian literature. Avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard MBA started in finance with consultant post at Mars and Company in 1982. Became an analyst for Goldman Sachs in 1984 before moving to Julian Robertson's (see) Tiger Management in 1990. Left in 1988 to start hedge fund Lone Pine Capital. Uses both long/short and long-only strategies to keep investors happy. Founder of Lone Pine Foundation, dedicated to helping children, families in NYC. Serves as a trustee for Teach for America and Dartmouth College.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger brother of junk-bond king Michael Milken. UCLA Law School grad joined Drexel Burnham Lambert 1978. Avoided fraud charges when brother pled guilty to securities fraud in 1990. Now focuses on philanthropy, medical research; also chairs Heron International (property development) and KU Education Corp. (early childhood development).

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Akira Mori, now Japan’s richest person, inherited initial real estate fortune from late father. Siblings who have vastly different approaches to property development went their separate ways in 1999. While Akira constructs functional office blocks without bells and whistles, Minoru builds grand office towers surrounded by shops, condos, parks and art galleries. Many of his developments, including his swank Roppongi Hills, are built on split levels meant to create the feel of hill communities in flat Tokyo. Mori’s latest project, the 1,614-foot Shanghai World Financial Center, slated to open this year, is China’s tallest structure. In September 2007 Morgan Stanley acquired a 10% stake in the tower.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's first ethanol billionaire saw his fortune drop by half since 2007 amid the decline of sugar and ethanol prices and takeover rumors. With family, Ometto controls Cosan S.A., one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane, and one of the largest producers of ethanol. Cosan listed its shares on Brazilian stock exchange in 2005. The company's origins date from 1936, when the Ometto family established a sugarcane mill. Cosan has grown since 2000 through acquisitions and new partnerships. Currently undergoing a restructuring aimed at turning Cosan into a global company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once a single mother living on welfare in a coldwater flat in Edinburgh, Scotland, Rowling is now the only billionaire author on our list. The seventh and last installment of her wildly successful Harry Potter series, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, was released July 2007 to throngs of rabid fans who made it the fastest-selling book of all time. Over 11 million copies were sold in the first 24 hours. Feeding the Potter-mania: the film version of the fifth book, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, came out the same month. The popularity of her boy wizard has put the author herself in the spotlight: a Rowling documentary aired last year. In November a New York judge ordered publisher RDR Books to halt publication of a Potter dictionary after Rowling brought a lawsuit against the firm.
title: Author

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brazilian billionaire banker Edmond Safra, who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment 1999. Lily is a socialite and philanthropist who splits her time between London and New York, and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. In 2006 she got novel Empress Bianca pulled from publication in the U.K. because she claimed it was a thinly veiled defamatory portrayal of her. The author, Lady Colin Campbell, has since changed the parts of the novel that might be regarded by Safra as identifying biographical features and is planning to publish the novel in the U.S. in the spring of 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother of billionaires Ferit and Filiz Sahenk (see) and widow of Dogus Holding founder, Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. As a passive investor, she shares in the family's vast portfolio of 25 companies that cross industry verticals, including one of Turkey's largest banks, Garanti Bank, as well as high-end Porsche, Audi and Volkswagen dealerships, retail and food stores, construction companies and tourism businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads cosmetics company Amorepacific, which controls one-third of South Korea's $6 billion (revenues) market. Door-to-door sales, a big part of distribution, took a hit last year, after Korean regulators reportedly deemed the practice an illegal marketing scheme and fined cosmetics companies. Still, Korea's make-up market is expected to grow in 2008, thanks to a rising number of women with high-paying jobs. Suh grew up next door to company's headquarters and was the only one of 6 siblings to take an interest in the business built by his father, Suh Sung-Whan. Joined Amorepacific in 1980s after earning an M.B.A. from Cornell University. An avid art collector, AmorePacific headquarters is filled with pop art pieces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun founded the Guanghui Group in 1989. Today, from headquarters in Urumqi in Xinjiang Province, Sun's companies employ 20,000 people and have operations in real estate, natural gas and logistics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Hopewell Construction 1963. Took it public decade later. Still chairs group, which has interests in infrastructure, real estate, hotels, restaurants. Son, Thomas Jefferson Wu, is Hopewell's comanaging director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zong launched Wahaha as a minigrocery story in a school in 1987. Today it's one of China's largest beverage producers and private businesses. Bitter dispute with Danone control of joint ventures hasn't helped the image of either, of late.
